content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												I rarely review games on Steam, but this was a special case. I got this game nearly a year ago and loved it. It was just the right amount of challenge, very rewarding, and pretty well-made, if with a few bugs. As the months went on, however, update after update ruined the game for me. Not only do I now have to pay more just to fully experience the game, but new systems such as the inventory system and mana system make the game much less accessible and enjoyable and have undone hard work I put into my character. The items also changed around significantly, as well as small but useful elements of the game such as the ability to destroy bushes and crates with queued spells. Portals regularly spawn near my character bringing him to the new and confusing level select hub (what happened to just playing through until death?) and undoing my progress in the middle of waves!In short I would not advise buying this game or getting new DLCs unless they bring it significantly closer to how it was in early 2015. I truly loved the earlier versions of Hero Siege and am so disappointed to see these updates ruin it so badly.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												This game isn't that bad, it has solid controls, decent atmospheric visuals and a pretty good gameplay loop. The problem I have with it is the pacing, it just feels really slow. I haven't played much of the game and I've only played a few classes, but the classes that I did play seemed underpowered at the beginning stages of the game. 2 of the 3 characters I tried had slow attacks that were pretty weak at the beginning of the game. The other character had a faster attack that still seemed pretty weak. It's just hard for me to get interested in a game which requires replaying the same level over and over to farm for experience points.I mean, maybe I just suck and other people have no problems at all getting past the first waves, I don't know. This game feels to me like it was balanced and designed around multiplayer, so playing it singleplayer I just ended up dying a lot to enemies who have aoe attacks which one-shot low level characters and having to start all over. This wouldn't be as annoying if you actually got sent to the first wave after the last miniboss you beat, but you don't. You get sent back to the beginning of the level and you have to slowly beat all of the other waves to get back to the one you're having troubles with. I honestly can't reccomend it because even though I did have some fun playing it, it kind of felt like a chore, and it's just not a game that I see myself playing again.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												TLDR: Great twin stick shooter with loot and stat progression.About 6 worlds, each with 5 levels and a lot of difficulty settings. This game is a 4 direction twin stick shooter.  There is lots of loot (Diablo, Titan Quest etc) for you to get and rare monsters to kill to get it. You get special relics along the way that increase your stats or give bonus attack options. There are stats you can level (strength, magic etc) and a basic skill tree to put points in to. There are also a lot of classes to play. Some of them are available with DLC (keep an eye on sales to pick them up) and they are all really worth it. This game is alot of fun and there is alot of replayability. Well worth the buy.

												Before the recent patch, i was obsessed with this game and i played it every day. I then came home from work to an update and i was curious what was changing as it was taking longer than a few seconds so i checked the patch notes. I didnt see anything bad so i just went into the game as normal on my level 111 Samurai and was heart broken by what i was welcomed with. "Swiftness" - 0 .... erm excuse me ? This game was so fun to play, and last week i thought of writing a positive review to tell everyone to buy it as i highly recommended it, i'm glad i didnt, because now the game sucks, not to everyone but to me and as i can see quite a few others it does. If the Devs could just revert to the patch prior to this 1.4.2.3 patch then the game would be back at its peak where it was really addictive and fun to play. I'm really sorry devs but im rating this game a thumbs down until you remove the mana system and bring back the speed and atmosphere that made this game fun. I have really high hopes for this game in the future, but if it is to keep going in the direction it is heading in currently, it's going to hit a brick wall, really fast ( not like it didnt just hit one after the latest patch ) Please fix this mess and bring back "Hero Siege" we all want you too so please, just listen to the community like you have always done and remove the mana system.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
												EDIT: I am still steamrolling as a level 80 in the Nightmare difficulty, already haven beaten the rare version of Damien. Anubis may be difficult, but this is still just a massive steamroll.TL;DR: easy grind that's irritating while still easy, just takes agesThis game has so many pros. It's just that it's easy & annoying in different aspects.This game is too easy in some ways. I'm a level 29 (30?) Pyromancer at the moment. All I do is spam the 2nd special attack whenever it gets too hot (pun unintended) and it wipes out everything next to me in seconds. The enemies will never do enough damage to put me in any actual danger, and it's never fun. The 2nd Throne Boss (death) died in less than a second, i'm not lying. If you really want me to prove it, add me and i'll put a video of it on Twitch. And the voice acting is just plain irritating. (and before you tell me that I should mute it, stop. i already did.) The Pyromancer has such an irritating voice. "YOU... ARE... FIRED" This wasn't even funny the first time. "THIS DUNGEON SHALL TURN TO ASHES..." Even MORE irritating. And he says this EVERY time he goes into a dungeon. The voice acting is annoying and has no variety, and it just ruins the feel of it.The music is okay, I guess. But it just plays the same track for each act over & over again. It doesn't have multiple tracks for each act, just one per Act. And while you spent a ton of time on each act, it gets unoriginal. I forgot to say, there's a ton of acts. And you can't get all of the achievements without buying the DLC (yes, that's correct, rare achievement hunters). Each act starts rather difficult, but the more you level up it gets so easy it's boring. And you just steamroll through it so quickly. This game's too easy, it's just one massive long grind. And I never thought an easy grind existed.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												Item interface is excruciatingly badly designed.  On lower difficulties, bosses literally die in .025 seconds after spawning (because the dev's didn't scale any of your abilities in strength, and it looks like the game was "Designed" around just one difficulty)Enemies are mostly stupid slow and not present in large enough numbers to pose a threat.  The only slightly threatening enemies are random traps you can't see due to weather effects or poison shooting slugs that slow you.  Every other enemy sedately walks into you.  This game would be challenging to people who have problems fending off the denizens of the local alzheimers home because that's about how fast waves of enemies move and spawn.Summoned creature AI lags and bugs out in multiplayer. my necromancer had skeletons frequently not follow him and just do whatever they wanted.Harder difficulties are literally just MORE HP MORE DAMAGE with no apparent changes.  Enemy variation is no different, and pack size seems to remain similar to what it was.Did i mention the item interface?  It's the most back asswards thing i have ever seen, with stupid unchangable hotkeys like " F D and G" for navigating the menus (which are also extremely frustrating in layout).   Quick swapping to a new piece of gear in a level is legit impossible because of the 16 steps you need to take to do so which will kill you.Game is described as "rogue like" - which is a flat out ♥♥♥♥ing lie.  It's got pre-set levels and difficulty.  An occasional mini-game puzzle popping up as a "Dungeon" doesn't make this wanna be bullet hell a ♥♥♥♥ing rogue like.Honestly trash game do NOT recommend.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												In short, a bug-ridden game is hard to love and/or recommend.Flashy effects and fun graphics. During many moments, you as a player can enjoy the excitement for trashing the mobs or speed-slaying a boss monster. The relic system in this game (little boost artifacts that you pick up from boss/chest/dungeons) have paid homage to fellow rogue-like games and some of the reference really gave me smile.With that said, this game has been out for alost three years, and the amount of bugs that I experience are at times ruining this fun experience. Quest-line bug, relics disappear upon save & exit, the game going into "slow motion" on some levels... With a ton more posted in bug report session that has not been heard of since. I have seen many posts regarding MP which I did not bother testing. I wonder what's in the dev's head as they push out new updates without keeping track of old issues. I bought the 4-pack while on sale and I have 3 gift copies. Yet I have to think twice about which of my friends to gift it to. Will this be a bless or a curse for them?

number of helpful: 31 of 49 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												Spending $5 (sale) on this wasn't a terrible decision, but it could've been put to better use.Pros:Easy to pick upYou can level up and get new skills that do things like stun or summon minionsBosses are good and reasonable, their AoE attacks are flashy but fair. Surprisingly, ones with ranged immunity are also reasonable, even if you're playing a purely-ranged class due to how common traps are.Cons:Simple and repetitive gameplay - Walk away from hordes of monsters while attacking them with sword/bow/magic/whatever, while also using skills whenever their cooldowns run out. This gets mixed up at times due to enemies with unique attacks ('maggot' enemies can poison a small area so it damages you if you walk on it), and the fact that melee classes involve a bit more skill since you have to be close to enemies, but it's not enough.Some skills are bugged or awkward to use - My Viking has a Stun skill that you have to stop walking away from an enemy to hit them with instead of walk-away-while-hitting which melee classes should be doing and a 'charge' skill that makes him run in a seemingly random direction (usually towards an enemy at least).You will die in one hit to an arbitrarily high-damage projectile or trap while enemies normally only do about a tenth of your health in damage. It will be unexpected and stupid.Getting the right beneficial potions, which randomly drop, will make you win too easilyA few potions will suddenly KILL YOU INSTANTLY when you have half health. Especially annoying because I've also wasted tons of full-healing potions because I don't want to die to a negative one.Devil Statues. Another terrible mechanic. They don't give you some kind of upside-and-drawback like 'evil' themed mechanics should, they can just PERMANENTLY lower one of your stats by 2, basically making you a level-5 character that levels up as slowly as a level-6 character, and so on for the rest of the game. Might as well just abandon that character to quickly level a different one up to 5.

number of helpful: 31 of 49 people (63%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												Disclaimer: I purchased this game using my own funds, and I do not write a review on a game that I have not paid for myself, because I believe they should be fair and unbiased. I don't believe you can get that unless you invest your own funds and support developers, and provide a personal sense of "value".UPDATE - I have been informed by two people on Steam that they were offered a free copy of this game if they would 'downvote' my review. Whether or not this is true is beyond my care level. It is a true and honest review, and I still recommended it, so don't know why this would have been the case. Was tempted to contact the developer and see if it was true, but as I despise drama, I let it be for what it is. Everyone has an agenda I guess?This is a great rogue-like hack and slash title that is sure to waste some free time. If you are a fan of Diablo, World of Warcraft, Torchlight, The Binding of Isaac, Fate, Legend of Zelda and many others, you will have some fun with this, as you can see elements of each game brought into this in their own unique ways. You have skills and talents to level up to further make your character unique, as you progress through various acts, all with unique background layouts that are quite fun. The comments your character makes from time to time are fun, and in 3 hours didn't get old or too overused to detract from gameplay. It has relics you collect that further enhance your skills as you play, all with unique effects. And hey - Trading Cards! Achievements!I originally bought this game on sale for $2 and with that being said, is probably where the price point should be.  The DLC is also way overpriced for the content that it delivers. While I fully appreciate the time and effort and creativity that these developers put into this game (and they *are* active), I experienced quite a few glitches with online play in just 3 hours. I also found the UI to be a bit un-intuitive, and it takes a short while to figure out how things work. But once you do, play progresses rather smoothly.There are quite a few regular glitches (that they are currently working on), but I really feel it has earned its very positive rating. It really does have quite a bit going for it!I can't speak much for single player play, as my experience thus far has solely been multiplayer, and aside from the glitches, I would recommend this game on sale. It has its own unique charm and blend of so many elements, the fun it provides was well worth the $2 I spent. When the bugs get worked out, and the price of the DLC drops to maybe $.99 each, I might put some more time into it. Honestly, we may just play it again a little more tomorrow....it was pretty fun.At $5.99 I would not purchase this game in its current state. Once all the bugs are worked out, and if the DLC gets included into that price, it would be a solid buy. If you catch it on sale, though, it will be a much better value.

Product received for free
												I already complained about the 1.7.1.9/1.7.2.0 release being bugged on its GNU/Linux and OS X versions and making cross-platform multiplayer impossible due to the developer probably not giving a fug about anything else than Windows, but at least it was playable in singleplayer.Not anymore. It's been SEVERAL days since the update, with many reports on their bug report forum, and despite attending other unrelated bug reports from Windows users, they remain silent on these. They just don't give a fug.I could understand why would a small indie developer not test on OS X since Apple computers are expensive (they probably made enough money off this game already to buy several Mac minis at least), but releasing for GNU/Linux without testing is just unexcusable. I don't understand why are they still selling this game as multiplatform when it's clearly not. It's dishonest.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Trying to be as neutral as possible, I still find myself echoing many of the comments made by others. The game is a fast and fun roguelike with enough customization to be enjoyable without being overwhelming. It's good for a few hours of fun.That said, it has gone through several changes to mechanics since I bought it, some of which affect balance and playability DRAMATICALLY. The mana system complaints are valid; it's frustrating to have high-level characters, into which you have invested much, suddenly become unplayable because their skills cost more than their maximum mana. The changes to skill synergies and itemization also significantly changed the game, though some may appreciate the changes. I enjoyed the speed of the game...the changes have increased the depth, which some players may like, but the game has lost its easy-going charm to me.All that to say: the game has been fun in the past, and may continue to be so. Be aware, though, that MAJOR changes have come since release, and may continue to come, that may completely change your enjoyment of the game.I have not have any contact with the devs, so I cannot comment on professionalism.

content:
Posted: March 5
												having owned this product for a decent while, I really don't feel like it's changed much. The leveling system is still the same - at first, it feels important, but you will quickly realize that the gear you find randomly by killing enemies makes the leveling system almost completely pointless, save the special abilities it grants you. Even the different weapons and gear really don't make a huge difference - very few enemies deal enough damage to be more than an annoyance, meaning traps are the only real threat to you. As your damage increases so does the health of your enemies, so it never really feels like you are doing more damage. Progression feels more like repetition than anything else. Not to mention the problem with keys - as you play, you'll find gold and diamond chests that I assume contain better loot. Not that'd I know, as keys are incredibly rare even for the iron chests, and nearly non-existant for the diamond ones. Half the characters are locked behind a dlc paywall for a game that already costs money, and already isn't really worth it.There is also the annoying problem of enemies and chests spawning outside of the boundaries of the map. There are often rat nests and ogre dens sitting just outside of reach, and in the case of ogre dens the "bonerang" ability can still hit you despite you not being able to hit its user, which is rather frustrating.Overall, this game feels like a good idea made out of a whole lot of bad ones, and the design choices are nothing to be proud of. I sincerely regret not having refunded this game when I had the chance.

I am also fairly good at topdown rougelike games as well, eg Binding of Isaac.

number of helpful: 130 of 235 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												Game Maker is a tool, and like any tool, you can use it well to create fantastic things, and you can use it poorly and make utter trainwrecks. The fact that I'm explaining this means you probably know what side of the line Hero Siege falls on.Hero Siege wants to be Diablo, on a basic level. It wants this BADLY. It breaks itself into 'acts' (with a new, fifth one in DLC form!), it has a bunch of classes with skill trees of their own, it involves semi-random world generation, and loot plays in heavily, with a smattering of crafting. Heck, it comes as close to ripping off the Diablo font as one can without a C&D being involved (if it's not actually just stolen outright - I haven't compared directly). The big problem is that the game's everything is a muddled, broken husk.The gameplay isn't mouse-based, and in fact, the mouse barely functions in the game. It's more like a twin-stick shooter, except you only have the four cardinal directions to work with (you can combine them to move diagonally, but if you can fire diagonally in any way, I didn't get it to work). Random 'traps' appear on the ground and around the world, and this is problem number one: the art doesn't convey things well. Things which appeared to be scenery would suddenly spit out a bullet and BAM, half my life gone. Even worse: bullets don't appear as the top layer of graphics, meaning they might hide behind other objects and suddenly go right through you. Instead of exploration being key, you're mostly in arenas which spawn enemies in waves. Sometimes you spend gold on items between, or level up with an incredibly pedestrian character skills tree here and there. (Fun fact about the level up screen: tooltips do not always work, so have fun figuring out if something is a trap or not!)To top it all off, this week there was DLC released for the game, which adds multiplayer. "Early Access" multiplayer, according to the in-game menus, but really the entire DLC is half-baked: for most of us, it doesn't work. At all. You can purchase it but if it doesn't allow you to unlock anything? Well, according to the devs, that's Steam's fault. It totally happened to a dev's copy of Indie Game the Movie, so that means they didn't code things poorly, you guys. (This is an actual excuse.) You don't want it, just like you don't want this game, but I really figured the technical problems were best summarized by that. Or the fact that options don't save/kick in unless you visit their screen, in which case it remembers "Oh yeah, you turned the volume down" or "Oh yeah, I'm set to Windowed mode!" and suddenly picks up on the thing that it saved to a file it refuses to load on boot? Also be careful dying if you're playing with keyboard! The mouse cursor can vanish (read: stop working entirely) on the death screen, making you force-quit the game to reload.I know I'm a harsh grader sometimes, but this is an honest plea from me to you: Hero Siege is a bad game made by people who are, at best, first-time developers way in over their heads. Please do not buy or support this title. It has been in enough bundles I've given out around 3-5 keys on my own now, if you MUST play it, wait for another deal of that sort. It's very bad, and not in a funny "it's better with friends" way. (Remember: online multiplayer is a DLC-only feature, so you're getting overcharged to screw around with pals who aren't at your place.) Everything it attempts is done better by another game, and most of those are just as cheap or entirely free.

It was quite playable at a certain point, a lot of people liked it before they started changing things. They literally made it worse and then handled fair criticism poorly. It's ridiculous.- Lack of tutorials or helpful information, which people really like. I mean it's not rocket science dude! I don't get why they just fail to explain things. What is this Dark Souls? Just feels lazy.- Shop prices are absolutely crazy imbalanced. The stat potions are stupidly cheap, etc.- Curse shrines are a massive blunder on the Dev's part. *edit* and I was tripping out about permanent stat reductions, they aren't as bad as I previously thought!I can't even be bothered to write the rest of this, there's so much wrong. There's so much potential and small great things in the game just gone to waste. I'm so sad man. Why devs...

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												I played this game many moons back but clearly not long enough for this turd to become a polished gem.Enemies hit you with nothing more than a passing glance, the game is a cluster♥♥♥♥ of bullets and instant death traps so never select hardcode mode unless you are adamant you have something to prove to the invisible masses (psst, the game is rubbish, so no one cares!) and speaking of invisible, the hitboxes are wonky as ♥♥♥♥.Its a game maker game from a 2 man team and I can forgive many of the shortcomings; hotline miami was a game maker game from a 2 man team and those games still had bugs too.So what is wrong with this game exactly?To sum it up the game plays closer to a bullet hell, which would be fine, if the collision detection was better and tighter. Games of that nature demand that you can dodge by the skin of your teeth and reward skill. That is why Touhou became popular.The online doesn't work for a start so the only reaso I bought it, to play with a friend, went out the window!Hit boxes are all over the place infact I died from looking at a giant ball. Its shockwave killed me apparently, although I dispute the fact since the ball was in the center of the bridge and I hadn't stepped foot on the bridge yet! Often enemies seem to hit you from afar, as if some kind of attack animation should be taking place but was removed or isnt working as intended.There is no hit recover either, so many attacks like acid on the ground will kill you in short order.Then there are the little niggles such as your health bar not showing how much health you currently have or classes that use abilities in the direction you are facing rather than the direction you are shooting or monsters displaying 0 health but are yet still being alive.This isn't a game that is so bad you have to share it, its just bad.Avoid.Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews

content:
Posted: February 3
												This is an incredibly fun, addicting game that I nonetheless can only give a heavily qualified recommendation. Why? Because it's the buggiest, most poorly-balanced and playtested game I have ever played, and I beat Fallout 2 before ever patching the damn thing. For example: certain power-ups will teleport you outside of the playable area, leaving you no way to get back, forcing either a restart or a trip to town; Key items for quests will spawn outside of the playable area; quests are utterly broken and don't seem to "flag" properly, so if you beat one, save your game, and restart, it'll still be in your quest log; certain skills have literally no effect on gameplay; character progression becomes completely meaningless in the endgame because the 100 or so attribute points you put into say, strength, will be rendered completely moot when you get an item that gives 10000+ points to a stat; there's no way to play certain melee classes at a high level because everything is an insta-kill; you move far too slow for a game with no way to avoid damage other than avoidance; etc.. There are others that I'm surely forgetting, but you get the point. Bugged. To. ****. Basically, you have to have an incredibly high threshold for utter nonsense to enjoy this game, but if you can get past the innumerable faults you'll find a fast-paced, enjoyable rogue-like with permanent progression and fun, varied classes to play with -- some of which are, as mentioned before, rendered useless once you start running wormholes and Toxic difficulty.

number of helpful: 12 of 16 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												* Please note my Hero Siege experience includes owning additional three DLCs: The Karp of Doom, The Depths of Hell and Wrath of Melvius. Every now and then I get an urge to participate in senseless acts of violence. And it can't get more senseless than hack'n'slash games. Please, don't even try to defy my logic here - RPG take on action genre is mostly ridicolous, yet I admit - it is also strangely satisfying.I've decided to pick Hero Siege and three available 'rift' DLCs while on discount - I got the whole package for less than four Euros, which is only a fragment of price of, let's say, Diablo 3 or Torchlight 2 full price. Of course, you can get good games for free if you want. See Path of Exile for more details.However, Hero Siege is not strictly an ARPG game, but a combination of genres. Part RPG, part twin-stick shooter, part bullet hell arcade, Hero Siege allows you to waste a lot of your time fighting various creatures in different arenas. Truth be told, Hero Siege doesn't even try to tell a story. There's none of it, unless you count some gibberish on Steam's store page which was probably written in around five minutes. After you create your character, you appear in typical RPG village. NPCs here don't tell anything interesting nor they give you any clues why you are there and what's your mission. Base game allows you to choose between one of seven available classes and DLC content unlocks several more. You can even unlock more classes with character DLCs which are unreasonably overpriced (spare me 'support the dev' stories unless you're part of MuHa Games team). Base game consists of four acts. These acts are being unlocked as you play, aside for DLC content which is unlocked as you're buying it. Each act is a rift consisting of five stages; four stages are ending with mini boss fight, while the fifth lets you fight the act boss. Levels are randomly generated arenas, mostly rectangle shaped, although some wild shapes appear in game later. Various dungeons and crypts appear in the game with interesting Sokoban-styled puzzles providing a refreshing variety to usual slaughter. Enemies are being dispersed in waves. Between the waves you can organize your inventory or search for healing orbs. Basically, fighting the hordes seems satisfying. Twin stick shooter mechanics are forcing you to always move and circle the enemies, trying to evade being caught in the middle. Beside enemies, you need to watch out for different environmental hazards such as flying spikes, acid rain, bullet spitting skulls etc. Every character can upgrade his skill tree which allows him/her to use different skills and fight more efficiently. Two of game currencies, crystals and gold, can be used for different purchases. Crystals are good enough for stats resetting, name changing, new hero skins and AI minion unlocking, while gold can be used to pay for items and Wormhole access which is nothing more but Diablo 3 Rift style dungeon where you fight the same fight for much better loot.However, there are few crippling problems with Hero Siege. First of all, after trudging through five and half acts and two of them in multiplayer mode, I don't find Hero Siege interesting enough to continue playing. Yes, you can turn up the heat and raise the difficulty level; you can grind all night long to finally unlock all the rifts and all the difficulties; yes, you can collect that gold, unlock those achievements and fight your way through various wormholes, but it is being boring the same way that D3 grinding is boring. There are games out there that disguise grinding as activity vital to the game, yet Hero Siege openly confesses you've seen it all and variations of the same ol', same ol' are all that's left. As I've stated previously, this game relies solely on its players will to waste time and kill senselessly, without the need to ask any kind of questions about anything. Yes, that might work in Binding of Isaac, but that's the thing with Binding of Isaac - it IS Binding of Isaac.Various bugs are also a serious problem for Hero Siege. Your enemies are getting stuck beyond your reach and unable to come back. Same goes with the items exploding out of arena walls and disappearing forever. An invisible walls will block your movement at the crucial moments. You will die and die again, while the frustration levels keep on rising. Inventory categorizing, equiping, dropping and selling is programmed with controller in mind and it's excruciatingly painful to interact with it using keyboard and mouse. Actually, using only keybord, since you can't use mouse to navigate the inventory. Did I mention severe lag in certain arenas that makes you move in slow motion? There you go.The main problem with ARPG aspect of Hero Siege is its lack of progress. There's no actual progress if you're able to get epic or legendary item early in the game. And that's what happened to me and, appearantly, several other players who reviewed this game. Overpowered items gained early in the game make players lose their interest early.Last, but not the least, I have to rate graphics as cute and sounds as damn repetitive.So, another one of those 'how the ♥♥♥♥ to rate this one' games. Truth be told, in nine hours that I've played, I had some fun because that's what I was aiming for - a senseless, turn off your brain and click game. If you're not a demanding player, lookin' for quick and cheap fix, get Hero Siege, but wait for sale - its lack of content (story, lore, original ideas), replayability and progress scale are actually ruining the fun aspects such as interesting controlling options and bullethell mechanics.If you're an ARPG veteran or roguelike champion and you're lookin' for a new addiction, you will not find one here. Hero Siege will probably leave you hungry, thirsty and frustrated.  ***You have reached the end of a review. However, there's more, plus giveaways, plus cool community of great gamers right at http://steamcommunity.com/groups/libereviews Follow the curator's page here: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/10953338/

number of helpful: 68 of 121 people (56%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												This game had a lot of potential, however, where the potential is there, it has been squandered.Hero Siege is a mix between Binding of Isaac and the class system of Risk of Rain. Hero Siege is targeted as a randomly generated evironment, and its gameplay is played in waves.Where you may be playing the game, you may think that it is very fun, but then, out of nowhere, you are instantly killed. From here, the problems start. The game has a great build system, unfortunately, youll find putting more of your stats into health and armor is better then anything else. The game starts to become a huge grind to level as your character struggles to keep up in damage to the enemies you face in the waves. At times, there is too much of a gap inbetween the enemies DPS and your DPS. Another problm is HP in that the increase does not scale well to the DPS intake from enemies.The game relies heavily on the player gathering relics to have a fighting chance. Unfortunately, relics typically are only found in dungeons, crypts and shops mid-round. To new players, crypts and dungeons often have enemies that are of higher level and have higher DPS than you do and it is not uncommon to be cornered and die to the swarm. The bosses in each of these locations can also one shot you unexpectedly, such as, Annie for example.At the end of a chapter there is a throne dungeon, it is in these dungeons I discovered the most game breaking bug of all. Save manipulation. My guide on it is here. After the player finishes the game, the game displays a message that the player has unlocked the next difficulty, but for many players, the difficulty does not unlock. There have been cases of players characters deleting themselves on updates, and lost data when playing. The DLC, Karp of Doom, adds little to the game. It is a Japanese-esque inspired chapter and it adds multiplayer to the game. Yes, multiplayer is paid for.I do not recommend this game, get BoI and RoR, you'll like them far more and not be frustrated in a bad purchase.

number of helpful: 13 of 18 people (72%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 8
GameplayHero Siege is a hack & slash game. That means the whole game is about slaying endless throngs of foes to get better equipment and to earn experience points to level up, which yields points to spend on stats and skills. The first thing you notice when you start the game, is the lack of information Hero Siege provides. You need to choose a class for your avatar but you get no information whatsoever about the classes: what are their strengths and weaknesses, what skills will they learn, what kind of equipment can they wear, and so on. So you either pick a class at random or you start googling for some basic information on each class and their respective skill tree.If you only bought the base game, the second thing you notice is how DLC heavy this game is. There are 14 classes to choose from, but 6 of those are locked out. When you click on these classes, a pop-up tells you which DLC you need to buy to play that class.You have an option to play the game on 'hardcore' mode, meaning if your avatar dies, it dies for good (aka 'perma-death').When you have decided on a class, you begin the game in a town. Here you find one NPC who triggers a Steam Achievement and one NPC you can sell stuff to. There are no merchants to buy equipment from and no NPCs to give you quests. To get ahead of myself a bit: Hero Siege has no quests and no story whatsoever. It's really all about the hacking & slashing & looting.You see 7 portals in the town, labeled act 1 through 7. Each act has 5 areas. You have to start at area 1 of act 1 and unlock each next area and eventually each next act. Again, if you only bought the base game you notice how DLC heavy this game is: 3 of the 7 portals are inactive because act 5 through 7 is DLC content. So almost half of the game. Before entering the portal to start your adventure, the last decision to make is the difficulty setting. Hero Siege has 7 difficulties. Of course, you won't be able to tangle the most difficult modes until you have gained some levels and found some decent equipment.I started playing the game using keyboard and mouse but almost immediately switched to a controller. You see, this game plays like a 'twin stick game': you need 4 keys (or 1 stick) to move your avatar in a certain direction and another 4 keys (or another stick) to have your avatar attack in a certain direction. Add to that another 4 keys (or 4 buttons) you'll need for skills and... suffice to say, a controller is optional but highly recommended for this game.Once you get to it, Hero Siege turns out to be a decent slayerfest. You find yourself in a small area. The opponents come in waves. You see a counter telling you how many opponents of the current wave are left. When you've killed them all, a new timer counts down to the arrival of the next wave. You can press a button (default: space) to skip the countdown and have the next wave spawn immediately.But you may want to use the time between waves to explore the area a bit. You'll find chests to loot, crates and bushes to smash and see if they contain any loot, more foes to slay and most notably: sometimes you'll come across a dungeon. These dungeons provide more foes, more loot and sometimes a miniboss. After about five waves of foes, a miniboss spawns. When you defeat this miniboss, you've cleared the map and can move on to the next area. The fifth and final area of each act doesn't spawn a miniboss but a full-fledged boss.You can return to the town at any time. Also, when you die you get sent back to town, unless of course you decided to play the game on hardcore mode.Like all hack & slash games, Hero Siege is all about loot drops. There are 5 qualities of items: white, blue, yellow, orange and purple. A real flaw is the item labels do not show the colour to indicate the quality of the item. All labels have plain white text. If you don't want to pick up every useless item (and you won't want to do that because inventory space is limited and white quality items sell for almost no gold), you need to look for a very thin glow on the edge of the item which shows the colour that corresponds with the quality of the item. Depending on where the item drops, i.e. the colour of the background, it can be easy or hard to spot the colour.There's a bug in the game that often causes loot to drop through dungeon floors and disappear. Sometimes, you see a purple quality item drop... through the floor and it's gone. In a game that revolves around loot drops, a bug like that is unforgivable.The interesting part of Hero Siege's loot drops are the relics. Relics are special items that boost your stats or give you an offensive or defensive bonus. You can gather and carry as many relics as you want and the total boost to your stats will grow... until you die. When you die, you lose all the relics you had on you. This an interesting mechanic because it motivates the player to be careful and try not to die when he has collected some useful relics. There are almost 200 relics in the game, so plenty of variety there, too.Once you finished the game on normal mode, or sooner if you feel up to it or want to grind some more levels before continuing your campaign, you can change the game's difficulty and replay areas you finished before. In that case, you'll find harder opponents and better loot in those areas. What I couldn't figure out is how to choose a difficulty and an area to make sure the loot that'll drop will be about the same level as your avatar. I've seen level 20-25 loot drop in the same area where level 80-85 loot dropped, which makes no sense.Another thing I couldn't figure out is what to do with gold. You build up a nice amount of gold but find nothing to spend it on. Sometimes, you'll come across a merchant NPC in a dungeon where you can buy a relic for a couple of thousand of gold coins but that's it.Graphics and soundThe game has very nice pixel art graphics. They look detailed, vibrant and colourful but not overly cartoonish. The music of Hero Siege sounds great. On the other hand, the quality of the sound effects is just so-so. There also seems to be a lack of sound effects sometimes, or maybe they're just too subtle to be noticeable. VerdictHero Siege is a decent hack & slash game. It's not the same level as the great ones like Titan Quest and Diablo, and it does have some problems and rough edges, but it is an above average experience, especially considering its low price when it's on sale or in a bundle. If you can appreciate the genre, you'll get up to a dozen of hours of fun out of Hero Siege. People who fall in love with the game and buy the DLC and/or play Hero Siege multiplayer (co-op) will get a lot more hours of playtime out of it.On Steam's extra featuresHero Siege has 5 Steam Trading Cards. You'll get 3 while running the game.Although it's certainly possible, it's extremely difficult to unlock all 60 Steam Achievements for Hero Siege. The main reason for that is RNG. For example, there is an achievement for slaying each of the 'alternate versions' of every boss. The chance of one of those bosses spawning is very rare. Also, there are quite a few achievements for DLC content and for online play. Lastly, there are some achievements that only people who play Hero Siege for many, many hours will attain, for example 'slay 50,000 monsters', 'collect 1,000,000 gold' and 'demolish 5000 bushes'. To give you an idea: having finished the base game (no DLC), I had about 70,000 gold. And after dabbling in the other difficulties for a couple more hours, I still haven't triggered the 'slay 6400 monsters' achievement.Although there are a lot of achievements that revolve around numbers like that, Hero Siege does not have achievement counters to show your progress (you know: '412/500' for example), which is a shame.

number of helpful: 47 of 83 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												It's not a bad game, but it's just too much grinding and too unbalanced.You can enter a dungeon in the first level and encounter enemies with 10k+ health while you deal around 50 damage per hit. While you don't have to enter dungeons it's the best chance of finding artifacts other than defeating the boss enemies every 5-6 waves. So it's a real gamble if you will be able to survive the dungeon or just end your run that way. I choose the viking as my first character and got an archer skeleton as my minion. The minion AI is horrible or better almost non existent. He doesn't follow you, but instead wanders around aimlessly. Yet he does 4-5 times as much damage as I do. So I lure the enemies to him and hide behind him while he shoots the enemies (and bosses). I pretty much just gather coins and revive him if he dies.When you level up you get 2 stat points which can increase your attack-per-second speed in the 0.01-0.02 range each point, your damage around 1 point, your armor percentage rating around 0.1% or your health for around 30-40 points. Investing in health seems to be the only viable option. It's a lot of grinding to gain a level and you only get a very minimal increase in you stats for that. You can find potions that increase your stats for this run, but they are randomized each run so you never know what a potion does until you try it for the first time. Of course there are a lot of potions with negative effects too so again it's just gambling.The presentation is nice yet simple. The different level have their unique setting and there's a good amount of different enemies. Some of the bosses are much harder to defeat than others and again it's completely random which one you'll encounter. Only the amount of hit points changes depending in which level you face them.Overall it's not a bad game, but it just doesn't feel balanced enough to be engaging. You can hit a lucky streak and get quite far or you'll just hit a brick wall in the first level. It's not skill, but pure luck.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												[My logged online hours do not reflect hours played offline.]There should really be a sideways thumb for games like this, but previously before all the recent updates I would have gladly given the game a thumbs up.  From when I personally had played the game, the mana update had come out and the game - as it was - was perfectly fine by me.  Arena-style, RPG elements, the overworld, etc. had a pretty alright feeling to it so I have nothing to ♥♥♥♥♥ about there.  Graphically it's quite pleasing on the eyes.  HOWEVER, I have noticed that the devs don't quite know what to do with their updates.The constant updates keep changing things about the game nearly every time.  You barely have time to get used to the new update before something else gets changed, whether minimally or completely.  There is no constant "making the game better" through slight changes or community advice.  It's game-changing changes that have kept me off from playing Hero Siege further.  Oh, and it's nice that you can't even complete every act because someone thought it'd be cute to release the rest of the game as DLC.  Cause that makes sense, am I right?  It's like if Stephen King wrote a book but only release the first two-thirds and released every chapter as a full-length book thereafter.But here are the positives that I previously enjoyed:+ The mana system was FINE.  ([-] HOWEVER, acking up the skills' use of mana is pointless for having said skills at said level if you can't even use them.)+ The overworld is alright.  Has portals per act.  Rather pointless to have though, not much to do other than sell equipment from a vendor you can't buy things from so you're left to hunt EVERYTHING down yourself (not that that's bad but it is tiresome after a while)+ Graphically pleasing.  Would not be surprised if they degraded it back to 8-bit or 16-bit graphics because we were all about 8 years old when the first Pokemon games came out anyway and that's how old the devs are acting.+ Bosses were fun... ish.  Getting through an area and mindlessly mass-murdering creatures with families and waging genocide to get to the next area left me with a tingly feeling all in my body that made me feel fuzzy.  It's kept me out of prison.- THE DAMN UPDATES.- THE DAMN UPDATES.-THE DAMN UPDATES.- Oh, did I mention the updates?Would I buy this game again?  If you like math, the probability of me buying this game ever again is 2 to the power of infinity minus one to one against.  So... no.

												The game is... Okay.Its a rogue-like so expect to die a lot and to get upgrades. It's a mobile game ported to PC... So don't expect much to come out of this game I guess.Pros:+ Art and Sound is pretty good.+ Game is pretty fun.+ Game has pretty fun multiplayer (co-op).. But.. (I'll get to that later)+ Game has a lot of content... But.. (I'll get to that later)Cons:- Bosses are pretty unbalanced. Some are 1 hit kill, and others 1 hit kill you.- The game devs DESPERATELY wants to buy its DLC. The game doesn't feel complete without it.- You HAVE to buy a DLC pack to play the co-op multiplayer.- The game always seems to have bugs, they let out small patches all the time but they don't seem to help at all.- Game gets dull pretty fast, no grabbing point.Overall, its an alright game. But they make you think you're missing something all the time. You won't enjoy this game unless you buy all the DLC (which is what they want). I honestly can't really recommend this game. You'll be annoyed with all the constant patches that don't matter. So no, I don't recommend this game. What I recommend the devs to do is remove the "Pay for DLC for multiplayer" thing. I don't know how hard it is to code and design games, but I'd also try remaking the game's engine or something, because it's very buggy.

number of helpful: 13 of 20 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Played with 3 friends.  Game was buggy in a lot of areas; one puzzle was unsolvable because only 3/4 of the pieces I needed spawned (friends saw all of them on their own screens).  A lot of strange design decisions; your character freezes and poses when picking up a potion but can still be damaged, the inventory system is clunky, and it becomes difficult to tell what flying projectiles belong to you and what belongs to your friends, especially when you each have waves of objects coming off of you.  Bosses didn't have different behaviors and were extremely easy to tear through in multi.Lots of in-app purchases, even for things like changing your character's name.  You get 10k of the real-money resource with your purchase, but I figure that Feels like it wanted to be another Binding of Isaac twin stick shooter, but it's not very satisfying and the controls aren't nearly as tight.  Very little variety in how you'll approach different waves of enemies because the random buffs you pick up don't change the game very much.  Wouldn't recommend.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												An almost very fun arcade style game with a lot of attacks, effects and events (crypts, treasure caves, traps) etc to keep something interesting always going on. However there are a few very bad flaws that turned this from a solid recommendation to a warning: - the game has no regular multiplayer. The menu screen has an option for multiplayer and then makes you buy DLC. Multiplayer should be part of the main game, trying to surprise you with required DLC is beyond sleezy. I'd rather have spent a few bucks extra on the main game than to have DLC for an essential part of the game forced down my throat. And many reviews say multiplayer is buggy and doesn't really work anyways.- there isn't really any balance. I like hard enemies, I like dying as I figure out a challenge. I don't like leveling so I can one shot almost everyone than a random boss/champion/trap appears out of nowhere with an unavoidable attack that squishes me. You keep your character level but have to repeat everything from the very first wave when you die which turns into wading through the early waves of weak enemies over and over again so get back to the boss that one shot you.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												tl;dr don't buy this game, even if they sell it for one penny. I'm sad. This is the first negative review I've written of a game on Steam. This game upon release was promising, character design still sucked and there were issues from hell to back (literally) on sprite models, items in game that'd break the game in your favor or make the last 10 hours you spent with a character meaningless (I get it, rogue-like elements, just wish someone would ♥♥♥♥ing tell me when I'm playing a Battletoads 3.) Multiplayer was NEVER remotely an option, unless you wanted to go to college for a four year degree in ♥♥♥♥ing with your router and your buddy's router settings, which for most of you underage folk just isn't an option. I see people comparing this game to Diablo 2, mostly because they blatantly ripped off the text from Diablo, but that's not a fair comparison. Blizzard communicated all major changes with the playerbase during that time, multiplayer thrived, there was a big competitive scene, it is still remarked as a masterpiece of the CRPG genre. In an attempt to seemingly fit into this genre, the devs have tried to add mana, but due to the nature of the abilities you use ingame, take up anywhere from 5-80% of your mana bar, so even though almost all melee characters had to dump points into brainless abilities and skillpoints like attack speed and strength, because the big bosses would whoop your♥♥♥♥♥♥from kingdom come unless you had an OP item or dodge all the seemingly random attacks (looking at you, Ra.) I wanted to love this game. I did. After the devs having no idea which direction to take it, blatantly stealing content from other games, refusing to work with a successful multiplayer game, banning everyone who tried to discuss content negatively on their site, the game not remotely being finished and ACTUAL parts of the game being sold for DLC and..well, the list goes on and on.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												Oh boy, where to start?Well, Hero Siege is a pixel-art Diablo clone. Great idea, looks promising, right?So at the outset, you need to pick a class before you can go dungeon crawling, leveling up and collecting procedurally generated loot. Something that bothered me right off the bat was the fact that nearly half the classes aren't available unless you pay some extra cash. Call me old fashioned, but I miss the times when you got 100% of the content when you purchased a game. This is particularly aggravating, if you consider that the multiplayer function is BUGGY AS HELL and simply doesn't work. Oh, sorry, I meant to say it's still "open beta", that's what they're calling it these days...Look, I know I'm coming off as an angry jerk, but the fact is - THIS IS AN UNFINISHED GAME. In its current state, it should be sold as "early access", and not as a finished product. I mean, come on! How many people purchased Diablo because of the single player campaign? My point being: This kind of game is quintessentially a multiplayer game, and therefore - if multiplayer doesn't work, the game is broken, unfinished."Shut up, Mordamir, it's good value for the money you paid." I don't care. You shut up.It's not about the price, it's about false advertising. Not only that, but there's a bunch of DLC available, while the multiplayer function isn't even working. There's a perfect example of misplaced priorities, in my opinion.But even if multiplayer were fully functional, I don't know if I would recommend this game. In all honesty, battle is reasonably fun, and there seems to be a good variety of enemies, and all that good stuff you expect to find in a Diablo clone. But the inventory system... I have no words, I really don't. It's  the stuff of nightmares. I remember PC games FROM THE EARLY 90s with better inventory systems than the one in this game. The mind boggles.Anyway, I'm really sorry I can't recommend this game, there's so much potential and even - dare I say - 'personality' in it. It all goes to waste because of yet-to-be-made-functional  multiplayer and an inventory system from the depths of R'lyeh.

Enemys are largely the same, the tougher ones have resisitances or more health or have a ranged attack, but are still only rats, skeletons, worms, or spiders. The actual combat is an absolute bore. You would do good to just take a pass on this one.

number of helpful: 24 of 42 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												Hero Siege is a game heavily inspired by Diablo and others. You play as one of many classes and beat waves after waves of Enemies until you finish the game. There are relics which increase some of your powers, various temporary items which are lost upon death which give stats or skills, statues that increase your stats permanently and potions with temporary buffs/debuffs. The game tends to be fun, however it takes time to get used to controls and the chaos going on. It depends a lot on luck and lucky generation of items, or else you're going to die for sure and restart all over again. Once you get a hang of it, it becomes fun but a bit boring as you're so strong it's no longer a challenge. Be wary after finishing a game on one difficulty you restart with no items on the next diff.>I'd give it a 8.5/10>Pros: Fun, lots of randomization, lots of items, good if you're a fan of rogue-likes and Diablo clones, graphics are neat. I previously stated bugs and imbalances as negative sides, however most of them are now fixed and they keep being fixed as reports come in.>Cons: Campaign acts which will come out in the future are all PAID DLC, also dislike the concept of not only having a DLC but an even more expensive "Collector's Edition". (DLC with acts and rest of the game should be free, collector's edition should be the purchase to support the developer rather than having it all paid for)

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												This game used to be a fun random roguelike top-down shooter. Now the difficulty has been ramped up so much you are forced to die over and over and over just to slowly grind levels.Before you could get tons of cool stacking random equipment, now they treat your character like a persistent RPG character with a single inventory and limited equipment slots.I think most of this was done for the co-op players who probably thought the game was too easy but if you play solo prepare for a ridiculous grind and millions of completely unfair deaths.The UI has also regone surgery and is horribly unintuitive, you will find yourself pushing random buttons to get through menus mid-game which will get you killed. Previously their in-game UI was so simple all you had was one button to go to your skill page and another to open the store and buy stats/items/hp.Now you have to find everything, even the useless NPCs in town have nothing for sale.I tried giving the game a chance I even bought the Amazon cuz I figured I used to like this game. Now it just feels like a chore, death will happen over and over and it's not your fault. Volcanoes pop up out of random boxes, enemies explode in your face, your companion wanders outside the map boundry and dies. And when you die you just get to start over from the beginning of the Act.Maybe this game is fun for certain "hardcore" gamers out there but I am not recommending it based on how much it has changed. This is not the game I bought two years ago. Not even close. (It's sad too because it looks the same and wants to be the same, but it's completely different.)

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Here, my opinion after going through a couple giga-threads about the game:From me: I like the game. I love the style and the mechanics. I am such a sucker for roguelikes and random generation, and that may have biased me into getting the game. Single-player was crazy good for me, and that was enough. I started delving in the community and the forums to see if the DLCs were worth my pennies. There are some major, glaring flaws in it: multiplayer has been a problem since launch and I never bothered playing online because it is buggy and devastatingly disappointing; the mana mechanic is well intended, but it is not balanced yet (there is a reason most successful roguelikes adopt cooldowns, skills are the best part of every character); some new items lack in the originality department and in more than one occasion the devs were disgustingly rude to the community.I could care less about Multiplayer. I gave up on that front. This game would be lovely with friends, but there are too many problems in the execution of it. Mechanics: I have my own bickering with the mana resource and with the amount of points allocated with every level, and I think it is not the optimal approach to the game. I usually leave attribute points unallocated because they don't even matter when compared to item and potion bonuses and onuses (eg. -40 strength). I hope this gets reworked soon.But that all was ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for me - I like the game and single-player, even with these flaws, made me happy. I like that experiments are being made to the game and, even when they are not well-implemented, it gives the chance of growth and evolution! To learn from mistakes made and get the good parts of it in other iterations! I love the new animations for the enemies!What killed the game and the possibility of buying DLC for me was a thread where a dev answered one of the many call-outs to the flawed mechanics with irony and disrespect. "boohoo mana boohoo equipments stop crying". No. This is NOT OK! There is no ♥♥♥♥ing reason for this ♥♥♥♥ing nonsense of disrespecting the fanbase that is playing a game that is in the same genre and niche of several better indie roguelikes! Risk of Rain, Nuclear Throne, Rogue Legacy, Eldritch, A Wizard's Lizard, Cardinal Quest, Teleglitch, even ♥♥♥♥ing Rogue Shooter! FTL gave for free a major update that revamped and added things to the mix! Devs for most up-and-coming indies are constantly listening their fanbase and testing things before making gameplay changes! It is NOT OK to just fall down and ♥♥♥♥ on your fans! I will not support this!I know many of the players share my POV. And I hope the devs get down from their high horses and start listening to the community that supported and helped the game get on the limelights. This is a good game for those who like to grind and to be merrily repeating stages, and has potential! But I would not recommend it to anyone now.I'm really sorry. I'm terribly disappointed.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												This game used to be a fun random roguelike top-down shooter. Now the difficulty has been ramped up so much you are forced to die over and over and over just to slowly grind levels.Before you could get tons of cool stacking random equipment, now they treat your character like a persistent RPG character with a single inventory and limited equipment slots.I think most of this was done for the co-op players who probably thought the game was too easy but if you play solo prepare for a ridiculous grind and millions of completely unfair deaths.The UI has also regone surgery and is horribly unintuitive, you will find yourself pushing random buttons to get through menus mid-game which will get you killed. Previously their in-game UI was so simple all you had was one button to go to your skill page and another to open the store and buy stats/items/hp.Now you have to find everything, even the useless NPCs in town have nothing for sale.I tried giving the game a chance I even bought the Amazon cuz I figured I used to like this game. Now it just feels like a chore, death will happen over and over and it's not your fault. Volcanoes pop up out of random boxes, enemies explode in your face, your companion wanders outside the map boundry and dies. And when you die you just get to start over from the beginning of the Act.Maybe this game is fun for certain "hardcore" gamers out there but I am not recommending it based on how much it has changed. This is not the game I bought two years ago. Not even close. (It's sad too because it looks the same and wants to be the same, but it's completely different.)

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												Let me start my review with "If it would be an early access game...":- "... then there would be hope that devs would fix unfinished/broken game mechanics". Let me detail this a bit more. The devs are still asking the players to report bugs. Devs this is your job before you release a game! There are plenty of game breaking bugs in there. For example, you may just die by running through a monster that is casting a mass attack because each bullet is counted. This keeps happening if you play a melee hero. Another annoying thing is, if monsters do not die within the "walls" items may just be dropped out of reach (happened a lot to me, mythics and legendaries just a leap away but you will never be able to collect them). Another problem are the "talents" and stats. During the game you may collect relics that boost your stats but in the very beginning you will have to guess which stat maps to the stats displayed in the character screen (strength <-> damage, energy <-> mana). Skills are just, ... usesless, most of the time the passives are the skills you will have to pick up (esp. paladin). The synergy of some skills is very simple and they do not really have synergies with other skills.- "... one may expect a working multiplayer part after EA." PanicNet vs. BattleNet. Well, there is not much to say. It is one server handling all the accounts... If this server crashes you will just have to wait until it is restarted and you have to hope that your items found in the last minutes are not wiped. One ♥♥♥♥ing server, are you serious devs? - This buggy♥♥♥♥♥♥of a dedicated server...I cannot recommend this game. It is a typical Game Maker game. Made by people who have not a little idea of software engineering, and testing. This game is a mess. It is fun but not worth the trouble...

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												TL;DR at the end of this Review.Absolut legit professional C++ coding at it`s finest !The game iself is a Diablo-Rogue-like-Bullet Storm-hack'n'slay mix up game with horrible balancing, lots of DLC's and boring skills.The devs say that theyr goal is to bring retro game titles back and challenge AAA games and hey they seem to have sold out mortal combat! So this Game must be awesome right?!(Doesn't mean that anyone actually plays it. Seeing max 300 online players at best) Well here`s what i think about it:Classes are unbalanced as hell. Some classes are just outright overpowered while others are simply useless. At early levels you will curse and rage due to constant dieing to some unbalanced poison wich will one hit kill you all the time. And don't even get me started on early Level progession of melee classes. Yet you will keep leveling up to the point where you won't even care anymore but will still only find level 7 gear because it's not scaling with your level rather than the difficulty your'e playing on, wich can only be normal since you have to play thru all of the game to unlock the next difficulty.Leading to you beeing level 50 by the end of act 2-3.Then you go and rush thru the rest of the game wich is then ridiculously easy just to unlock the next difficulty. This will keep on going until you're either too bored of laggy maps when summoning all waves at once (wich you easily can because you are level 50 now and the difficulty curve is like non existant at this point) or until you reach the difficulty you should actually be playing with your level.You will then realize that there are DLCs for this buggy mess of a game (i'm not going deep into that hole because i don't want to write a book here.) wich are exactly 5! Right now. You could of course go ahead and buy them to get access to more laggy maps, and all those fancy legendaries and stuff that comes with those. Oh and you also get a bunch of other classes wich nobody seems to play?And with all those DLC's and the Purchase of this amazingly well made game (wich is clearly early access. or IS IT?!) you are now ready for the onslaught of your life on the perfectly coded Servers!Unless theyr provider decides to not let you i guess? last time i checked you needed about 15 minutes to actually log in. make a character, get kicked, try to login again.Check out what the shop has to offer, leave shop, get kicked again, login for another year.If you are still sane and managed to make the character you hopefully like you can either play on a dedicated server wich didn't work anyways or you can grab up your own actually working connection, fire up your toaster and host the game by your own and finally ! Get your friend on it.But wait a sec! They also have to do this torture of login in! and hopefully they dont get caught in the login queue they've set up as a temporal (hopefully) solution to this stuff.I don't know if they fixed this yet and i honestly don't even care anymore. I reworked this review due to theyr way of handling criticism."quote"The Void  [Entwickler]  - The Servers are coded just fine, we have a server expert who made them with c++. Its the server provider that sucks, not the actual programming of the software. I love you pseudo-programmers who know everything about everything and call out "amateurs" when you probably have no clue how making games in this scale works, well not probably, you dont know how this works and what problems there are behind the curtains. You just dont know, ok? The Void  [Entwickler]   - "The devs say that theyr goal is to bring retro game titles back and challenge AAA games (good joke) while not beeing able to even handle the basics of theyr game." ^We have out sold mortal kombat on steam by 800,000 copies. I call that success and competing with AAA. The Void  [Entwickler] Vor 1 Stunde  Some corrections to your "pulled from the hat -facts".- First of all you dont need DLC's to enjoy the full game, because the full game is what you buy when you buy hero siege. the DLC's are simply extra content as in Expansions for the game, just like in any other game (WoW has like 6 expansions, Diablo has expansions, starcraft has expansions and the list goes on). And the Expansion amount is 3, not 8."quote end"So long story short:This Game is for all you people out there who like professional C++ coding combined with the feel of an unfinished early access Game. (because we all love early access don't we?)P.S. (this is not an Early access game)

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												Hero Siege combines the gamefeel of Gauntlet with the combat mechanics of Binding of Isaac. While the gameplay at its core is solid enough, Hero Siege has some very rough edges. Multiple currencies and an impossible-to-afford item shop reek of a bad mobile pay-to-win port, while an unconscionable number of assets are lifted verbatim from the games that supposedly inspired this one. Hero Siege goes beyond homage to straight-up theft, and for this alone it cannot be recommended.Still, the many unique classes and multiple difficulty levels offer a lot of replayability, and there is a unique sense of frantic and overwhelming odds which will push the player to build the most efficient character possible. For those who love grinding through waves of enemies and have no qualms about the use of stolen assets, Hero Siege will definitely offer a few hours of fun. For others however, the repetition will quickly accumulate into manifest boredom.

Marksmans first ability works based on the direction you are walking as opposed to the direction you are shooting? All the gold I collected disappears when I die, and I have to trade 1k gold for 10 gems, then it takes like 1k-5k gems to get any items from folks in town?Not really worth spending too much time playing. Maybe a 20-30 minute session every few weeks in order to remind you that the other game you have been playing for hours isn't really as boring as it has been seeming in the past couple days.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												I absolutely love this game, but it's a complete piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥Game is extremely unbalanced, a complete nightmare from that perspective.Character classes are mostly same-ey and undifferentiated since you only get 4 active skills and the rest are generally on proc passive skills. You'll struggle and die a lot in the beginning until you randomly happen to get a purple rarity item that literally multiplies all your stats hundredfold, and then since there's no level requirements on items you'll basically never have anything else to put in that equipment slot except for another purple with marginally better stats way down the road. There's literally one artifact that doubles your character's damage. Was breezing through the game until I died and lost it, and now I can't do enough damage to stay alive. Some levels are poorly designed and force you into tight hallways in a game that's all about dodging. Some stuff kills you instantly no matter how much health you have. Certain attacks will stun you long enough to cause everything in the map to converge on you and eat your face. Other times you find yourself breezing through bosses you kill in two hits. DLC basically just makes more levels and more enemies to fight, no new items, character options, or content except new classes to play. Game is often extremely buggy and chugs at times on my gaming desktop.Kind of fun if you can get a friend to play with, but then you have to go through the trouble of setting up port forwarding to host an online game.There's plenty of potential for good stuff here, but nothing in the game works the way it's supposed to. Really puts a damper on all of it. As other reviewers have noted, developers focus on putting out new DLC (which adds nothing substantial) rather than fixing the base issues with the game or finding some way to balance it. It's just one huge, hot ugly mess. Basically just a levelling/loot gathering treadmill where the treadmill keeps alternating between 90mph and 0.5mph without telling you what's going on.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												Honestly, wait for the game to mature. I realize it's on sale at time of posting for 90% off. Maybe pick it up and don't play for a while. The whole game seems to be fluctuating on a regular basis, and I wouldn't say I've seen the most mature responses from the development team in their update posts, or forum activity.If you want to drop a couple bucks on it and romp around a little while, have fun, and hopefully you feel the cost-benefit works out in your favor. I'll probably play some more, but I can't say I plan on investing much time or effort into speccing a character until they work out how to apply balances, and stop rubberbanding.Additional notes at time of writing:In-game button prompts and icons are only for Xbox controller. Trying to play with keyboard alone is pretty terrible, and frankly controller controls are wonky due to it being setup to play as a wasd/arrow twin-stick style shooter.Controller vibration, which is on by default, seem to occur whenever you kill an enemy, or get hit yourself. Given the bullet hell and swarm nature of the game, your controller almost never stops rumbling.Melee attack animations on enemies do not seem to line up with visual effects, leading to confusion as to why you take damage.In-game HUD for inventory is unintuitive beyond belief. Current equips on the left, with a center column that displays other equal-typed items (such as other helmets) when you're hovering over an equip slot. While hovering over an equipped item, the far right panel displays that item's detailed description. Selecting into an equip slot lets you navigate the middle pane and swap an equipped item with the item you're selecting (note, the details pane remains pointed towards the currently equipped item). Comparing the actual stats between items requires an additional button press to change the middle navigation into a detail description of the inventory item that is not equipped. Sound confusing? It's equally weird to navigate on your own.Overall, feels like a slap-dash pixel-art port of diablo, and not really in a good way.I plan to keep an eye on it for a while, but it's certainly not great.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												This game is so insanely frustrating.I have played quite a lot, but still haven´t gotten past the first act, you´d think that leveling up would make a difference, no. You might as well be level 1 the entire game, since the stuff that will kill you will one-shot you even if you´re at full health of 2k. Should the first act really require a top-level character?No invinciblility-frames, ever.Numerous times I´ve been killed by arrows or something else the first frame when teleporting in to a new area, after killing a boss. Before I even have time to move, let alone react.Especially one boss (the one with the red beams in a rotating cross pattern) is damn near impossible to dodge if you´re not in a good spot to begin with, so he will kill you as soon as he appears on-screen, before you even can see what boss it is. Since you can´t fire diagonally, you´ll have to stand at a straight angle, bam you´re dead.I had this boss on wave 6, 5 times in a row, that didn´t feel very random.Forget about exploring the dungeons, they´re cramped to all hell, and (usually) filled with mobs with 8k health that hit like a ton of bricks. Forget about buying anything in the "Treasure room" anything other than stat boosts will be 1k gold or more, and from my experience those rooms only appear when you don´t have enough money.If you get a good relic or wo, you´ll breeze through wave after wave, until something random and unavoidable kills you, sending you back to square one. Very rarely do I die and not have a "That´s bulls**t"-feeling.Played a little co-op with a friend, after 10 minutes he said " I will never, ever play this again"What´s even cheaper than the 1-hit kills, randomness and outrageously OP dungeons is the developers adding online multiplayer as DLC, even if it doesn´t cost alot, that´s just weak. "Fututre updates are only for the DLC" wow, yeah this is getting uninstalled asapI can´t believe this game has a "Very Positive" rating.

												When I first met my cousin who lives on the other side of the world-it turned out we were both PC Gamers. He showed me Hero Siege for the for the first time and we both really enjoyed it. I buy the game a few months later. I realized there was no more attack speed available for upgrading and it was replaced by mana. I was a bit mad at first but decided to shrug it off because the game was still really good. I was enjoying playing as samuri because I bought all DLC that was available at the time. Later on Wrath of Mevius came out and I coughed up my 3$.Now everything was going fine until todays update. Now my samuri build can not be used. Hours of work crashed and burned because I can not use a single skill because of the overwhelming cost. Even the cheapest skill cost a few hundred more points then I have. They are gonna fix this in around a day I thought. But then I saw the "act 8 under construction" area. You are telling me they are making another DLC? When the already partailly broken game due to new updates, now unplayable because of todays is being ingnored because of a DLC we never asked for? Also when they promised Wrath Of Mevius is the last one. WHAT THE F***??? They took out, attack speed. They took out skill charging/cooldown system and replaced with mana. No one liked mana. Then today they took A HATED SYSTEM AND BROKE IT?? AND THEY DON'T TRY AND EVEN FIX PAST PROBLEMS BUT WORK ON MORE $ GRABBING DLCS WHEN WE ALREADY HAVE 4 FOR A SIMPLE ROUGE-LIKE? I'm sorry. I loved this game. Developers ruined it. Please, may a develper respond to this and address what I said here. That would be highly appriciated and the first step to fixing your currently broken game.EDIT 1:The develpors have realized their mistake, and are currently working on the problems created in the last couple of days.

												I was gifted this game a day or two ago by a friend, so my review is in no way biased from a point of feeling like I wasted my money.Pros:-Not very PC intensive, which means my craptop (only computer I have right now) can run it-Cute graphics, reminds me heavily of The Minish Cap (a zelda game)Cons:-You have to buy it, and there's still a lot of microtransactions.
