Us gamers have made it very clear that we don't like this type of thing (looking at YOU, EA)-No in game tutorials or instructions or how to play option. Game literally just plops you down without telling you what it is your supposed to be doing-Awful voice acting that (as far as I can tell) can't be disabled-No HUD/GUI customization-No story. This one's just a personal preference, but it's still a con. Since the game appears to be a Diablo-esque game on the tin, I figured it would have at least some type of readily apparent story.-GUI is clunky and visibly unappealingOverall score: 2/10. Would not recommend.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												This game is extremely entertaining, but there are a number of bugs that you'll come across that are just extremely annoying. In multiplayer you'll lose your relics without any explanation. Friend dies when you're in a portal queue? Let me take them relics boy. It's random minor bugs like this that make the game annoying. One HUGE issue with the game is the multiplayer syncronization. What you see isn't what your friends see. When you're doing small tasks like dungeon puzzles, your teammates can mess that up really easily without knowing it, because instead of being a co-op task its four separate singleplayer tasks with invisible multiplayer interactions (wtf?)It's fun to play casually, but for the price you're better off getting a fully developed Loot RPG.I would recommend thsi to the casual player.For players such as myself who love to dive deep into an Loot Hack and Slash RPG, well; Classes are unbalanced to a large degree (scalings on some characters are non existant)Classes you purchase through DLC are often underwhelming (I payed extra pls gimme more)There are tons of glitches and bugs that you'll find annoying.Multiplayer is lots of fun, but the bugs really ruin it.There is no ingame Archive of relics. Anything would help, a log that keeps track of the relic and the description maybe.The main personal thing I'm salty about is the amazon. Why the hell do none of her skills scale? Wtf?

content:
Posted: April 3
												Do I recommend Hero Siege?Ehhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh No, not really.The gameplay is decent, a little hard to start, but okay nonetheless. The issues are the following:PriceOk, FIRST OF ALL, I do not have all of the DLC. Why? Because I'm not keen on spending, what? $3~$5 on another arena that has similar layouts as other arenas. Pardon me, they are called "Acts." You know, that name developers give to parts of a STORY and not what seems like parts of a continent. Is there a lore or story at all? Yeah, sure, there are games that don't really have a plot where one isn't needed, such as survival games, but there are exceptions (Starbound). But plot can make a game more intriguing while you are bashing away at baddies or farming or whatever. What am I reviewing again? Oh that's right, price. There are uncanny purchases when shopping for Hero Siege. $3 for a new character (and maybe an act), then for $2 more you can get ♥♥♥♥ing cosmetics that you have to look for in their terrible menus. 5 of the DLCs that cost $5 are just ♥♥♥♥ing cosmetics, seriously. (And yes, I do know that people buy it to support the developers, but if you want to have some way to support a game, just have a damn patreon. Steam gets a portion of the purchases and sales won't help.) I thought TF2 was the king of♥♥♥♥♥♥faced cosmetics, but atleast in TF2, when you spend $5 dollars on a cosmetic, you can ACTUALLY see detail instead of a pixelized version of it. I bought 2 DLCs and already spent more than what the game's worth, and I bought this before the price drop from $10, then again, I got it on sale for 95% off or something.BugsGotta love crashing, am I right? It is unbearable, the creatures will sometimes spawn outside the boundaries and their pathfinding won't update, so I'll be walking around trying to look for something that's stopping me from advancing to the next wave. Heck, sometimes crypts, dungeons, statues of my bum will spawn outside the boundaries[steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net], just ♥♥♥♥ing out of my reach since you get teleported to the middle of the arena if you try to pass a gate. One gate teleports you if you just touch it. It's really funny to walk into a dungeon and get smeared to the wind because your character is too underleveled. Sure, melee characters have sort of an AoE attack that causes them to hit behind them sometimes, but even with the melee attack, you still get ground up and used on salads and plants as fertilizer.Here's a joke, what happens when your friend crashes in a multiplayer game with you, but you are still connected? Their character turns into you[steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net] and you have control over it while you are still in the same area.Too long so you didn't read itA buggy game with overpriced, useless DLCs.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												This game crosses the line from being inspired to trying too hard to mimic the success of another game. It's clear to anyone that's played or heard about Blizzard's Diablo series that this game takes many things from it, Diablo III in particular. Just from my limited amount of time playing it, I found that it steals too many things from Diablo III for me to look the other way. The rather pathetic copying of material disgusts me, but the overall product coupled with the total lack of creativity makes me unable to enjoy just about anything about this game. I understand that the developers' goal of wanting to make games that harkon to the legendary games of old, but, like I said, this crosses the line from the land of the inspired into lazy money-grab territory.Diablo font? Check. Diablo's names for difficulties (Normal, Nightmare, Hell, Inferno)? Check. Diablo III's champion/elite modifier of spawning stationery rotating lasers? Check. Secret level named and themed around a form of livestock? Check. Treasure goblins that function serve the same purpose as DIII's? Check. What's worse is that I painfully predicted that they would open a portal and disappear if I was unable to kill them, and as soon as it did as I predicted, I sighed in anger. All of these painfully obvious thefts, on top of a game that has very random spikes in difficulty, very little room for skill to play a factor, and poorly designed random elements make for a game that'll also steal your mood and sour it. Anyone who tries to compare this game to The Binding of Isaac does nothing but shame Edmund McMillen's game. The Binding of Isaac has a much better system in place to allow for players' skills to be developed while providing an environment of adequate pace with well-scaling challenge and the expected mystery of randomized rooms.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												Most of what you are reading is basically "MANA UPDATE AND ITEM WIPE RUINED IT". Now this consistency might sound circlejerky and immature at first examination. But it is completely true, and it is why a game I used to play for multiple hours at a time, I can now only muster 15-20 minutes of before I drop it for at least a month. It hurts that a game that I was once addicted too, that I've bought all the DLC for, now is completely unsatisfying. Please don't let the "Very Positive" label fool you, those positive reviews are outdated.Early game:Basically a top down fast hack slash with RPG elements that took a lot of design choices from The Binding of Isaac (I highly recommend TBOI, go play any version of that instead, it is what you are looking for if you like a game like this.) You would fight five waves and a boss in areas, and after five areas you would move on to an act boss and finally the next act. Dungeons and shops have the chance to spawn after each wave in each area. (This hasn't changed) Each character has a skill tree and stats to apply. Among the character tree are both passive and active skills with level requirements. Active skills could always be activated whenever off cooldown, encouraging expirimentation with how they combo together and how best to use them in sequence. The skills are binded a bit akwardly, but can be gotten used to, taking up 1234 slots and not slots closer to the WASD buttons like Q, E, R, and F, or something similar.  Honestly the game took some grinding, as even though skill and stat points applied are permanent, they serve more to augment which of your characters stats or skills does end up more prominent than others. Relics found in dungeons, bought in shops, or picked up at the end of areas heavily help your character, giving certain passive or active skills, or even just certain stat boosts. The actual combat was pretty fun in a lot of ways, so the difficulty due to health/armor constraints disappeared the longer you play or the farther you get. An inventory with items [still constricted to your current run I think?] was introduced. It didn't have too much depth, but it was just starting and there were some items that made getting skills above your level requirement possible, so it was pretty nice. It doesn't pause the game for it though, so you have to be fast. It is made easy by the side by side comparison of the currrent and new item, and the simplicity of the choice of either replacing or dropping. Definitely wasn't perfect, and didn't have the greatest balance, but it still managed to be fun, at least for me, so w/e. :) Multiplayer was in development, quite buggy, but it was exciting to think that online co-op was coming.Changes:I had dropped the game for a bit due to other games grabbing my attention (Dota 2, TF2, Half-Life series, etc.), nothing I mentioned before really forced me away. But the combination of all this new stuff is ....eh. SUDDENLY MANA. Not only does this add a constraint to gameplay that maintained a lot of its fun due to fast combos of spells for some classes or spammable spells for others, mana costs grow exponentially for all skills per points put into them. This means gameplay is nearly permanently slower forever. Fun crashes to lowest levels yet. Pre-existing characters suffer the most, as the  more skill points they have, the more trouble they have now that they have nowhere near enough points into this new attribute that controls mana. Experience for levels also still grows exponentially it seems, so it isn't easy to grind the stat points needed.Items you had are wiped as the inventory is complicated. You can hold onto items now however, you can't just walk over items to pick them up (this might of been how it was in the original actually so scratch that?), the inventory controls are now clunkier and laggy to accomadate, and you still aren't paused, meaning you can still die while struggling to navigate your even more complicated interface. You can't just add more button presses to just equip an item without allowing the player more time to do so. This can be circumvented with only fiddling with your inventory at the end of areas, but it still is slow and a bit frustrating. From what I've noticed, the grinding and difficulty issues haven't been really fixed, but I can hardly play this for any comparable duration, so what do I know? I guess I only have my complete disinterest in the game as of now to control my decision making  ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ KappaMultiplayer is a bit more playable, but there are still many issues.... yuck.There is now a town warp that helps with reaching end game content which might help some with grinding and has some odd stuff (A beach ball and a probable boss rush maybe?). Has some pale excuses for NPC's, and an acheivement for not ignoring this new yet bare bones looking feature. Could work if I could stand playing this for longer...?Okay, I'm definitely being repetitive with how it isn't as enjoyable, but it is a main part of why I liked this so much. The balancing is awkward, the controls are a bit weird, and the grinding has always been a bit of tedium. But there was also the satisfying times of sequencing or spamming spells, and finding more and more relics to majorly augment my run kept me hooked despite it not being a "great game". This was a guilty pleasure of mine. But I now I feel with these changes I've been pushed back into the grinding, and it will be even harder for me to find enjoyment in it to the same extent due to the limitations of the new game. I mean, I haven't even had personal experience with the apparently horrible staff. (All I know is that from the time I followed the creator's twitter he was often quite bratty) Play something else. Save yourself the time.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												What wasn't told here: This is not a full game. Despite the 7 portals (acts) at the town, this game has only 4 acts and then it finishes and unlocks nightmare mode and so on. You will not fight Damian, the villain on the trailer, unless you buy the DLCs (I saw at least 3). There is also a 8 act described as "under construction".There are 12 classes, but 5 are locked due it's exclusiveness.There are 8 NPCs on town, but only 2 will be usefull for trade purposes. The others are probably from DLC's quests.I bought it on a sale, VERY VERY cheap. The normal price is just unworthy. Wait for a sale if you are curious.Other topics:Gameplay: It's just a regular hack n' slash/shooter game in 8 bits style. Attack anything that moves (and also what doesn't), collect loot, upgrade, repeat all three steps forever. You can't shoot diagonally (what is awful). As you level up, the screen gets more and more crowded with enemies and traps. The AI is dumb and monsters get stucked on walls or outside the playable zone.Story: It doesn't has. There is a couple of NPCs just for trade purposes.Customization: New gear don't change character's appearance, there is a shop outside the game, where you can buy gear just for sake of style. The skill tree doesn't allow character building, it's linear.That is it.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												By answering No in the question if I would recommend this, don't be mistaken, I'm not saying that Hero Siege is a bad game.The reasons that I do not recommend it is that it is not a complete product, the game still evolves and feels like an early access, even in core mechanics (by the time Im writing this, its about a month since they added mana as resourse to all characters). Quite many stuff need further work, eg: many maps are fixed, meaning while some early maps have random elements and feel that are generated others in later acts are fixxed and no matter what, eg: the lava river pattern, will always be the same). Heroes start as weaklings and eveolve into gods, doing more that enough damage to clear the monsters, but you will find occasionaly the random monter that may/can/will oneshot you, with you having little to no resposne to that, even while you are trampling over the hordes of enemies. Bosses still need a lot of work since they die quite fast and few big monsters can be more durable than hem. Lastly a big negative is the dlc policy, given that extra acts/heroes and a multyplayer game mode are part of dlcsThat been said I do enjoy Hero siege (given that I've played quite some time) but having the knowledge about the game I have now i wouldn't probably buy it. If you do love almost-meaningless hack n slash with rng elements then by all means I do recommend hero siege.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Definitely worth the less than dollar I paid for it. Full price, probably not.I'm not entirely sure what the point is. The story is quite weak. The gameplay is just wave after wave of enemies with a few bosses and dungeon instances thrown in. But every time you do an instance, the entire world regenerates when you come back out. If you wanted to dive into both of those dungeons that have appeared, you're out of luck. Maybe I just got lucky on my third guy, but I played for 3 hours straight and the game was laughably easy. It took less time to get the mini-bosses (which you encounter after every handful of waves and at the end of dungeons) down to 0 HP than it did for the game to do the death animation (they have a drawn out death animation where lightning strikes all over and an angelic choir sings and the boss goes "AAAAAAAHHHHHHHHH!" for like 10 seconds).The gameplay is fun, but it's nothing we haven't seen before. The "rouge-like" aspect of it is a stretch. You just lose some of your stuff. "With RPG Elements" means there's XP, Leveling, Skill Points, and an inventory. The inventory is confusing. The control scheme is weird and inconsistent (F is the action button? But sometimes you have to press Enter... Wat?). Um... the good stuff about it is that I sank a bunch of time into it without really feeling it very much (except for the "too easy" bit).It seems quite a bit of content is missing from the base game. Evidently, the DLC portions of the game are each worth at least 50% of the base game cost even though it doesn't seem like each adds 50% more game. I haven't purchased them so take that with a grain of salt. There's enough wrong with the base game that it didn't seem worth it to dish out $10 (full price) for DLC (that's more than the game!).The multiplayer was down and I didn't want to make an account with these people, so I didn't experience that aspect of it. Maybe multiplayer is where the game really shines, but from what I played the game just wasn't compelling enough for me to want to keep giving it my time. For that reason, and because of it's faults, I can't recommend you buy it at full price.5/10 because I want my roguelikes to kill me. And because it lacks polish where it counts (balance, core game systems, multiplayer servers...).

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												I keep WANTING to like this game. But every time I get a few hours in, something goes wrong, and now I'm just getting rid of it.I've played the (ludicrously buggy) multiplayer with 2-4 people. The interface is like something youd see from the EARLY 90s, both in the multiplayer and the game in general. I haven't been on the forums or heard all this dev drama, so I know nothing of the vindictiveness, but the amateurish programming? Oh yeah.Several fun ways you can die (losing all the relics youve worked hours for) include:- 1-shot instantly. As a "death recap" all you have is a black screen and the template pixel of the projectile that killed you. One of the recent patch notes I read said this should not be possible from full health. It's happened twice in two days.- Game crash for some sort of bug. Still. After over 2 years, there's no getting returned to lobby or menus, just time for good ole task manager.- Popping a chest on a water level, then getting chain-rooted in place by potions until you run out of breath, because picking up a potion takes priority over moving or BREATHING.- Getting locked in place while trying to pick up an on-use relic as it constantly switches with your current on-use relic, much like potions.After hours spent building up your temporary stats and relics, the amount of times I've thought: "ah, okay that was good progress, I'm done playing for now," is maybe 10% of the time. The other 90%? Great, another bug. Screw this I'm done.Now, I'm just done for good. Pretty sure a friend got me this game after buying a 4-pack for something like $3 on a sale. There are plenty of cheap toys you can buy for less than a dollar, and this game fits right in with them.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Binding of Isaac-like random powerups, level progression and hack'n'slash, sounds great!Too bad the basic gameplay is crazy repetitive and the feeling of progression is not there with the current skill/attribute system. Example: The Viking has a skill Stoneskin unlocked somewhere around level 18, which gives you 1% chance to "gain a massive boost" to armor. This massive boost is 5 points of armor, which translates into 1% damage reduction. The skill doesn't mention when does this happen, nor how long does the effect last. Most of the skills and attributes are equally underwhelming and most of the information is either hidden or wrong (Pirate lvl1 skill at rank 1 claims to do 25000 damage, lvl28 skill at rank 1 claims to do around 40, neither is even near correct).The main thing you're collecting is money, but the only place to spend it appears randomly (high chance that you'll get too much money to spend). Most of the items sold are just minor stat gains for this particular run. When your Pirate has a good chance to shoot a cannonball for 1000 damage, you really don't care about that +5 strength which would give you about 2 damage per attack.Chances are, that the game is balanced for "end game", but I can't seem to find the fun in trying to reach there. Was fun for a few hours, could've been way better (and apparently has been, if other reviews can be believed).TL;DR: Your generic minion available to all classes hits harder than you. If you don't care about any details how the game progression works and like hacking away, this game might still suit your needs.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												I do not reccommend this game at all, unless it goes on sale for less then $4. The so-called "twin-stick, gauntlet style/diablo/binding of isaac/etc" gameplay is not at all relateable, and the game turns into a hold an attack direction and wait for either an ability to go off cooldown (every 15 or so seconds) or have an ability proc an additional effect when you hit an enemy with a basic attack.When you level up in this game, you get a tiny bit of health, and a tiny bit of damage. The game jokingly gives you the option of increasing Health, Attack Speed, Defense, and Damage. You can dump every point into damage, defense or attack speed, and you will notice zero difference. What kind of damage increment is a FRACTION of one point of damage, when monsters have increasingly high scaling health in the thousands and tens of thousands within a few hours of gameplay? What is 0.01% damage protection and attack speed?? Why would they have increments so damn minor they don't even matter?? At least with the health upgrade, you can maybe survive another hit with enough points... but therein lies the next problem.This game has no difficulty curve, especially on one player. Eventually, you will be put in a situation where an attack is unnavoidable, because a projectile/enemy ability will FLASH across the screen (or off-screen) and hit you, which causes immediate death . Worse yet, enemies are capable of stunning and freezing you, even some common enemies, and they may continue to keep you locked in place permanantly until death. Virtually every boss in the game has an ability that kills you in one hit from what I've found in my three hours of gameplay. It's so horribly painful to spend so much time grinding, just to be one-shot by something you couldn't avoid. Bosses are not fun to fight. ...With all that being said, the reason why I -do- like this game, is because it can be fun if you are looking for some silly mindless gameplay, especially if you are the sort that likes to grind for items. Don't get me wrong, the game is still horrible through-and-through, but random luck streaks are always exciting. But the time and price investment simply do not outweigh the issuesOn a final note, multiplayer is still broken. So I guess it's permanantly single-player for a lot of folks in any case.

												Needs dlc to be actually played. Got it in some sort of bundle. Idled the cards. Would uninstall again 5/7EDIT:Oh,a developer response! wow! Jokes aside then, since this is a hack and slash game where ultimatively the end game represents gearing up your character to the maximum level, not finishing up the levels. For me at least.While the game does a good job at hooking you up to this, just the idea that i would have to pay for dlc's to reach what i want from this game is off-putting.I understand that dlc's are a productive marketing strategy and I have nothing against that. Coming from a dota 2 background, i like to have everything available right when i play the game, not behind another paywall. I personally think dlc and ingame purchases are best used for cosmetics and not actual content. And i did pay for compendiums and cosmetics in dota 2 because i felt the game is worth supporting.That is the main reason i don't want to play the game right now. Perhaps when i see the dlc bundled in some kind of steam sale and get them for cheap i will want to play the game :) I am a fan of hack and slash games, ever since Diablo 1 hooked me to the genre.Just to note, regarding my review, it is supposed to be for fun, i cannot objectively review a game i did not actually play.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												This game has an incredible amount of potential. That said, IT IS NOT A FINISHED PRODUCT by far.  To begin, I have the DLC so I can't tell if the release has changed the fact that YOU MUST BUY DLC FOR MULTI-PLAYER.  If it has that's an awesome improvement, since when I bought the game opened to play it I found myself curious as to where the ♥♥♥♥ the multi-player listed had vanished to.  It isn't abandoned yet like a lot of seemingly money hungry indie devs, there is always updates. A lot of people are complaining about difficulty, I found how hard the game was to be refreshing. Sure you can be one shot, you're not supposed to get hit.  The problems start with the updates ALWAYS breaking something far worse than the original problem.  At first the bugs I was getting in multi-player were things like random CTD's or Random server disconnects. Things like the clicking through the server list would put you into a random server instead of the one you wanted.  Useless Skins since they don't show up (you'll see it but others will not) in multi-player, Glad I paid for the collectors edition.  Also dungeons and traps were a little misplaced and unreachable for anyone other than the host (It really sucked seeing a trap in one area thinking you're safe and your buddy being♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥because on his screen you just ran full speed into a trap).  Also various Item bugs surrounding relics. My buddy and I decided it was a game worth looking into after some updates.  A month later we hopped back in and seen the  Server list was fixed and got our hopes up from there.  We begin playing and (He's hosting) I'm running around and BAM 'm dead nothing around wave 1. I'm like ok must have been a trap I'm just bad. Happens again and again and my buddy is resurrecting me saying " Dude wtf why do you keep standing on top of these traps?"  Turns out the misplaced traps are now invisible.  On to the updated dungeons.  Go into the dungeons buddy hits said button to activate said bridge runs across and the bridge never activates for me (tried several different dungeons activation only registers on hosts game client).  The skins now don't even show up for you (Extra glad I bought the collectors edition >.>). I think the worst part is that the Dev. actively responds to the community claiming that he has fixed something that is still very much broken or worse.  Or that his companies facebook is consistently updated concerning his league of legend rage.  Also seeing how much he rages about league of legends and looking at this almost $10 game on my steam really, really pisses me off. Plus I think he has got to be pretty horrible like silver ranking cause it is so much rage.

												Meh.I'm surprised by the "very positive" reviews.You grind and grind the same area box over and over until you get the right class level, and get the right items on this life to beat the boss then move on to the next stage. You can't shoot diagonally, while the enemies can. The power selection for each class is pretty limited. (edit added: However the variety of classes, all with different skillsets, is pretty good and have nice flavor. This is one of the highlights of the game.) Wait until a sale and the game with all DLC is a couple bucks. It's underwhelming but not "bad". Mediocre. (edit added: Fun for a few minutes every now and then. Something I might play in between other games when I'm burned out on my other arcade-style/rogue-like games. This review is based on playing single splayer only. I cannot speak about aspects of multiplayer.)Plus the devs and moderators on the forum are the type to delete posts and love controlling others.I guess they got tired of people questioning their decisions and just deleted all replies and locked the thread. If not for this poor behaviour I wouldn't have reviewed the game.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												If you want something to play that'll pass the time or crave a game with the classic RPG feeling to it, then Hero Siege is the perfect game for you. It's, in my opinion, a fantastic little gem of a game. Gameplay wise it feels as though the developer stuffed Diablo’s more reserved brother into a blender with The Binding of Issac, and added in a pinch of Killing Floor for good measure. In more sensible terms, it’s got a great number of rogue-like and RPG elements to it. There are a number of different levels, ranging from forests to snowy tundras, deserts and many more. At the end of each of these levels you can collect random pieces of loot, or relics as they’re called, which grant you varying stats and abilities. These relics come in four different flavours; weapon enhancing ones, which, as the name suggests, enhances your weapon giving it extra powers. For example an item called the Basilisk's Tooth makes it so that you have a 2% chance to turn enemies to stone. There are also passive relics as well, which improve your character’s skills. One example is the Cactus, which periodically spawns a cactus on the nearest enemy. The third relic type is active, which, after pressing the use key, will activate the effect of the relic. The Candy Crusher, one example of an active relic, launches candy in a ring around the player that explodes on landing. And the last relic type is orbiting, which float around the player and help during fights. One example is the Almighty Fedora which rapidly shoots projectiles.All these and many more can be obtained by progressing through the game, and surviving the large waves of enemies the game throws at you.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Talking about enemies, there are a large number of different types. Ranging from axe throwing skeletons to towering yeti-like beasts. Also there are several “elite” type enemies that have particular skills that happen once they die. For example creating a large laser that spins in a circle or an X shaped explosion, which both appear where the “elite” was slain.There are also a number of RPG elements in the game too. For one, there are unique skill trees for each class, providing varying passive and active abilities, depending on which class you choose out of the possible seven, or ten (depending on whether you own the DLC). They also all have their own sort of personalities and quotes as well.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Graphically the game looks a lot like your typical indie, rogue-like affair. But it fits nicely. The characters are easily distinguishable from each other and the varying levels all look pixel pretty with their individual themes and settings. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Overall the game feels enjoyable to play. The classes and their skills vary enough for the game to be replayed time and time again. Not to mention the seemingly endless number of experience levels you can rack up on a single class. The enemies vary in difficultly, depending on the level, and the boss battles, for the most part, feel fairly satisfying once they eventually kick the bucket.To Conclude, I’d say that Hero Siege is worth a play, whether it’s a rogue-like or an RPG you're after, or just a quick bit of fun. It’s a satisfying game to play and well worth a go. Good Day!

content:
Posted: March 19
 When Binding of Isaac meets Diablo TLDR; Hero Siege is incredibly fun alone or with a group of friends. I played non-stop and even though some relics are coming from The Binding of Isaac, Hero Siege is a great alternative to some of his most serious contenders.  Pros: + Replay value+ Price (less than 1$!)Cons: - Short-lived- Servers are really unstable- Class seems quite unbalanced General : 7/10Follow us here Steamship Discord: https://discord.gg/XbsKrtK  Steamship Steam group : http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thesteamship ----------------------------------------------I've only played for a day or two and I became an instant-fan. This rogue-like is also mixed with elements of Hack n' Slash. Very quickly, if you manage to get passed the bugged servers you will have to pick a class, some are free, some aren't.You end up in a map and have to kill monsters for 5 waves and then a mini-boss will follow. There are going to be traps, chests, small dungeons or events will happen during your adventure.With the same idea in mind than The Binding of Isaac, you will drop Relics that make you stronger and will lose them upon death.This is the main idea of the game, and you repeat for a few acts. The difficulty can be adjusted and will let you have a good challenge in hands.Overall, this is a very cheap, cool game that ends up being super addictive !General : 7/10Follow us here Steamship Discord: https://discord.gg/XbsKrtK  Steamship Steam group : http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thesteamship

number of helpful: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												I got this for rather cheap so luckly it paid for itself but at its regular price just be careful.In this game you fight waves after waves of monsters using a rather scant diablo like set up, and hillariously terrible voice acting which is a plus (though judging by the lumberjack with a chainsaw, that may be intentional). The monsters generally just walk into you and deal their damage, they don't attack you so to speak. After completing enough of a stage certain features will open up such as dungeons and level features, inside they are usually puzzles, boss fights, and trap guantlets.Each character has about 4 action skills (mostly attacks) and usually a few buffs that either enhance their attack or one of their skills. Some of the characters are pretty creative with their attack skills and some feel oddly basic. Don't expect long and complicated trees.But the shortcommings of this game make itself apperant. Some abilities do not have an obvious use but most of all what should be a serious test of skill. Difficult enemies almost always have a death attack that is difficult to avoid, in otherwords to make the game tougher they intentionally try to get a few cheap hits in. There is no real inventory to speak of... You can do the dungeons but they might just outright kill you with no hope for you to win. Collecting potions is the most deadly thing you can do as you will stand still for a second, enough time to be hit by a trap or boss.Add in that this game has a cash shop, and you will see where they will be trying to earn some cash off of you... and a lot in this game costs crystals and they constantly have it up in front. For example renaming your character costs crystal and respecing your character costs crystal. You can earn crystal in game but don't expect to earn anywhere close to enough. You start off with a generous amount, assuming my 750 was typical, so getting to the end of the game and then respecing might be a good idea. The fact that 50% of the options menu is cash shop (with bright flashing crystals showing to draw your eyes)... can get on your nerves.All in all this game is alright... but there are a lot of diablo-like games and even "Waves and waves of enemies you must kill" and even "trap guantlet" games that do this genre so much better that even for the price I got it for (a dollar) I can't recommend it.However, this feels like a game that I dislike but that others will enjoy. So please consult other reviews.

number of helpful: 23 of 44 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												Obviously, the game is not finished and very raw. Likewise, I certainly feel absolute disrespect of developers to their players.First and foremost, the game is full of bugs. At every step, at every option you can run into a bug and lost hours of playing, joy, and temper. A lot of crushes, disappearing of items, random generation collisions, menu bugs, ...The second thing is gameplay dis-balance. In fact, there are no any balance. It's a mess of features, monsters, skills, ... Some of skills are totally useless, some of character's features can easily kill any monster or boss. Items are random and it means that in some cases you won't have keys to open a door and no chance to get it. Likewise, you can occasionally get extremely powerful item in the beginning or completely loss some of skills (for example, speed in two times).The third one is the graphic. Some people name it pixel. But it is not a pixel. It's a collection of schoolboy scribbles. There are no any style, clutter of colours, discrepancy everywhere, total disproportion of everything, ... This mess really hurts my eyes.The fourth one is the music and the sound. I suppose it's personal, but I couldn't play with music and sound of the game. I turned it off. It's hard for me. I know a few people who like music like that, but it's not my cup of tea.From my perspective, the best description of the game is the trash. Total Trash. (it's not bad or good, maybe you like trash)I really tried to understand the game, but I failed. Sorry.

content:

Product received for free
												本体+鲤鱼王DLC原价党表示转投差评游戏频繁更新，更新到几乎没有原样，我并不是玩了半天突然嫌弃。时隔半年我再重新捡起它的时候让我觉得，不仅一心二用，还逐渐变得快餐，整个游戏简直就是不伦不类。+比旧版本相比已经丰富了很多元素，例如装备、地牢和洞穴的随机生成、装备、丰富地图布局等等，再也不是当初那种简单的手游移植。+练级时候先苦后甜的感觉+自带宝物图鉴+不会再纯粹留意怪物是否走到你的身边，怪物有各自的的攻击方式和附加效果-以我个人经验，60级之后整个游戏变得很无聊，除了刷就是刷，成就内容还是要你刷-你获得的宝物、药水大部分只是换个面孔给你增加各项属性。更何况有些宝物真的没什么用，道具复活跟手动重启没有两样，但是上次拿到的宝宝还存在，lol wtf？-更新了快两年bug依旧不断变化机关乱摆放，额外地图挑战失败code error，金币兑换蓝宝石的商人点开对话后无法切换继续毫无征兆的code error -连装备也是给你加各项属性，种类甚至多种多样到懒得画细节-DLC地图和本体地图相连，买多少DLC你就该打完多少才能解锁下一个模式-居然可以中途返回基地，我看已经没心思做rougelike了-这个就算了，你为了让别人买你的dlc，每个dlc画一个人物立绘，我很是佩服有些东西真的还不如旧版本，不过你花2块钱（92off）体验网游般刷怪练级的快感（升级速度简直堪比三流网游）还真是不错（笑）

content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												This game got boring fast. It is an autoattacking game where the items you pick up only affect the strength and speed of your autoattacks. There are no abilities, and the few active items that exist seem to just be different additional autoattacks. That being said, it gets boring fast. The reviews that are drawing comparisons to Binding of Isaac or Rogue Legacy are seriously unrating the game mechanics of those two games. This game is extremely shallow in terms of depth -- it doesn't come close to comparing. I can only guess this is why there are no let's plays of this game on YouTube or reviews anywhere; it is boring to play and EXTREMELY boring to watch.It would be an amusing $1 purchase on a phone or tablet (or free with ads), but I could never recommend this to anyone anywhere near the $10 asking price on the PC when there are much better games available.(Also the voice work is laughibly bad. Not enough to detract from the game but it is amusing to me how terrible it is.)

												Got sent this game by a friend, however I have subsiquently bought it an additional 3 times for other people, as it's currently only £0.47, and also because it's an amazingly fun game.Obviously Diablo 2 inspired, from the game play to the sojs and the shakos (which if you've played D2 I'm sure you'll understand). And like a lot of games inspired by D2, the gameplay is really fun. Reminicant not just of D2 but also Torchlight and a few others, this game has all the best bits of a few cool games and frankly is a steal for the current price (or any).There are some bugs where you'll join and be the wrong character or be unable to see a friends game ect, but most of the bugs are solved by going through any portal.There have been some issues with servers being down or crashing, but frankly, a little patience and a few minutes is really all it takes to get round these, I've been playing most of the day and other than crashing once or twice and having to wait a few minutes here and there for servers to come back up to be able to create a game, it's worked perfectly, dispite the occassional "server unresponsive" message that occassionally pops up in chat.All in all, I've no reason not to recomment this game, if you like the indie style and you enjoyed D2 I'm sure you'll really enjoy it, and if you haven't, you probably still will.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
EditIt's been a while since this review's been up and originally I'd given this a negative review. I had people commenting and messaging me telling me the game's been changed quite a bit and I should check it out. And I did. This is what I've discovered.The difficulty has evened out quite a bit. My main gripe wasn't so much the difficulty itself as much as it was it's erratic curve. I made a new guy, a necromancer, and decided to play as far as I could, noting how far I've gotten each time I died. First time I died was to the first boss which is understandable. I was playing a squishy character and I'll admit the death was my fault. Second time I died I'd just killed the first boss and didn't notice all the skeleton archers. Third time I died was at the second boss. Each time I died I learned from my mistake, got stronger and got farther every time. It's tough but it's my kinda tough. I like it. Good job fixing that up fellas. I also enjoy how easy it is to get right back into the game and breeze through the easy waves. You can skip a bunch of waves at one time and take on all the monsters at once to quickly get to the boss. This is perfect for a game this difficult.I still have a bit of a problem with the voice acting. I've said this before but if you can't get great voice acting then don't get voice acting at all. Sound effects or just simple grunts and yells would do just fine. I do however love the sound design. In a game where you're killing things ad nauseam it's really important to make it feel good when you defeat an enemy. They make good gorey sounds and explode in a huge mess. The music doesn't get repetative either but it sure as hell gets stuck in my head. So yeah. Great sound design, bad voice acting. All in all it's a good game. I was completely on the fence about it before but the changes they've made had me changing my mind. I promised I'd update my review and here it is. Don't wanna leave a bad review on a good game. Especially one that doesn't deserve it. I'll keep my old review here up for posterity. I find it really hard to recommend this game. I'm completely on the fence about it. I'm having fun playing it but there's just too many things wrong with it. It gets constantly updated and it seems every time there's a serious flaw someone writes it off as "I'm sure the devs will fix it eventually!". What people don't seem to realise is that this game isn't early access. This is a complete game. So any flaws in its design are absolutely relevant. My biggest gripe is with this game's difficulty. I'm all about hard games. I've clocked in hundreds of hours in Dark Souls 1 and 2 and have played my fair share of roguelikes. I'm a huge fan of the genre. But the difference is when you die its your fault. You get right back up and learn from your mistakes. This game, however, throws that out the window. It's difficult for the wrong reasons. I chose a marksman and granted I know they're a bit squishy but dear god half of what hits me just outright kills me. A lot of the creatures deal a pretty decent amount of damage and they drop health orbs when they die. That is until there's a boss or some kind of special monster. Every single boss I fight outright kills me in a single hit. Every. Single. Boss. Even the very first one. The difference in difficulty between the first and third boss I fought was nonexistant. They're completely random so hope to god you're fighting a melee boss because if he's ranged or has an AOE of any type at all then you may as well just jump off a cliff and save yourself the trouble. The problem with this is my marksman is level 20 and I'm still in the first act and STILL GETTING KILLED IN ONE HIT! Now I have played the melee classes a bit and they're not much less squishy. I find myself dying just as much. The first few levels of your character you may as well be throwing tissue paper at the enemies because you're not gonna do jack. Your best bet is to just lead the enemies to traps until your leveled up enough to get the one or two important skills that'll win you the game. Just don't get hit! By anything! Ever! Also every point you put into defense only raises damage reduction by .2%. So unless you invest a ridiculous amount of points into it, it's not going to help you at all. Skill points add a very negligible benefit to your character. The online multiplayer is absolute garbage at this point. Online multiplayer is in its alpha stage and you can definitely see it when you play. Joining games is a hit and miss. 90% of the time I join one the game just freezes for 2 minutes and just takes me back to the main lobby. That and sometimes the lobby says certain games have a negative amount of players in them (-1/4) or completely lie about the ping. All this I can understand. It's hard to just add in online multiplayer. It's a huge thing. The only reason I'm mentioning it is because you guys deserve to know its current state. My only real concerns about it are two-fold. Multiplayer is ESSENTIAL to beating this game and YOU HAVE TO BUY DLC JUST TO PLAY ONLINE! That's right. You have to purchase a $3 or $5 dlc just to play this game's god-awful online multiplayer. I'm thankful I bought this when it was on sale because I feel horrible for the people that actually paid full price for this mess. This sort of business strategy just infuriates me.I actually like this game's graphics and sound design. The music is fitting, the pixel-art is decent and stylized pretty well and the sound effects are great which is a lot more important than people might imagine. In a game where you're fighting huge waves of enemies it's imperative that you make it feel good to kill things. Enemies explode in a satisfying pile of gore and it sounds great! However.. this game has some of the worst voice acting I have ever heard. The writing is god-awful and it sounds like the same guy did the voices for everyone. This game does not need voice acting. There's no story. Dialogue is completely useless. Voice acting is one of those things that you either get right or just not have at all and I think this game would actually do far better if the characters just grunted or screamed rather than have full lines of dialogue.All in all, will you enjoy this game? Probably. It is a lot of fun. I've been craving a diablo-like multiplayer arena game for a long time and this one fulfills that desire. It's hard to find good things about it with all that's wrong with it though but something keeps bringing me back. Maybe you'll enjoy this type of game. If you can put up with the awkward difficulty then I'd say you'll probably like it too.

content:
Posted: March 14
												Hero Siege, where do i start.First off, i found this game a while ago and wasn't very interested in it because of the price, graphics and looked like a cheap knockoff of Diablo 3.A few days ago i saw it on sale for $0.99, so i went and bought the 4 pack for $1.99 and gave 2 copies to my gaming friends. We tried it, one of them lost interest in about a hour and half of gameplay, while me and another friend somehow got hooked to this game even with it's really bad start. What do i mean a really bad start? Well in the 2 hours of trying the game my friend and i came across 3 bugs that really made us wonder if we should sink time into this mess. The biggest bug being when we did a puzzle and when i hit the reset button my friend the was next to the wall and standing on where the stone piece resetted, he got pushed out of bounds and couldn't do anything but walk around and watch me for the rest of the dungeon. Another being sometimes missions sometimes have a tendency to spawn objective items (even mobs and loot that you cant reach) outside the map and you just have to sit there looking at it, although going to the next stage of the act will respawn the last piece for the mission.With that said, you'd think to yourself, this game seems so broken, why would i ever play this? Well, the answer my friend is the grinding and loot that you would normally get in diablo, just a bit more rampaging bloodshed than diablo.Here are my pros and cons:Pros:-Fun if your into one shotting everything from 1-150-Your friend can join you (my friend made a new character and i brought him through Inferno difficulty and got him to 70+ in levels)-LOOT-Neat and useful, sometimes funny relics (#StickmanSteveForMVP)-Classes are for the most part distinctive in playstyles-You can play with up to 3 other friends in a PRIVATE AND OFFICIAL SERVER (yes pls)-You can also host an open server for people to join (good luck getting people to)-You can name your character anything, and you can reset your skills, talents and even rename your character for an ingame currency called rubies.-There's a leaderboard for Wormholes (endgame stuff)-There's a chat section you can talk to people while you wait for your slow as hell friend to turn on what feels like his 1998 windows computer, get his dial-up running, and spend forever getting on skype and finally the damn game.-There are many difficulties to go through while you level up which includes, Normal, Nightmare, Hell, Inferno, Agony, Destruction, and Toxic. Right now my paladin is level 145 and im finally moving to Destruction to hopefully get to 150.-The devs seem to care at least a little bit about the players which is good enough for me.-And most importantly, they have the best relic, Stickman Steve. His quotes are amazing, and his voice is that perfect type of annoying that you'll love.Cons:-Many glitches, but can be fixed by going to the next section of an Act (The game is divided into Act 1-7  and Chapters 1-5 for each Act)-Your items not appearing when you get ingame (which ONLY happens if the server is down and you connect on peer-to-peer, since the items are saved server side, until the server is back up, you have no items)-Server crashes happen 3-4 times in the past few days, but the devs said ti was because alot of new players joined and it crashed the servers, so they are upgrading it over the next little while to hold more players-The damn animation for picking up potions that end up getting me killed once. At least there is a relic to insta-pickup items so it cancels the animation for picking up potions and relics.-Dying resets ALL the relics you collected (when your playing with 1 or more people this only occurs if both/all players die.-You only really need to put your skill points into health as items will increase your skills for you and Damage/Mana has an awful scaling per point you allocate to it, so it is only beneficial to allocate them into health.-There is only one active guild i see on US that has a decent playerbase, and that is 3G, although i've made my own guild with just my friend and i, and we're having fun playing as the underdogs.Overall, as bad as this game looks, i kinda have fallen for it. If your like me and dont mind the grind, even if it's 150 levels and like 6-7 playthroughs of the same maps and Act bosses, you should give this game a shot, especially if its on sale. And if you see me in chat (The Boss), feel free to join my guild or to start up a convo, cause we both know i'm just waiting for my 1998 windows, dial-up, slow as hell friend to finally get on.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Hero Siege is a good idea with really poor execution in so many areas that shows some fundamental lack of ability about what it takes to polish a game in 2015.It has probably the worst UI I have ever seen in a game in recent memory.- inconsistent behaviour, it pauses when stat upgrading but not when changing inventory? Some items auto-pick up but not others?- no tool tips or tutorial behavoiur of any sort, nor is there any tutorial for even basic things like how to pick up items. There isn't even a controls screen so you can see what controls are available. And there are WAY too many. I'm pretty sure a PC flight sim in 1994 had fewer buttons to remember.- lack of feedback on so many things. You can select any dialogue options you want and there is no confirmation that it does anything.- double-randomness involving requring a random chance to get keys and to get chests. So you end up finding a bunch of chests you can't open, with no way to go back to them once you have a key. Who ever thought that was a great idea?- keyboard controls are basically so busted the game is unplayable.- mouse operates only some things, but is otherwise inconsistent.- inventory select screen is about as bad as you can make one. Why even have 'inspect' as a seperate opion? So dumb, it makes you press buttons all over trying to figure out what your best inventory item is. On top of this, not pausing the game during this fullscreen dialogue means you can easily die if you ever try to change items in the game. Compared to diablo where you would just highlight to inspect and double-click something to equip it if it was better, this game you have to nagivate with the keyboard and F and G keys, then press R and G to inspect and leave the inspect screen.. for every item. It's just insane, how could they ever think this was ok when diablo 2, one of the clear inspirations for them, solved this so much better over 15 years ago.- Finally know that it's basically a free-to-play game they charge up front for, the base game should really be free with how much content is behind a paywall.On the plus side the art style is very appealing. It's just a shame it can't be enjoyed to it's full potential.In order to like this game you have to have a large tolerance for going on forums to learn how anything works.Looking at some youtube reviews of what it used to look like... wow they really did wreck their game. It used to be much more simplified and straighforward and actually tell you what buttons you need to press to do things. All abilities used to be passive so there were fewer buttons to press too.

												I know how to play games, I know how to host games, I know how to port forward.I could not under any circumstance, after:Reinstalling the game several times.Wiping it from the registry.Deleting the files in appdataForwarding 6510 on Windows Firewall / My router Turning Windows firewall on/offChecking on seven sites that 6510 was openReinstalling the game againRunning the game without any overlays or SteamMaking two panic.net accountsHard wiring into my modemReinstalling the firmware on my router entirelyPutting in an entirely different network cardAFTER THAT... I COULD NOT GET THIS GAME TO:Talk in online chatHost a P2P gameJoin a P2P gameHost a Dedicated Panic.net gameJoin a Dedicated Panic.net gameI bought a four pack on sale, the people who bought it - they play just fine. But for me under no circumstances could I play multiplayer.So if you want technical hell, you'll see all the posts of "I port forwarded and it doesn't work!" and realize, hell, maybe just hell, it isn't just the port forwarding.Avoid buying for multiplayer, chance of not working entirely.Four hours played in game, didn't play the game.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												While the concept of the game is great, it does get boring quick. I was able to get the game for a $1 through a game sale site. After playing the game, I would not be able to justify spending $10 for it and would convince others to avoid doing so as well. While there are multiple classes to choose from and a decent amount of content, the game is limited. Like others have said, there is no depth. Run around and shoot, pick up some gold (which is pointless in my opinion, the shop has only temporary items), and find relics which increase attack/speed or give additional passive attack types. I was excited to get into the game, but being able to go through the Normal difficulty in about two hours, the only other thing to do it go through the game at a higher difficulty. Not worth the trouble or time, but worth the play once or twice if you can get it cheaper.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												I’ll be as brief as possible.I hate this game and I regret spending money on this thing. Reasons being as followed.- It takes way too many points invested in stats before you see meaningful changes in anything but damage, and even then it fails to scale well compared to the nonsense starting the second region. Also your stats do NOT passively scale with level, making it worse!- The game is an utter crapshoot. You do well or poorly purely on chance.- You spend the majority of the game running from people and shooting as you go backwards. Running towards stuff is never a choice.The last one is a nit pick that I have with all twin stick shooters I’ve played and have yet to play one that encourages an aggressive approach of running towards the foes rather than away. Then again, I DETEST playing passively and I hate it even more when its the ONLY VALID WAY TO WIN! For those reasons I cannot recommend this game to anyone but the most hardcore or determined twin stick shooter gamers.As for me, I’m going to uninstall this and never look back. To fix all the issues would require a total overhaul of the game. And I doubt the development team is willing to put in the work. Otherwise this incompetently put together product wouldn’t exist in its current form.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Nice distraction if you want to play it on your phone or something, but this is a casual game lacking in depth. The "roguelike" tag is pretty much a joke. The random elements have very little impact on how you will play the game (hold the attack button constantly and kite enemies.)The production values are surprisingly good - it's a well-crafted game and doesn't feel cheap, so I've got to give them credit for that. The explosions/gold pickups are satisfying. Still, leveling up feels unimportant and there's no real strategy or metagame like Binding of Isaac etc. Pretty much NEEDS multiplayer to be fun, which they say they're working on. As it is, I got bored after about an hour. I might've enjoyed nightmare/hell difficulty more, but they don't let you select them right away like I wanted to, so I don't know. Normal is too easy for too long, which contributed to the boredom.I paid a dollar for Hero Siege on IndieGameStand, and I don't regret my purchase... But I would have if I paid the "official" asking price of $10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												I both like and don't like this game so its hard to pick between a simple yes or no.  Do i regret the $1 I spent, no.  Will I play it much, no.  I seen this and thought, hey.. its like realm of the mad god and it kind of is but mad god has a very clear view so you can easily see what your dodging and better worlds to explore.  This one has better character development choices and random items that are interesting.  The biggest problem I have with this one that makes me have a really hard time giving it the thumbs up is that theres so many trees and such that its hard to see everything you need to dodge.  Bullet hell games should have a very clear view so one doesn't feel robbed because they instantly died to something they could not see.My only other problem is that theres nothing worth while to spend my gold on.  The pirate class has skills specifically designed to help her get more gold but everything I can buy with it is a temp buff or consumable so the pirate has to give up a useful skill in her tree for one that doesn't actually do anything and her first active skil scales on it so one needs to level it anyway.  This isn't a very big deal to me but I still wish I could use the gold to actually increase her power to make up for her giving up power so she would snowball enough to overcome it.  If the dmg or atk speed potions were permanent but smaller buffs and simply got more expensive after buying them then I would like it better for all the classes.Overall, its a decent game at the sale price but for the full price of this game or less I can get paper sorcerer, evilquest, plants vs zombies, binding of issac, ghost master, dungeons of dreadmor or classics like sudeki, septerra core, etc.  Thats just to name a few and with the typical steam sales and free to play titles that are worth playing..  I just can't recommend this game but I've certainly spent a buck in worse ways.

content:

												I got on board with this game way back when it was on a Pay What You Want deal on indiegamestand.Back then, I promoted it as a fantastic 2d homage to Blizzard games, specifically the Diablo series, with some callbacks to the better raids in WoW as well.It was a simple game back then. The single player amounted to simply fighting waves and waves of enemies and occasionally being amazed if you got a Frostmourne. It was Diablo 2 meets 2d tower defense. It was a blast.Multiplayer added a host of problems. It's nearly impossible to navigate the server browser now. Bugs are common, whether in the game or at the menu. You can join a game and randomly get 1 shot and there go all your items- if you manage to join a game at all.I will update my review if the game significantly improves. It was a good game when it comes out, but as it stands now, I would not suggest someone buy it.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												First off, Hero Siege itself is a pretty decent game good for some mindless bloodsoaked action. I've had fun with it, I got to say that the bugs were tolerable and it's easy to pick up. Just don't expect too much depth, HS is not aiming to be more than mindless fun.BUT as somebody who bought this game to play with friends (which I expect a lot of people did), I sort of feel a little cheated by the publisher. Yes now they have multiplayer as it was announced. Yes now they have a lot of different classes. But paying actually more money for a dlc than I originally paid for the game which, frankly was not very long, to get more content and exclusive acces to a multiplayer alpha? Come on, that's just weak. Not to mention that after advertising the new character for a month, you realise that you have to pay for him as well.So in comparison, it might be worth the ten bucks if you do not own it already, give a loot of monster slashing fun, but as for I feel a little played with I do not recommend this game. For the price you could get Torchlight 2 or Binding of Isaac.

content:
Posted: March 14
												Hero Siege, where do i start.First off, i found this game a while ago and wasn't very interested in it because of the price, graphics and looked like a cheap knockoff of Diablo 3.A few days ago i saw it on sale for $0.99, so i went and bought the 4 pack for $1.99 and gave 2 copies to my gaming friends. We tried it, one of them lost interest in about a hour and half of gameplay, while me and another friend somehow got hooked to this game even with it's really bad start. What do i mean a really bad start? Well in the 2 hours of trying the game my friend and i came across 3 bugs that really made us wonder if we should sink time into this mess. The biggest bug being when we did a puzzle and when i hit the reset button my friend the was next to the wall and standing on where the stone piece resetted, he got pushed out of bounds and couldn't do anything but walk around and watch me for the rest of the dungeon. Another being sometimes missions sometimes have a tendency to spawn objective items (even mobs and loot that you cant reach) outside the map and you just have to sit there looking at it, although going to the next stage of the act will respawn the last piece for the mission.With that said, you'd think to yourself, this game seems so broken, why would i ever play this? Well, the answer my friend is the grinding and loot that you would normally get in diablo, just a bit more rampaging bloodshed than diablo.Here are my pros and cons:Pros:-Fun if your into one shotting everything from 1-150-Your friend can join you (my friend made a new character and i brought him through Inferno difficulty and got him to 70+ in levels)-LOOT-Neat and useful, sometimes funny relics (#StickmanSteveForMVP)-Classes are for the most part distinctive in playstyles-You can play with up to 3 other friends in a PRIVATE AND OFFICIAL SERVER (yes pls)-You can also host an open server for people to join (good luck getting people to)-You can name your character anything, and you can reset your skills, talents and even rename your character for an ingame currency called rubies.-There's a leaderboard for Wormholes (endgame stuff)-There's a chat section you can talk to people while you wait for your slow as hell friend to turn on what feels like his 1998 windows computer, get his dial-up running, and spend forever getting on skype and finally the damn game.-There are many difficulties to go through while you level up which includes, Normal, Nightmare, Hell, Inferno, Agony, Destruction, and Toxic. Right now my paladin is level 145 and im finally moving to Destruction to hopefully get to 150.-The devs seem to care at least a little bit about the players which is good enough for me.-And most importantly, they have the best relic, Stickman Steve. His quotes are amazing, and his voice is that perfect type of annoying that you'll love.Cons:-Many glitches, but can be fixed by going to the next section of an Act (The game is divided into Act 1-7  and Chapters 1-5 for each Act)-Your items not appearing when you get ingame (which ONLY happens if the server is down and you connect on peer-to-peer, since the items are saved server side, until the server is back up, you have no items)-Server crashes happen 3-4 times in the past few days, but the devs said ti was because alot of new players joined and it crashed the servers, so they are upgrading it over the next little while to hold more players-The damn animation for picking up potions that end up getting me killed once. At least there is a relic to insta-pickup items so it cancels the animation for picking up potions and relics.-Dying resets ALL the relics you collected (when your playing with 1 or more people this only occurs if both/all players die.-You only really need to put your skill points into health as items will increase your skills for you and Damage/Mana has an awful scaling per point you allocate to it, so it is only beneficial to allocate them into health.-There is only one active guild i see on US that has a decent playerbase, and that is 3G, although i've made my own guild with just my friend and i, and we're having fun playing as the underdogs.Overall, as bad as this game looks, i kinda have fallen for it. If your like me and dont mind the grind, even if it's 150 levels and like 6-7 playthroughs of the same maps and Act bosses, you should give this game a shot, especially if its on sale. And if you see me in chat (The Boss), feel free to join my guild or to start up a convo, cause we both know i'm just waiting for my 1998 windows, dial-up, slow as hell friend to finally get on.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
EditIt's been a while since this review's been up and originally I'd given this a negative review. I had people commenting and messaging me telling me the game's been changed quite a bit and I should check it out. And I did. This is what I've discovered.The difficulty has evened out quite a bit. My main gripe wasn't so much the difficulty itself as much as it was it's erratic curve. I made a new guy, a necromancer, and decided to play as far as I could, noting how far I've gotten each time I died. First time I died was to the first boss which is understandable. I was playing a squishy character and I'll admit the death was my fault. Second time I died I'd just killed the first boss and didn't notice all the skeleton archers. Third time I died was at the second boss. Each time I died I learned from my mistake, got stronger and got farther every time. It's tough but it's my kinda tough. I like it. Good job fixing that up fellas. I also enjoy how easy it is to get right back into the game and breeze through the easy waves. You can skip a bunch of waves at one time and take on all the monsters at once to quickly get to the boss. This is perfect for a game this difficult.I still have a bit of a problem with the voice acting. I've said this before but if you can't get great voice acting then don't get voice acting at all. Sound effects or just simple grunts and yells would do just fine. I do however love the sound design. In a game where you're killing things ad nauseam it's really important to make it feel good when you defeat an enemy. They make good gorey sounds and explode in a huge mess. The music doesn't get repetative either but it sure as hell gets stuck in my head. So yeah. Great sound design, bad voice acting. All in all it's a good game. I was completely on the fence about it before but the changes they've made had me changing my mind. I promised I'd update my review and here it is. Don't wanna leave a bad review on a good game. Especially one that doesn't deserve it. I'll keep my old review here up for posterity. I find it really hard to recommend this game. I'm completely on the fence about it. I'm having fun playing it but there's just too many things wrong with it. It gets constantly updated and it seems every time there's a serious flaw someone writes it off as "I'm sure the devs will fix it eventually!". What people don't seem to realise is that this game isn't early access. This is a complete game. So any flaws in its design are absolutely relevant. My biggest gripe is with this game's difficulty. I'm all about hard games. I've clocked in hundreds of hours in Dark Souls 1 and 2 and have played my fair share of roguelikes. I'm a huge fan of the genre. But the difference is when you die its your fault. You get right back up and learn from your mistakes. This game, however, throws that out the window. It's difficult for the wrong reasons. I chose a marksman and granted I know they're a bit squishy but dear god half of what hits me just outright kills me. A lot of the creatures deal a pretty decent amount of damage and they drop health orbs when they die. That is until there's a boss or some kind of special monster. Every single boss I fight outright kills me in a single hit. Every. Single. Boss. Even the very first one. The difference in difficulty between the first and third boss I fought was nonexistant. They're completely random so hope to god you're fighting a melee boss because if he's ranged or has an AOE of any type at all then you may as well just jump off a cliff and save yourself the trouble. The problem with this is my marksman is level 20 and I'm still in the first act and STILL GETTING KILLED IN ONE HIT! Now I have played the melee classes a bit and they're not much less squishy. I find myself dying just as much. The first few levels of your character you may as well be throwing tissue paper at the enemies because you're not gonna do jack. Your best bet is to just lead the enemies to traps until your leveled up enough to get the one or two important skills that'll win you the game. Just don't get hit! By anything! Ever! Also every point you put into defense only raises damage reduction by .2%. So unless you invest a ridiculous amount of points into it, it's not going to help you at all. Skill points add a very negligible benefit to your character. The online multiplayer is absolute garbage at this point. Online multiplayer is in its alpha stage and you can definitely see it when you play. Joining games is a hit and miss. 90% of the time I join one the game just freezes for 2 minutes and just takes me back to the main lobby. That and sometimes the lobby says certain games have a negative amount of players in them (-1/4) or completely lie about the ping. All this I can understand. It's hard to just add in online multiplayer. It's a huge thing. The only reason I'm mentioning it is because you guys deserve to know its current state. My only real concerns about it are two-fold. Multiplayer is ESSENTIAL to beating this game and YOU HAVE TO BUY DLC JUST TO PLAY ONLINE! That's right. You have to purchase a $3 or $5 dlc just to play this game's god-awful online multiplayer. I'm thankful I bought this when it was on sale because I feel horrible for the people that actually paid full price for this mess. This sort of business strategy just infuriates me.I actually like this game's graphics and sound design. The music is fitting, the pixel-art is decent and stylized pretty well and the sound effects are great which is a lot more important than people might imagine. In a game where you're fighting huge waves of enemies it's imperative that you make it feel good to kill things. Enemies explode in a satisfying pile of gore and it sounds great! However.. this game has some of the worst voice acting I have ever heard. The writing is god-awful and it sounds like the same guy did the voices for everyone. This game does not need voice acting. There's no story. Dialogue is completely useless. Voice acting is one of those things that you either get right or just not have at all and I think this game would actually do far better if the characters just grunted or screamed rather than have full lines of dialogue.All in all, will you enjoy this game? Probably. It is a lot of fun. I've been craving a diablo-like multiplayer arena game for a long time and this one fulfills that desire. It's hard to find good things about it with all that's wrong with it though but something keeps bringing me back. Maybe you'll enjoy this type of game. If you can put up with the awkward difficulty then I'd say you'll probably like it too.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												Utterly fun for a couple of runs, at least.  Not a strict roguelike: Unless you check the "Hardcore" option, your character will continue to level between runs, setting you off stronger each time you play.  Multiple characters, with very different ways to play, and several difficulty levels means tons of replayability.  Only criticism: The items make the run.  I picked up a single powerful item, and it carried me from Act 1 through 3 straight hours to the end of the expansion Act.  If you're looking for an instance-based game in the vein of Diablo or Torchlight, I can't think of anything better.
