content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												While the concept of the game is great, it does get boring quick. I was able to get the game for a $1 through a game sale site. After playing the game, I would not be able to justify spending $10 for it and would convince others to avoid doing so as well. While there are multiple classes to choose from and a decent amount of content, the game is limited. Like others have said, there is no depth. Run around and shoot, pick up some gold (which is pointless in my opinion, the shop has only temporary items), and find relics which increase attack/speed or give additional passive attack types. I was excited to get into the game, but being able to go through the Normal difficulty in about two hours, the only other thing to do it go through the game at a higher difficulty. Not worth the trouble or time, but worth the play once or twice if you can get it cheaper.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												I’ll be as brief as possible.I hate this game and I regret spending money on this thing. Reasons being as followed.- It takes way too many points invested in stats before you see meaningful changes in anything but damage, and even then it fails to scale well compared to the nonsense starting the second region. Also your stats do NOT passively scale with level, making it worse!- The game is an utter crapshoot. You do well or poorly purely on chance.- You spend the majority of the game running from people and shooting as you go backwards. Running towards stuff is never a choice.The last one is a nit pick that I have with all twin stick shooters I’ve played and have yet to play one that encourages an aggressive approach of running towards the foes rather than away. Then again, I DETEST playing passively and I hate it even more when its the ONLY VALID WAY TO WIN! For those reasons I cannot recommend this game to anyone but the most hardcore or determined twin stick shooter gamers.As for me, I’m going to uninstall this and never look back. To fix all the issues would require a total overhaul of the game. And I doubt the development team is willing to put in the work. Otherwise this incompetently put together product wouldn’t exist in its current form.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Nice distraction if you want to play it on your phone or something, but this is a casual game lacking in depth. The "roguelike" tag is pretty much a joke. The random elements have very little impact on how you will play the game (hold the attack button constantly and kite enemies.)The production values are surprisingly good - it's a well-crafted game and doesn't feel cheap, so I've got to give them credit for that. The explosions/gold pickups are satisfying. Still, leveling up feels unimportant and there's no real strategy or metagame like Binding of Isaac etc. Pretty much NEEDS multiplayer to be fun, which they say they're working on. As it is, I got bored after about an hour. I might've enjoyed nightmare/hell difficulty more, but they don't let you select them right away like I wanted to, so I don't know. Normal is too easy for too long, which contributed to the boredom.I paid a dollar for Hero Siege on IndieGameStand, and I don't regret my purchase... But I would have if I paid the "official" asking price of $10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												I both like and don't like this game so its hard to pick between a simple yes or no.  Do i regret the $1 I spent, no.  Will I play it much, no.  I seen this and thought, hey.. its like realm of the mad god and it kind of is but mad god has a very clear view so you can easily see what your dodging and better worlds to explore.  This one has better character development choices and random items that are interesting.  The biggest problem I have with this one that makes me have a really hard time giving it the thumbs up is that theres so many trees and such that its hard to see everything you need to dodge.  Bullet hell games should have a very clear view so one doesn't feel robbed because they instantly died to something they could not see.My only other problem is that theres nothing worth while to spend my gold on.  The pirate class has skills specifically designed to help her get more gold but everything I can buy with it is a temp buff or consumable so the pirate has to give up a useful skill in her tree for one that doesn't actually do anything and her first active skil scales on it so one needs to level it anyway.  This isn't a very big deal to me but I still wish I could use the gold to actually increase her power to make up for her giving up power so she would snowball enough to overcome it.  If the dmg or atk speed potions were permanent but smaller buffs and simply got more expensive after buying them then I would like it better for all the classes.Overall, its a decent game at the sale price but for the full price of this game or less I can get paper sorcerer, evilquest, plants vs zombies, binding of issac, ghost master, dungeons of dreadmor or classics like sudeki, septerra core, etc.  Thats just to name a few and with the typical steam sales and free to play titles that are worth playing..  I just can't recommend this game but I've certainly spent a buck in worse ways.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Hero Siege is a good idea with really poor execution in so many areas that shows some fundamental lack of ability about what it takes to polish a game in 2015.It has probably the worst UI I have ever seen in a game in recent memory.- inconsistent behaviour, it pauses when stat upgrading but not when changing inventory? Some items auto-pick up but not others?- no tool tips or tutorial behavoiur of any sort, nor is there any tutorial for even basic things like how to pick up items. There isn't even a controls screen so you can see what controls are available. And there are WAY too many. I'm pretty sure a PC flight sim in 1994 had fewer buttons to remember.- lack of feedback on so many things. You can select any dialogue options you want and there is no confirmation that it does anything.- double-randomness involving requring a random chance to get keys and to get chests. So you end up finding a bunch of chests you can't open, with no way to go back to them once you have a key. Who ever thought that was a great idea?- keyboard controls are basically so busted the game is unplayable.- mouse operates only some things, but is otherwise inconsistent.- inventory select screen is about as bad as you can make one. Why even have 'inspect' as a seperate opion? So dumb, it makes you press buttons all over trying to figure out what your best inventory item is. On top of this, not pausing the game during this fullscreen dialogue means you can easily die if you ever try to change items in the game. Compared to diablo where you would just highlight to inspect and double-click something to equip it if it was better, this game you have to nagivate with the keyboard and F and G keys, then press R and G to inspect and leave the inspect screen.. for every item. It's just insane, how could they ever think this was ok when diablo 2, one of the clear inspirations for them, solved this so much better over 15 years ago.- Finally know that it's basically a free-to-play game they charge up front for, the base game should really be free with how much content is behind a paywall.On the plus side the art style is very appealing. It's just a shame it can't be enjoyed to it's full potential.In order to like this game you have to have a large tolerance for going on forums to learn how anything works.Looking at some youtube reviews of what it used to look like... wow they really did wreck their game. It used to be much more simplified and straighforward and actually tell you what buttons you need to press to do things. All abilities used to be passive so there were fewer buttons to press too.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												Having given up on the daily review writing game,  I have come to realize that this means I can actually take time to play and enjoy games that I really wouldn't have been able to sit down and enjoy had I continued.  It's actually surprising now how I can open up one or two of these new games and find myself enjoying playing them far more than I would have if I had a too-short deadline in front of me.  I guess this means that when I write new reviews, they will probably be much more authentic.Hero Siege is no exception to this statement.  I opened this up a week or so ago, thinking I would find a fairly simplistic top down bullet hell-ish bore, and i found myself actually surprised.  Surprised enough to not realize five hours had passed and I had finished my first playthrough of the base game, and with enough relics to make me effectively unstoppable, and I still didnt really want to put it down.  This, to me, is the definition of a truly good game, one that keep s your interest over time, even as you get to the end of it.Now I will say, that officially I have 'completed' the base game in that five hours, but that doesnt mean I stopped playing.  The game is basically an odd combination of bullet hell, tower defense, and binding of isaac roguelike, and for all its entertainment is actually fairly short.  What you get by playing a character however is the ability to play the same levels over on harder difficulty levels, though with your massively overpowered character dealing hot death to scores of mindlessly wandering foes.  The characters are simple enough to control, use your base attack most of the time then deal massive death with special moves when the cluster of baddies gets to dense for your base attack to be worthwhile.  As you progress, your experience grows your levels and base stats, and you also get random powerups which add unique powers in a binding of isaac like fashion, which you lose if you die, meaning you have  an increasing sense of protectiveness of your character the more difficult the game becomes.  The intent behind this I have to assume is that it keeps you on par with the difficulty level, which unfortunately it didnt seem to have done.  I was basically unstoppable until half way through my playthrough on the third difficulty level, whereupon I happened to hit a brick wall in a particular boss that apparently doesnt seem to understand that exponential difficulty increases only work if you go up one exponent at a time.  Afterwards, I lost all my relic powerups and quicly realized that my character though quick at reaping destruction before, was apparently not as powerful as i had been led to believe.  Curse you Hero Siege for such slanderous lies.All that being said, do I recommend this game?  Basically the answer there would be yes, though I will say that it doesn't have a lot of things that make it unique among the roguelike genre, and if you are already knee deep in things like isaac or Enter the Gungeon, it may be best to give a pass on this one, at least until you get sick of those and want to try something slightly different but still the same.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Been Playing the Hell out of this one since I bought it during the Winter Sale of 2014, its Basically a combination of a Horde mode and Binding of Isaac since the Items you can get are pretty much the same (even the names) Takes you through 5 Whole Chapters with 5 stages in each. so 25 levels in total, complete with optional Dungeons, Crypts, and Shops to go to between Enemy Waves which you must survive around 6 to 8 waves per stage. with the final wave of each stage being a mini boss. Now the game does have a lot of replayability. lots of characters to go through and can grind your way all the way up to level 200 I'm sure. but it does get pretty damn stale at times. since you basically just kill wave after wave after wave of enemies for hours on ends. until you reach the end of a Chapter to fight a Real Boss and proceed until you complete the game. Now this took me a while to figure out, but if you want to succeed in this game in one go. Grab everything in sight, break every possible thing in the level. That means use all types of Potions so you know which ones to use throughout your run, break leaves and pots for cash, and go through Dungeons and Crypts for free items or gold at the end of each one. Without doing so the game will be a Hugh Pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ enemies will start to be very difficult to kill and you will most likely die in one or two hits if you are not careful. and the game is FILLED with bugs and glitches. some that can help you, and some that can♥♥♥♥♥♥you off.Overall the game is Pretty damn fun if you want to spend a lot of time playing a game for a good grind. but its really hard at first, and The Melee Characters are almost useless. but once you get a crap load of items the game is pretty simple at that point, even on harder difficultys. So Yeah Give it a shot if it interests you

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Has so much potential but it falls short. The game just gets so repetitive and boring after a while. To get to the point i just think more content will help such as: More Content in The Town of Inoya. The reason i say this is because it is just so "boring". It has nothing to even offer to the player considering the player is constantly forced to go there when out of combat. It has absolutely nothing to offer besides the somewhat non variety of shops and just useless NPC's. If anything to make the game better i think a more compact resting area with some cool stuff to look at with more content would be nice. Another thing that really bothers me is the currency in the game. First i will start with gold. Gold is essential to the player but i feel like use for gold has not much variety. Yeah you could buy relics and buffs with gold and wormhole keys yeah. But i just feel that there could be more use just like The Town of Inoya. Another currency is those blue crystals and i have to admit that the blue crystals are so useless after you have purchased what you wanted and will maintain for the rest of the game. Yeah you can use the blue crystals to go to Sheeponia but even that only gives like one equipment you cant even use since youre underleveled.Sometimes attributes and skills for characters can be such a confusion too. One example is the Berserk skill for Viking in which the description says that it has a chance to ignite enemies around you but it doesnt say what is the percent. Plus investing in hp late game is also just a waste of time since it only gives like 100 hp per click but that becomes useless too.Also another one big one is those golden health bar bosses. They are just so broken that it is stupid. They can one shot you and you wont be able to do anything back which is just stupidly broken for the game. When you die you have to re accumulate relics but that is just so damn boring since youre most likely grinding lower level acts. However i am certain that developers would spend some time to fix these issues. But there are also some really good stuff about the game such as combat. Really fun to just smash everything in your way and im pretty sure everyone likes doing that. But it can be unnecessarily overly difficult which takes away from the fun sometimes. Even though i put a bunch of complaints about the game i do recommend it for the extremely cheap price to content ratio if you want to be technical for that. But disregarding price probably not the best game to pick up as of now.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												   Hero Siege is a game that stands somewhere between a roguelike (most notably, The Binding of Isaac) and a dungeon-crawler (like Zelda, or Diablo).It certainly takes many aspects of those games, but turns them into something of its own.    I've only finished the game twice on normal mode, with a melee and a ranged class. I did try 2 others classes, but didn't beat the game with those, just wanted to try them out.   It's a weird game to review, actually. I don't consider it a good game. At all. However, if you manage to overcome all of its faults, it becomes a very fun game where you feel like a God and everything explodes around you. It's not well designed, but it surely is a lot of fun, at times!   There's quite a bit to mention about the game, so I'll try to write a brief overview of the game's systems, and then give an extended opinion about certain design concepts. Graphically, it has a 16bit style, very similar to how JRPGs look, only on a bigger scale. I liked it. Take into account though, that there is A LOT of things on the screen all at once, between enemies, destructable terrain, or permanent objects like trees. These often obstruct your vision of traps and enemy bullets, which makes it a bit too hard to dodge, early in the game. As I said, late in the game, you're God, so you will not worry about such petty matters.   I didn't pay much attention to the Music. Not that it was bad, but I play these games while zoning out with my own music, or podcasts. From what I've heard, it wasn't bad, but didn't really add to the experience.   The SoundEffects were actually pretty satisfying. Perhaps not on their own, but controller vibration was very well used to make you feel like you're actually exploding everything around you. The combination of these 2 was very good!   However! There's a problem inherent to this: when you're very aware that you're doing damage, you're not aware that you're taking it... The game doesn't give you much feedback when you're close to dying, and early on, it can mean your death. And prepare to die a lot, as the game is very unbalanced. More on that later.   Now, I'll try to just explain what the game actually is, mechanically.   You go from map to map, fighting waves of enemies. At the end of each map (6 waves), there's a random Boss fight, with a random item reward. Every 3 (or 5) Bosses, there will be a fixed Boss, marking the end of an Act. There are 4 Acts in the main game, with an additional 5th on the DLC (which I don't own).    While it is very similar to TBoI, it's much longer, and less structured. On each map, here's what you aim for:   - ActiveItems - you have 1 slot. You press a button to use it. It can go from healing you, droping a bomb, a barrage of missiles, giving you a potion, etc.   - PassiveItems - these are far more important. They often give you very powerful attributes, or perhaps a passive ability (like a chance of doing a long range attack along with you basic attacks, etc), or defensive/offensive orbital companions. This is where the meat of your progression is, aside from upgrading your skills.   - Chests - there are 3 chests. Some are common, and require no key. They contain keys, potions, or coins inside. There are Golden chests, that require a normal key (with a generally higher pay rate), and also Crystal Chests, that require a crystal key (and generally reward you with an item).   - Crypts - these are mini-dungeons, without a boss. Sometimes, they'll appear on the map. You'll usually find lots of traps and/or a puzzle inside. If you overcome it, you'll get a free item.   - Dungeons - these are similar to crypts, but they have a bigger focus on combat. More enemies, and also a Boss fight. It will also reward your with an item.   - Shops - these will have one item, one potion, and 4 stat upgrades, for different prices. It's hard to make use of them early on, but they're useful when you get enough money.   - Potions - these function like pills in TBoI. Their effect is unknown to you, until you try it. After that, you can use its color to recognize its effect (which is different in every run). These can grant you upgrades and downgrades, but they're essential to your success, since there will be a lot of them. It's your biggest source of attribute upgrades, aside from items, despite carrying a risk.   - Destructable objects can include crates, pots, or just vegetation. All of these drop something of potential use.   While there seem to be many options, the game has a very hard difficulty wall. Once you pass it, however, you'll snowball out of control, and reach the end of the game so overpowered that you don't need to dodge anything and you won't lose more than 5% of your HP, even walking over every trap and enemy.    The other important aspect of this game is your character.   There are a bunch of different classes (maybe 9? didn't count), some melee, some ranged. You gain XP by killing enemies, and are able to spend 2 attribute points, and 1 skill point. The attributes are the same for all classes (Damage, Attack Speed, Damage Reduction, and Health). The skills vary from class to class, but there are a few common features.   Every character you create has permanent progression (leveling is permanent). However, as I said, items and potions are the most important part of progression, and those are contained in the run itself. Each character is also level up individually.   The combat is more old-school than I was expecting, which I'm not sure it fits into what it's going for in terms of structure. But more on that later.    Most of it is passive abilities. Each character has 4 active skills, but they have a cooldown associated with, and while useful, they don't make as much of an impact as the passive ones. A lot of your skill tree is having a %chance of doing *action* when you attack. I actually liked that aspect of the game, but it also makes gameplay closer between classes.   With all of this, I can see people milking this game for hundreds of hours, between classes and different difficulties. However, it doesn't seem to be as replayable as, say, TBoI, due to its length. Each run may take 3 hours, and is long enough for you to get most of the items.    The game has many flaws (which I failed to mention), but it can be a fun game, if you overcome its difficulty. It's not expensive, so sure, give it a try!---I keep screwing it up. I need to summarize these reviews more to have space to actual discuss design decision. Anyway, here's what I think is wrong with the game.   The most important aspect here, is balance, which this game lacks a lot! There are inumerous different enemies, and these have modifiers as well, so there's quite a bit to consider when you're early in the game. Some of them are fine, while others explode on death, or do damage around them when they're hit... This isn't good at all with melee characters, for example. Early on, you'll die over and over and over again, because of this aspect. Another, is traps that are often obstructed by terrain, or even enemy projectiles. This, coupled with the lack of feedback, makes your life really freakin' hard.   It reminded my of NES Castlevanias, almost. Everything needed to be methodical. Which I love! However, those games were much shorter. In a roguelike of this length, I don't think it works as well.   Well, more in the comments. Sorry about this! I'll try to revise my writing in future reviews.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Has so much potential but it falls short. The game just gets so repetitive and boring after a while. To get to the point i just think more content will help such as: More Content in The Town of Inoya. The reason i say this is because it is just so "boring". It has nothing to even offer to the player considering the player is constantly forced to go there when out of combat. It has absolutely nothing to offer besides the somewhat non variety of shops and just useless NPC's. If anything to make the game better i think a more compact resting area with some cool stuff to look at with more content would be nice. Another thing that really bothers me is the currency in the game. First i will start with gold. Gold is essential to the player but i feel like use for gold has not much variety. Yeah you could buy relics and buffs with gold and wormhole keys yeah. But i just feel that there could be more use just like The Town of Inoya. Another currency is those blue crystals and i have to admit that the blue crystals are so useless after you have purchased what you wanted and will maintain for the rest of the game. Yeah you can use the blue crystals to go to Sheeponia but even that only gives like one equipment you cant even use since youre underleveled.Sometimes attributes and skills for characters can be such a confusion too. One example is the Berserk skill for Viking in which the description says that it has a chance to ignite enemies around you but it doesnt say what is the percent. Plus investing in hp late game is also just a waste of time since it only gives like 100 hp per click but that becomes useless too.Also another one big one is those golden health bar bosses. They are just so broken that it is stupid. They can one shot you and you wont be able to do anything back which is just stupidly broken for the game. When you die you have to re accumulate relics but that is just so damn boring since youre most likely grinding lower level acts. However i am certain that developers would spend some time to fix these issues. But there are also some really good stuff about the game such as combat. Really fun to just smash everything in your way and im pretty sure everyone likes doing that. But it can be unnecessarily overly difficult which takes away from the fun sometimes. Even though i put a bunch of complaints about the game i do recommend it for the extremely cheap price to content ratio if you want to be technical for that. But disregarding price probably not the best game to pick up as of now.

												I've been playing this game for so long, it's hard to pin down exactly where the game is at. It's changed massively in the year and a half since I got Hero Siege (the first DLC came out the day I got it), and in many ways for better and for worse. Before they added Mana, the game was pretty solid; the mana update has been rough, but it's clearly getting better. The devs are pretty dedicated to this game, and they want to improve it as much as possible. It's fun, but it does take a good amount of persistence to get the hang of the game. It's very hard, but I definitely recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												I've played two characters so far: Viking and Pyromancer. I've played with an Xbox gamepad.Pros:+ Nice graphics+ Nice sounds+ Large selection of charactersCons:- The in-game options screen is incomplete. You can't change certain options in-game, you need to go back to the main menu.- Scenario gets in the way (visually). Sometimes you can't see stuff because it is behind a house, or a tree. Okay, trees get transparent when you move behind them, but houses don't. Still, it requires moving behind it. It is annoying.- Scenario gets in the way (movement). Sometimes when I'm running walking away from enemies, I get stuck and end up dying. Then I noticed that there was a pillar or tree that I couldn't see because it was transparent.- Pyromancer attack is ranged. However, even though it can move in any direction (analog stick), it can ONLY shoot in 4 straight directions (even with the analog stick!).- Pyromancer attacks miss enemies even though visually I believe they should have hit.- First boss while playing Pyromancer: a skeleton that is immune to ranged attacks.- While playing a melee character inside a dungeon, both one enemy and the boss were knocked back to behind the dungeon walls. They stayed there, at the "void", outside the dungeon, a location that was supposed to be solid and that no enemy or item should be at.- Pressing B to quit the inventory screen also counts as "advance to the next wave".- Pressing D-pad down to move in the inventory screen also counts as "open teleport spell".- Grinding. Grinding. Lots of grinding.- Each character requires grinding separately.- Walking speed is relatively slow. But I know you can grind for items to improve it.- Feels a bit confusing without a tutorial. What's the objective? What do I keep when I die?- The inventory screen is confusing. It took me a while to figure out that each empty square is an equippable slot.- Two currencies? In-game gold and in-game crystals? What's that? Is this a freemium game? I bought this game! This is confusing, even more so without a tutorial.- All those NPCs in the main area seem confusing. I don't know what they do. And I don't want to waste time walking from one to another (why is walking so slow? why are they so far apart?).It looks a very polished game.But if feels very unpolished.After some grinding to increase the attack strength a lot, playing feels a bit fun. But still confusing and pointless. Without increasing the attack, it feels very boring and repetitive.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												If you're reading this, you already know the basic gameplay: it's a shmup with RPG elements. One thing that you can't tell from the videos and screen shots is how confusing it can be when you start. You're thrust into the game world with very little explanation, and you have to figure stuff out as you fight and die and die and die. Some people will find this fun (including me, which surprised me) and some people will find this frustrating and quit. It's up to you to guess which category you'll fall into.I haven't experienced any bugs, but I have run into some.. unusual balance decisions. Enemy melee attacks seem to be much weaker than their projectiles, which in turn are much weaker than the projectiles spawned when they die, so you have to be more afraid of enemies when they die than when they chase you. Like I said, kind of odd, but once you notice that pattern and get used to it, it's no less fun.Skills don't look very balanced to me, either, but respeccing is cheap so that's not necessarily a big deal.Graphics and sound are pretty subjective, and you can check them for yourself in the above video, but FWIW I really like them. The one exception is the voice acting, which I didn't think was the 'so bad it's good' type. I thought it was the 'so bad it's really terrible' type.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												Bought this a while ago, I think when it was on sale. Finally got around to playing it over a year later. What I found was a bunch of locked content barred behind DLC doors, a painfully difficult start (my first few runs died in the first minute of gameplay until I was finally able to find some equipment), no ingame explanation of how to even play, and a glaring UI bug -- the numerical portion of your health gauge doesn't change no matter how much damage you take. (The actual bar works, and the mana gauge works fine, but not the numerical part of the health gauge -- it always reads full) Seriously, that kind of a glitch indicates nobody's ever even bothered to playtest this thing. Then there's also rat nests spawning outside the reachable gameplay area. And then there's the fact if you get unlucky with a statue early on, you can take a -40 penalty to Strength, which can make it go negative -- and moreover, make your damage output become negative. That's right, your main attack heals enemies while you're below 0 Strength.It's also rather chilling to see the first five reviews on this page being all negative, and three out of five of them blaming the developers for being vindictive, deleting criticisms from the forum, and even banning said critics from both the forums AND the game's multiplayer -- all for the supposed purpose of maintaining their 'motivation'. This is very bad PR, and bad PR leaves permanent black marks on a developer's reputation. Far worse than losing motivation for working on a single game, as that reputation can carry over to future created games.Also... is it just me or are there a lot of ripped ideas from The Binding of Isaac in this game? I'm seeing too many similarities for it to be mere coincidence or marked up to 'inspiration'.It's kinda fun although parts of it are on the tedious side, but I'll play it because I've already paid for it. But for most players I would advise against buying it, as I personally do not want to see negligent debugging, DLC onslaughts, and developers banning criticisms supported further.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												This review is based on online co-op (I have not bothered with single player).  The game itself is fun (especially with friends), but the game has been out for 2 years yet there is a ridiculous amount of crashes, some infuriating bugs, and many server issues.  It's uncommon be able to finish the 30 waves per Act in one go without one of my party mermbers or myself crashing (and since there is no hot-join, you will have to exit and remake the game and restart the Act).  The bugs I mentioned before are Relic pickup glitches and even sometimes items/relics lost upon reloading (rare but has occured with 2 friends of mine) which is enough to make any gamer rage. The most frustratng was figuring out how to connect with friends online.  The dedicated servers and even peer-to-peer are inconsistent for visibility of friends games in the lobby.TL;DR The game itself is probably worth it for the $6 price tag, but DO NOT expect a smooth online experience until (if ever) the bugs/crashes have been fixed.  If you do choose to gamble on this game, the only reliable solution (from my experience) to connecting with friends is for the host to forward port 5610 and having your friends "Connect to IP"

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
First of all, you get to choose and upgrade your characters, equip them with hats, and when you die you keep your levels gained and thus your ability/stat upgrades as well. The characters themselves are all fairly diverse, with active abilities and different ways to upgrade your regular attacks. As the game is completely reliant on RNG you will definitely have a few "wtf" moments where you just die. In a lot of cases getting hit once or twice is insta-death. The tombs and crypts are usually so hard that I just ignore them. Some of the bosses are stupidly easy and some are nearly impossible with certain classes.The creativity factor is there. The enemies are fairly generic but the designs and sprites are not bad. The voice acting is unimpressive. Personally I have beat the first area boss (which is a random boss each time of course) several times but upon reaching the second area I just get overwhelmed and shortly die, every time.The game is fairly fun. I play it from time to time and I got it on sale for cheap. A week or two after I got this game they released the DLC which basically says "Buy our DLC for $6 or you won't get any updates" and it's a slap in the face. Another reviewer said that he noticed some of the artifacts are stolen straight from Binding of Isaac. I would say that this game is definitely worth buying if it's on sale, and i'd say to wait until the DLC goes on sale if you plan on buying it. If you want to support a real action roguelike, go check out Nuclear Throne.

												Hero Siege, simply put, is an extraordinarily affordable yet underwhelming title.Its gameplay intentionally carries heavy Diablo, and consequently Torchlight, vibes which is very pleasant for those seeking a bit of nostalgia but beyond that Hero Siege is severely lacking. All fond memories to me in different ways.  What i didnt like about this game is the way the developer is a inconsistant ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who changes WHOLE classes, UI and stats to be♥♥♥♥♥backwards...lets it sink in a few months and then CHANGES IT AGAIN. Heres a few examples of flawless game design: 1.) In the previous build of the game there was NO unit collision ( I can walk through any enemy ) to ALL units have collision. 2.) I go to pick up and look at a piece of gear side by side and either press F or G to equip or destroy, like in the old build, and it just picks up the armor?? how the ♥♥♥♥ do i equip it now? how do i throw it away? wheres the update that tells me that this game has been turned on its god DAMN head?** Edit ** The developer added in different keys that show you how to either equip or destroy things in your inventory so the world isnt completely over and you can call off the strike.  Its still kind of hard to get used to sweeping changes but thats basically all that happens during this games patches.  Ill edit in if anything else happens.3.) Now that you can see how to equip or drop items you have the very real chance to drop an item and while still in the menu pick up the item that you just dropped....but not just one a whole STACK if depending on how much you threw away....and so when you are fiddling around in the menu an enemy comes along and kills you because you have no ability to stop time or see past your characters inventory screen....awesome.If the dev was looking to model himself after Blizzard North (The dev team for Diablo 2) the thing i wouldnt try to emulate would be buffing the ♥♥♥♥ out of one class or ability and nerfing another to be almost unplayable and not even addressing the issues.This game definitely has some flaws that need to be worked out but if you have the patience of a saint and just love to wait for ridiculous and glaring issues to be worked out then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
												Let's be clear out of the gate, Hero Seige isn't a perfect game by any token. Many have complained about patches and this and that and how its ruined this and that and blah. I bought the game over the summer, and played it for a short spell. There were other games I was more into at the time, but caught a sale. I knew I'd return to it eventually. I did after the supposed patch and its whatever to me. The game can be a bit static, operating in small areas over a long period of time. Orcs Must Die comes to mind, aside from the trap-laying mechanic. Instead you've got just your wits and weaponry. The Isaac references are clear, the Diablo spirit echoes softly, and so long as you eyeball your stats wisely (and avoid the acid at all costs) random deaths aren't really an issue. Its usually pretty clear. Like I said, its not perfect. It can get a bit dull after a while since it IS so static. But with an hour to kill every here and there, its hard not to come back to the game, even if just with the desire to conquer one act with a new character or on a new difficulty. Make your own consideration when it comes to a buy, but if you catch it on sale, you're not losing nearly as much as people are claiming you are.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												Art didn't grab me, much like the gameplay. I played as Necromancer with a friend and found my low-level skeleton summon spell to easily handle just about anything on its own with no intervention, balanced only by the fact that my health would vanish in the blink of an eye to something I didn't even know existed until it killed me. This resulted in the ideal tactic being 'raise skeletons, run, don't fight and wait until you win'. Even when I did participate in combat, the enemy AI and my attacks alike were both dull and I very quickly grew tired of playing.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												This game is a lot of fun with a little bit of not. Class-based with roguelike elements, it has a few surprises up its sleeve to keep it interesting and enjoyable. Just when I think I'm pushing water uphill, I manage to pull myself out of a tight spot. Just when I feel like I'm cruising along too easily, I get my face pounded in with something spiky and mean. I've clocked almost 10 hours in three days, and I'm showing no signs of stopping anytime soon.I have a few problems with the game, however.While the blood of a roguelike is pumping fast through the heart of this game, it isn't passing through the brain as much as I'd like. Collecting a relic grants an effect, but very rarely does the description of the relic lend to an explanation of what that effect is. A mouse-over text would do wonders for telling the player what they've just gotten themselves into.Also...there's no nice way to say it. The voice acting is a crime against nature. Thus far I've played five of the available eight classes: Viking, Marksman, Redneck, Pirate and Samurai. Only one of these five (the Viking) hasn't made me wish I knew more about modding, and that didn't seem as though it lacked the attempt.How is it that the Marksman is more redneck than the Redneck? The Pirate is so obsessed with treasure (and climbing, for some reason) that it actually makes other pirates look charitable - seriously, we get it, you like gold and want it in your pockets. As for the Samurai...If you can imagine Antonio Banderas doing an impersonation of Christopher Lambert's Raiden from Mortal Kombat who is himself doing an impression of Mickey Rooney's character from Breakfast At Tiffany's, you've about got it. Seriously, Kyle Kinane's bit about Trader Joe's Asian counterpart Trader Ming was less racially insensitive, and it was mimicking a man who was doing a terrible Oriental accent. "Trader Ming demand respect from forrorers!" It's that bad.Oh, you don't want to buy the DLC and find out? That's okay, just whisper the following phrase in a very pensive, meaningful way: "Your rack of barance was your reakness." That's an actual line from the game, in all the glory it lacks. You get me? You get me.I highly recommend this game to anyone who has a strong love for games similar to The Binding of Isaac (same control scheme, even) but who have long patience for dying unnecessary while cringing at terrible, just terrible voice acting.Oh, and Akrea, the Lightning boss, talks like a six year old with a speech imediment. "Awe you scawed?" L2speak, then we'll talk....seriously with this voice acting...

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
First of all, you get to choose and upgrade your characters, equip them with hats, and when you die you keep your levels gained and thus your ability/stat upgrades as well. The characters themselves are all fairly diverse, with active abilities and different ways to upgrade your regular attacks. As the game is completely reliant on RNG you will definitely have a few "wtf" moments where you just die. In a lot of cases getting hit once or twice is insta-death. The tombs and crypts are usually so hard that I just ignore them. Some of the bosses are stupidly easy and some are nearly impossible with certain classes.The creativity factor is there. The enemies are fairly generic but the designs and sprites are not bad. The voice acting is unimpressive. Personally I have beat the first area boss (which is a random boss each time of course) several times but upon reaching the second area I just get overwhelmed and shortly die, every time.The game is fairly fun. I play it from time to time and I got it on sale for cheap. A week or two after I got this game they released the DLC which basically says "Buy our DLC for $6 or you won't get any updates" and it's a slap in the face. Another reviewer said that he noticed some of the artifacts are stolen straight from Binding of Isaac. I would say that this game is definitely worth buying if it's on sale, and i'd say to wait until the DLC goes on sale if you plan on buying it. If you want to support a real action roguelike, go check out Nuclear Throne.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												There is something here... Its like I'm 8 years old again and there's a big pile of leafs. God damn that'd be fun to jump in. But when you jump in its full of nails and broken glass and like... dirty siringes used by drug addicts who probably have hep B. Sure if they put this fun retro pile of leafs through the leaf filter and took all that crap out it'd be a lot of fun... EXAMPLE. I was in a skype call with a friend who I was playing with.  I thought to myself I'm going to turn down the Music volume to hear better. I click the option and go to move it down to zero. Instead what it does turn itself all the way up and the ball that you click goes off of the option menu waaaay over to the right. Turns out... this is the loudest volume. OH then you try to turn it down but for some reason you can never get it back down to even the original volume *which is plenty loud* so its stuck at blaring.NO PROBLEM! There's a master Volume Off button! *click* .... *click* *click* *click* Oh right.... doesn't work either.Literally have to leave the game change the setting then  you can start again.... joy. In conclusion... Fix Yo $#% This feels more like an alpha... Not a beta... Game companies are trying to get away with more and more now a days. You don't need a player base to regonize some of these OBVIOUS problems.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												EDIT: At first, I did recommend the game however after hearing news about how the creators/mods/etc have treated their customers along with further progression showing me only terrible glitches that they, themselves, have denied existed or need to be fixed. Even going so far as saying that this game is still in beta.....after a full 2-3 years of being on steam. Even at 5$, don't buy this. Not even as a gag. Don't support the creators until they decide to fix their game. It's broken and shouldn't be up in such a bad condition along with blatently being rude to their customers and removing the posts of people giving critisms on their forums. * = an edit.Alright, so first off, lets just start with what you'll be introduced to first upon entering the game's world. These will be seperated into pros/cons respectively afterwards, but first I'm going to give you an explanation of how the game felt to me (and me alone. Obviously, this first bit will be biased.)You get your 5 minute download complete and you start the game up. The companys are shown before you're presented with the main menu. If you've played the 2nd Diablo game, you may feel some small vibes from the game, because I did personally. You're presented with Single Player and Multiplayer, along with options and the option to exit the game, along with the "Hero Siege" title presented above the selections. Most likely, you're going to hit Single Player.There are literally more character slots then there are characters. So go wild.Once you enter the character selection, you'll see hardcore mode and go "Well there's the Diablo vibes he was talking about." where if you die you're perma dead and have to make a new character. You select your character and enter. Again, you're going to feel very light Diablo II vibes. You check the shop and see you can only sell, but not buy. You go up and find a blue rift, so you enter it, then you go to the left and step on the roman numeral for 1 and enter the rift that pops up.Now, the combat.Also take note that the music cues and the announcer is just....PERFECT. Lol.Enemies at first seem a bit tanky. I'm gonna tell you this, with how OP items can get at only 15 (and yes, they are by definition Over Powered) enemies being tanky will be a mere memory and you'll be slaying everything with one shot and straight up rushing. Your character is level 35, and enemies are slightly becoming tanky again. You will most likely disregard it and still rush in thinking you're still the OP beast you once were, and you'll die from getting bashed from literally every angle from allowing yourself to get boxed in, along with enemies glitching via teleporting or simply making your screen freeze for a few seconds simply from spawning in.You then go to the main menu and almost click quit game, but then you notice the Multiplayer selection. You suddenly go "Well....maybe it's more fun to play with others." And then almost as soon as you login after a long loading screen, you eat your words as you enter the most laggiest lobbies even if you enter the region that you're in with just the best wifi around. Your teammates most likely rush a lot just because they know they aren't alone, and will die a lot. You spend 10 seconds to revive them and will average a total of one minute and 30 seconds out of every 15 minutes (if you even manage to stay connected that long.) Have fun being the opposite of the reaper for the entire multiplayer experience, or you can just make the person think you're a♥♥♥♥♥♥and go off somewhere else ignoring his revival circle.You get disconnected after spiking heavily, then say "Eh, what the heck. It's just a minor d/c." You then realise that the game doesn't auto save frequently, because before the d/c you were 45 and had a tonne of gear, now you're 35 and all of your gear is suddenly gone due to an irreversal loading error that cannot be fixed apparentally because I had this game for a good year and they haven't fixed it. The servers also seem like they got worse. You rage quit harder, and consider uninstalling, but you most likely enjoyed the singleplayer so you held onto it and waited for the next time you had literally nothing to do.SO! You got my biased part of the review out of the way. Here's the "General" review. I will take each piece of the puzzle and put it together next to a # rating. 1 = Bad | 10 = GoodGameplay - 4: It's fun! It's entertaining and is a nice grindy beat-em-up dungeon crawler/treasure hunter. It's like a discount Binding of Isaac if it had sex with discount Diablo. *Now, that's if you disregard the glitches. But with the glitches, the game just SUCKS. No way around it...*Multiplayer - (Official Server Hosting:2 Peer-To-Peer Hosting:4) The official servers suck so badly. That's all I can really say for that. Peer-To-Peer is pretty much hosting your own server, which for the most part fixes the lag issue to an extent. It at least makes it easier to play without disconnecting so frequently. I know this because I've played the majority with my girlfriend (all the way in Japan and we both still had good connectivity compared to the official server(s).) and we had plenty of fun playing together on there, however we both encountered the bug that makes our gear disappear and our levels drop due to rare auto-saves.Bug Free/Playability - (BF:1 Playability:*3*) Oh damn. It's bugged alright. *It is playable but....the glitches really ruin the mood as they're so frequent.* Nothing more to really add, just saying if you can ignore the mere gear/relic/level deletion, it really isn't that bad.Intruiging - 3.5: Honestly, I can't say it's boring at face value but it's definetally not attractive. I'll probably play it for 30 minutes then get off and do something else. But it's something I'll always come back to once in awhile, and maybe with my friends.Story - There isn't any. Unless you count slashing through mobs and randomly killing bosses as "story".DLC - (*) I haven't bought any DLC however some accessories and characters are locked behind them. I can't make even a biased review on them because I honestly don't really want to buy them. Technically, I'd rate the DLC at 1 from face value as I'm not really intruiged by any of the other characters. *The fact that they are being so rude to their customers and deciding to not fix bugs, in essence making the game a mere cash grab. Seriously. Just don't waste your money or time.*Community - 2: They are either silent or illiterate kids being angry in the lobby chat. If you're going to play, just go P-T-P with a friend. Overall - *1*: *This game is a nightmare. It's a wreck. It's a ruin. It's a cash grab. It's so. Very. Bad. I'm so sad that I can't get a refund so I don't have to fund the creators deciding to make such terrible broken games that are mere cash grabs, scams. I'm going to refund the gift I gave to my girlfriend so I can buy something else that's better and put heart into, even if the game is only 5$. Don't support the company until they learn to actually fix their coding.*

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												It would take a real hero to make this game seem good.I tried to like this game, but it is very cluttered, confusing, and pay to play. Once I got the hang of it and got one of the many game breaking items/skills, i just ripped through it. Most of the game (around 50% of it) is only in the DLC's you can buy. Their trademark character, the fallen paladin, is only playable through a DLC! He is even on the banner of the game below the community hub button on the store page! There is multiplayer, but the servers lag too much for it to be fun, and mods and cheating are banned in them. You will be banned if you accept items from a cheater. Imagine if all plugins and mods were permenantly banned from a game like minecraft? It would be absolutely horrible! The base game without multiplayer is either boringly easy, or way too hard till you find OP items. I don't reccomend this game. I got it for less than a dollar, and i feel cheated. If I was into useless grinding and I wanted to buy the numerous DLC, than I don't think it would be that bad. Unless you like playing cookie clicker for hours, I can't reccomend this game. If I could increase the difficulty, than it wouldnt be too boring, but you can't do that without beating the whole game!

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Hero Siege is a hack and slash rpg from in indie game studio.  This game can be great fun, it helps to have friends to play with like most online games.  It seems that the Devs have a thing for the diablo series, the referances are abound(from Shakos to enigma armors and more) Like any normal RPG you go through levels beating minibosses and a final boss at the end of each act.  Once some one makes a game up to 3 others can join.  Max level is 150 but after that you get extra levels that increase your stats 1 level = 10 to each stat.  The extra levels go across all your max level charicters, so once you get a 150 with (13) extra levels any charicter you get to 150 will get the extra 130 stat boost ***note since update  The xp needed to gain a hlvl has gone up but the stat bonus has gone from 10 to 25.**Pros -Many classes to choose from (You get more with DLC)Fast quick action ingameEasy to learnVast amounts of gear and combosTons of Relics you pick up that do veriaty of things (these do go away once you die, but you get them at the end of levels and in shops)Cons-Online gameplay can be buggy (game crashing occurs too often)The community is hit or miss, meet some great people but there are alot of beggers and anoying people.Dev team is small so it can be a bit to get bugs fixedThe prices is alittle steep since all the DLCs are pricey tooI will point out that the Collectors editions include things like Skins and Eye Candies but the normal DLCs have the Classes and levels.  I was a Huge Diablo 2 nerd and this is a great new game for those that like D2.Over all I really enjoy the game.  I hope to see it grow.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												I don't do reviews really often, usually when a game is REALLY good or REALLY bad, do I feel like doing a review. This little game was a huge surprise! I expected it to just be a mediocre game that you play for 1-2 hours, to try it out, then kinda just shelf it 'for another day'.Not the case, this game is VERY good, simplistic in design, but has intrinsic depth. You can sit down and play this game, and quickly realize it is 3 hours later ! The game's levels are diverse enough to keep it fun, but not too diverse that you feel you need to keep learning how to play. All the items that drop in the game are actually useful ! This game is one that everyone should try, especially at the low price it always sells for, then when it goes on sale, it is a real steal !

												Before I start the reccomendation I want you to go to the negative ones and read them. What do you see? People ♥♥♥♥♥ing because the game is too hard. Guess what. It isn't, it takes time to get used to it, but it itsn't. Probaby the people writing those reviews are used to easy as hell games.The game is simply amazing. You can choose from a variety of classes all with different abilities and spells and as you go through the stages your hero becomes a lot stronger. You need to have dodging skills as well, and good eye coordinations because enemies appear out of nowhere. The DLCs that will come and came out will add many features as well, so I suggest you buy those for a better experience.There isn't much to say to be honest as it is still early access, but it is worth the money. I rate it 9/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												EDIT:: 1 year later, here I am still playing Hero SeigeOriginal Review: 7/18/14Edit: 7/18/15Hero Siege, the game about killing stuff that has more health than you.Then again, what roguelike isn't about that?After 3.5 hours of gameplay, I can strongly recommend you buy this title. Its not easy but not hard difficulty keeps you from sliding right through a level, but it also doesn't have you on your knees begging for mercy. The classes vary from something traditional like the Pyromancer, to something not so traditional, like the Redneck. Crypts, dungeons and statues can apprear, giving you chances at gold, keys to open chests, and experience to level up. I can't imagine the time it takes to get to level 210 (as seen in the screenshots), my Pyro is only a level 17, after 3.5 hours of playing.But here's the thing about roguelikes: no matter how much you play, or how much your practice, you're still going to suck. With a game like this, you just have to hope and pray you don't get hit with an arrow of get a potion that brings you down to no health. If you get hit by an arrow, that's it. You have to find some health or you'll get hit by another and die. Aside from that, no matter how many times the game pulls a kill out of it's ♥♥♥, the satisfying feeling of leveling up or killing a boss will always make up for it.Even after throwing my mouse at the wall, or tearing my headset off and throwing at my PC, Hero Siege will hold a place in my gaming life, known as the game that broke me. It will forever hold a place as my least favorite game, the game i play all the time. 10/10

content:
Posted: March 6
												It's a nice game, don't get me wrong.But unfortunately, there are many bugs. I hope that maybe in 3-4 updates the devs will finally fix what is REALLY wrong (without adding more problems).If you can have it for a really low price and have some friends to play with you, it could be worth it as long as you don't go higher than destruction difficulty. Even in that case, do not buy all the dlcs.- Corrosive puddles are still a dumb and artificial way to add difficulty. I'm not against a more challenging game but here it's plain boring and game breaking for certain chars that just cannot play higher WH because of this only. No counterplay.- The drops are even worse than before - I'm amazed by this, didn't know it was possible. Less drops of Satanic gear and when it does, it seems like you have less luck to have the synergies.- The inconsistency of toxic mode: it is supposed to evolve with your WH level but you have all the hazards right from the start... sometimes it goes away to scale properly when you reset the map. Drop rates also seems to be worse. Basically not worth it to play this mode for ALL the char. How am I supposed to avoid the explosions/puddles in the tiny rooms of the dungeons/crypts?- Sometimes it is impossible to use the WH portal... always a pleasure to waste money.- Cheaters are roaming free.- The WH keys are so expensive while the WH in itself doesn't give much money... So basically you have to grind destructions bosses and pray to loo the keys. I love grinding but again it is not pleasant as you gain no xp, there is no fun.- If you want to fight higher level bosses in order to have a boost in gear level, it is really frustrating as again, some mechanics have no counterplay. I'm ok with being OneShoted by those bosses but sometimes you have to step back, so you don't know when they are going to use their abilities so you can't avoid them aaaaand you're dead.PS. don't keep your gear in your stash, you never know when it's going to be wiped.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												Many things can be said about this game, so I'll just go into the pros and cons.Pros: It's a well done roguelike game.It's spiced up enough that you don't have to stick to one class and be stuck only with that one class. (although...)The game is different each time, as you never know what items you are going to get.Cons: There is an abundant amount of issues with the game that are thankfully constantly being patch, but it can be bothersome from time to time.There is a bit of a paywall to access every single class, but it's slightly understandable.There is very little end game content. Once you've beaten every single boss and stage, it's just going back to grinding.All in all, it's a good game. It's not this special little snowflake of a roguelike, but it's a roguelike done well. 3/5 stars.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												Decent game overall with a lot of similarities to Binding of Isaac. Like BOI, it has you progressing from area to area defeating monsters while collecting items and coins and building your stats to eventually take on the boss for that area. It also has a fair amount of replayability as you can attempt to go through the game on harder difficulties to unlock achievements. Unlike BOI, it lacks style and flair, as well as some sort of story or setting to hold the game together and to provide motivation to progress or some sort of end-goal to work towards. The latter is not necessarily a must-have for these types of games, but I think it certainly could have been an improvement in this case. In addition, the decision to not explain much and let you figure things out as you go along (again, like Isaac) is fine, but it has issues. The key to letting one figure things out is that one must actually be able to figure things out. In other words, the game doesn't have to hold your hand, but it needs to be intuitive to allow this learning process to happen. Things like referring to the same stat in different ways (mana and energy) will, in general, initially lead to confusion, and gameplay elements such as an empty unexplained chest forever in your inventory (that apparently is only relevant to some unique end-game boss or something) dont mesh well with the decision to let the player figure everything out on their own.There are a few things that I particularly like about the game. For one, I think I actually prefer the way the combat feels in Hero Siege over Binding of Isaac. The hits you land on enemies just feel a bit meatier and a bit more impactful. FIghting through waves of them can be both satisfying and addicting. It's because of this that I probably don't mind too much the grindy nature of the game (a complaint I often see). It's true that the game could use some rebalancing to avoid the need to revisit and battle through the same areas to build stats and items, but I enjoy the combat enough that it's doesn't feel too much like a chore. Building a beefed-up character, by the way, can also be quite satisfying. The other thing I like about the game is its art. I'm a sucker for well-done pixel art, and the visuals in the game are just that. It's not anything mind-blowing, but it gives the game a very clean and sharp look.Overall, I like Hero Siege. It's not amazing, but it's fun enough that I'll probably keep playing it for a while to try to get those achievements. If you like Binding of Isaac, there's a good chance you'll enjoy this to some degree.6/10

I bought solely for single player so have not tried the multiplayer but no issues as of yet except for items sometimes falling into areas you cannot reach.  Pretty difficult at times and sometimes to the point I just rage quit but always seem to find myself coming back a few minutes later for some more. Higly reccomend.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												The game is great, love the classes and leveling system. However, if you are looking at this game for it's multiplayer you should hold off. The multiplayer is full of bugs. The bugs can be small like invisible friendlies of major such as character switching. The multiplayer is also only avaliable with the dlc at the moment(it'll be free later according to the dev). Other than that, this game is a great way to spend time.

												I Played this game on my friend computer , i broke the game achievements and currency systems 10/10I will recommend you to play it on your own PC to avoid achievement and currency problems/confusion, but keep you keep your multiplier characters. I Still really recommend this game , its awesome and got elements similar to Binding of Issac, Diablo and more , it have lots of "Easter eggs" reference.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												PS: Pardon if you are the devs and are spending time trying to balance out and make this game better, just ignore my review and go on with your lives, work hard and make it a good game so I can recommend it. I will correct this review if the game makes up for my expectations in the future.PPS: This review will present some terms adherent to MMORPGs, other games, or just terms that I created since I am lazy to look out for the correct terms to be used. I am going to start this review by poiting out the good sides of this game and why someone would buy it. Then pointing out my opinions (which are mostly negative) on this game based on other similar games I've played, or games with similar mechanics that are pretty referenced within this game.First of all, this game looks very promising, it has many mechanics that may work in the future if more polished, it has many things that would work if the developers spent more time on it  has a pretty good presentation and a good amount of references hidden within, the Character creation looks like Diablo 2, the skill builds work similarly to Diablo 2 too, both mechanically and aesthetically, the way the light goes through the stage after finishing it looks a lot like the Den of Evil from the same game, the game makes lots of references of The Binding of Isaac too, which is another roguelike that has many similar mechanics. I would point both of them as being the main drivers of this game, along with Diablo 3, that has many mechanics "referenced", such as the elite enemies, some of them have similar powers, such as Cold Enchanted freezing the player character for some seconds that may kill him, while others may explode and send out a globe of laser that (will, most of the time, if unseen) kill the player character too. I like the way the developers tried to create many classes and how they try to work differently, the necromancer summons minions to aid him, while the Viking goes straight for melee combat doing hard crowd control. The game is separated in acts, just like the now-so-famous Action RPGs, it also resembles old time games such as Smash TV, you wait for the monsters to come, and exterminate them while trying to dodge them and stuff like that. Okay, end of the positive parts.If the developers were trying to make their game similar to The Binding of Isaac + Blizzard Stuff + Pixel Art + Original IdeasGold feels useless for most of the time, while crystals are just "cash" that can be used on some pretty cute/cool stuff like hats, it is also used for resetting the character or renaming it, these character features should be free or with small work needed by default to incentive players to change names and try new different builds, but are pretty expensive.Damage done by the player is extremely hard to see, numbers are small and travel too fast, and are also decimal.Hidden traps can be utterly strong without previous knowledge since the player couldn't see them, and are mostly luck based when they spawn, if it hits the player, the mobs or nothing. Grabbing potions on the ground may mean player's death if she happens to grab one that is among the gold/loot while a blood maggot/other strong mob is shooting at you. Since the players stops all animations for extremely valuable 0.5 sec.Some bosses will 1 shot a squishier character with no way to read how much damage they would deal, just like the "girl spirits"  Annie or Samar, they just spawn going lightning speed toward the player while dealing like 50% damage in 1 hit, no clue what happened and just died. Also, their projectiles don't look like dealing THAT much damage.Voice acting is terrible, wish there was a way to shut it down completely, because there is no way.Now for the main part:The Game feels totally incomplete and unpolished, at times I thought it was a Early Access and had to go to the Store Page to check if it really wasn't. Most of the Controller based commands feel incomplete, e.g.: "B" is used to call a new wave, while "B" is also used to close the level up menu, if you press B to close the level up menu while you are able to call a wave, it'll do both.Trees and most of the props are just hindering player's vision too much, just too polluted, I know that the intention was to hinder the player, but since the player can't tell what is behind 100% of the trees, sometimes there is a ultra-strong 1 hit killing turret/statue trap and the player can't tell it, just killing the player by full surprise.Most of the "spheres" that monsters throw to the sky when dying are broken, blue, red, yellow, they are always off screen unless the player is north of the monster that throws it. Sometimes monsters have "0" HP on their bars but still alive, some monsters get stuck on their own paths and cannot reach me going forwards and backwards non-stop, somesome bosses are ridiculously easy, like Beketamun, while others need extremely high skill from the player to be able to kill him, like ones that laser around non-stop, bosses like that need a open-area for the player to be able to move, but they walk after the player and sometimes it just means death if summoned on the wrong place. Such as near a Statue Trap.dungeons are like rolling a d20 to see if you get out alive or not, some dungeons may present you with a screenful of godlike enemies on the instant you enter it, the area that the player has to deal with bosses inside dungeons is also pretty small, there is nigh-none space to fight bosses, and there are also bosses that are summoned that are ultra-strong for particularly enclosed spaces. There are also other dungeons that may be empty with a free treasure for the player with just some small puzzle before it. Entering dungeons is just too high of a risk for lower leveled characters, since the chances of dying because of a unlucky boss or unlucky room are very high. While it may present free relics for higher leveled characters, it just stacks with the grind needed to become "successful".So far most of my deaths have been to the Blue Sphere on-kill effect from monsters, I've played plenty of Diablo 3 to know where this mechanic came from, so, In Diablo 3, sometimes monsters had the "Arcane Enchanted" property, which happens to be a similar mechanic, when they die, they leave a purple sphere on the place of their death, which exists for 1 second before firing a "laser needle" which spins and deals huge damage, the main problem with Hero Siege's "Arcane Enchanted" is that it is only a sphere that's thrown out of screen at the monster's death, when it comes back it is already firing the laser, seeing the shadow of the ball is pretty difficult considering the amount of trees, grass, monsters and shots on the screen, most of the time it is instant death for the player if it happens to fall on his head, that is if no traps spawn on the player's feet insta killing.- It seems to me that the Devs didn't play their own game before releasing 1.0, or if they did and enjoyed it, they must have a pretty taste for artificial difficulty. Some bosses can kill you while on their death animations, due to the lightning globes that keep spawning when the player damages them while they are dying.most sprites are far from being user friendly, since it's hard to tell what's "friendly particle" to a "foe particle".- There is no catalogue to check the item list, I know that the Twin Blades give me Critical Chance, but how much Crit%? I can't even see my critical chance on the menu in first place. If this is intentional, it feels pretty odd when playing.There is almost no room for faults since most of the stuff will 1-hit the player, I know that the developers must've made it their way, but when playing on hardcore it is just too unforgiving.tl;dr: dont buy it, too luck/grind based instead of skill, unpolished, broken mechanics sluggishly borrowed from other games. My tip, go for Risk of Rain for roguelike, Path of Exile for action

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												It's pretty slow paced. That's the first thing I noticed when I started this game.This rogue like game, Hero Siege is a top down 3rd person shooter/fighter. There are several characters which contain but are not limited to, Viking, Pyromancer, Necromaniac, Lumberjack, Pirate, and more. Each of the classes sport a very unique play style while all typically having a base speed.Items in this game aren't very common to come by, and level progression is fairly simple. Pros:+Several unique classes+Game visuals look good+Interactive environment+Monsters are difficult(ish)+Music is alrightCons:-Voice acting is pretty bad-All dialogue is pretty poorly written-Interface and menus all work like they're meant for controller-Settings menu is pretty sparce-Slow (More of a preference)-Enemies that aren't tough mainly just have a lot of health or you just take too much damage-Progression is kind of slow-Item drop rateWhile the cons seem to outweigh the pros, it's not that bad of a game. It'd be way better if certain elements were fixed such as the shoddy voice acting, level progression, and things that kill you basically immediately without you being able to do much on your part, but I guess that's part of the rogue like genre. Overall, 6/10.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Hero Siege is a good, solid game that doesn't take long to play- but certainly has an incentive for you to pour hours into it if you want. I'll let others talk about the gameplay, which is solid, and i'll focus on this instead-  the things I like about Hero Siege is that the developers are VERY open and responsive to player feedback. Updates/ fixes are frequent. But the guys behind this game also did something that's important to me- that is, the game closes FAST. One of my many points of frustration with a game like Battlefield 4 where spiders have been known to crawl on me and spin webs while i wait for it to fully close. Hero Siege and EVE Online both close within a blink of an eye- to which i am grateful.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												Hero Siege is an awesome game.  It is a great time killer with mindless hack n slash and rogue like looting similar to Binding of Isaac.  The melee characters are a little tough to play as a beginner, and ranged classes can be a little too easy for the active player.  Though there is no real story to this, the rpg elements are great.  Leveling, skill trees to costumize your build.  This is well worth the money for rogue like lovers.

												Got a 4 Pack and had mad fun for a few days with my friends.Then the devs dropped a big F**K YOU and made the game unplayable patch after patch, adding meaningless content without fixing what already was broken.Crashes, about 10 fps, skills and talents that stop working all the time and one of the worst inventory systems I've ever seen in a game.I'm more sad than angry. We had a blast and now it f*****g sucks.
