number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												I would like to recommend this, but honestly I can't. Even for its "low" price. Even if it's an indie game, assuming that indie games have lower budget and they can be imperfect. This game is far from perfect.I initially bought this game because of my friend who also bought it. There was a nice discount so I was like "well, whatever". I like rogue-like/rpg games (even when it comes to modern games of that genre). What's the worst that could happen, this game was cheaper than a pack of cigarettes.When I first played the game it was a really nice experience. There is a few classes to choose from (like 10), each with different skill/perk set and stats, look etc. It's nice to have this kind of diversity. So I started playing the game.This game is pretty simple and kinda reminds me of Binding of Isaac (it's not a carbon copy though, but you can see the inspiration). The difference is you don't get rooms with enemies, they come in waves, also you get levels. But still you get temporary boosts (potions) and 1-run boosts (relics). In addition you can also have a minion and a "charm" which is a stat item.Talking about gameplay: it's repetitive but a game can have replayability of sorts. You get few different bosses and enemies, they get tougher, some get affixes (special abilities), you develop your hero, get new relics and such. But there isn't really much fun about it. It's a shame, but I'll talk about a few things in detail in a second.Unlocks: Mostly consisting of areas and difficulty levels. The latter seems obvious, as for the first: often I feel like the areas are almost the same but with ground colored in white/green/yellow, even some statues/models are reused, and I really didn't expect that. You also get relics which are fun but some seem overpowered for the moment and often you feel like there's little control over them. Also I've never felt like "gee I would like to get X now to make this run better/more fun". Isn't that exactly the opposite of what SHOULD be happening?Hero development: You get levels and new skills abilities but the descriptions are really confusing and it often feels like some of the perks are underwhelming which shouldn't ever happen in such a game. Again, I didn't feel any urge to level up in any other way than "this will maybe improve my fighting capabilities by 0.05% yay". I get that some of the perks are better, some are worse, some will only work with enough attack speed/damage, but still...Mechanics/gameplay: Ok I thought the game was simple enough to never touch this subject,  but... Controls in the game are really sketchy, honestly. One of the things is that you get to use the mouse in game, you see the cursor while playing, but still you control and attack with WASD and arrows. Kinda strange, but ok, let's say that's the way this game is made, it's not bad, just a bit confusing at start. On the other hand you can go to the right and attack to the left, which is cool for kiting with ranged heroes (and melee as well). But if you use a directed active skill it will still shoot in the direction you're going, not the direction you're currently facing, which is REALLY annoying. Sometimes you can't tell if there's a wall on your way, or you're gonna pass right through.Audio: The voice acting is terrible and I feel it would be way better if they didn't even bother recording the voice lines. There's a few of them and you hear the same line over and over again. Most of the responses are super edgy even though it doesn't fit the design (that's the way I feel about it). Other than that the audible part of the game is OK, nothing to complain about.Graphics: It's ok, pseudo-retro-ish style like in many indie games released in past 3-4 years. But still, as mentioned before they could've made the areas a bit more interesting and varied. I didn't mention some of the projectiles are really tricky to see/recognize, but I'm not sure if that's how it was supposed to be. My humble opinion: they should be easy to spot, but hard to dodge/avoid.Multiplayer/additional content: This is where it gets really though... Due to lack of replayability factor (other than mindless grinding, which ends quickly because you have only 9 abilities per hero to discover) I wanted to ask myself what content is there waiting for me, but there isn't really much about the game. I was really so bored after playing for 1.5 hour (I felt like I've seen everything) I wanted some confirmation about this, and my friends actually confirmed there's not much more to this game than what I've already seen. Co-op would be fun, but you can either play local co-op or you have to... PAY FOR THE DLC. I mean jesus, the 2 DLCs this game has cost more than the game itself and one of them is pretty much a MUST HAVE if you want to play with your friends over the internet. This really sucks.Conclusion/TL;DR: It's not really that bad, it has a lot of flaws, but it's somewhat playable, just really boring after a short session, unless you LOVE doing the same thing over and over again, but you could be playing any other game of the genre and most probably have more fun. It's really repetitive, there isn't much of a reward for playing. There's a lot of stuff unlocked with the DLCs (like multiplayer) so consider the price for the game + dlcs as a full product price. I personally felt like the game I bought was just the demo and a way to "hype" me into buying the additional content. I didn't get hyped at all. Game sucks.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Got this game in a Humble Bundle a while back. I've been playing it since before the online patch was added, and it's been a great experiance. For this companies first game, it has everything you look for in a fun top down roguelike-ish RPG. The classes are ballanced pretty well. The level/dungeon Randomization, items, and pickup's are great and make the game different with each playthough. The multiplayer can be buggy at times, but it's been improved with each patch, and is getting a lot better.8/10

There are also other dungeons that may be empty with a free treasure for the player with just some small puzzle before it. Entering dungeons is just too high of a risk for lower leveled characters, since the chances of dying because of a unlucky boss or unlucky room are very high. While it may present free relics for higher leveled characters, it just stacks with the grind needed to become "successful".So far most of my deaths have been to the Blue Sphere on-kill effect from monsters, I've played plenty of Diablo 3 to know where this mechanic came from, so, In Diablo 3, sometimes monsters had the "Arcane Enchanted" property, which happens to be a similar mechanic, when they die, they leave a purple sphere on the place of their death, which exists for 1 second before firing a "laser needle" which spins and deals huge damage, the main problem with Hero Siege's "Arcane Enchanted" is that it is only a sphere that's thrown out of screen at the monster's death, when it comes back it is already firing the laser, seeing the shadow of the ball is pretty difficult considering the amount of trees, grass, monsters and shots on the screen, most of the time it is instant death for the player if it happens to fall on his head, that is if no traps spawn on the player's feet insta killing.- It seems to me that the Devs didn't play their own game before releasing 1.0, or if they did and enjoyed it, they must have a pretty taste for artificial difficulty. Some bosses can kill you while on their death animations, due to the lightning globes that keep spawning when the player damages them while they are dying.most sprites are far from being user friendly, since it's hard to tell what's "friendly particle" to a "foe particle".- There is no catalogue to check the item list, I know that the Twin Blades give me Critical Chance, but how much Crit%? I can't even see my critical chance on the menu in first place. If this is intentional, it feels pretty odd when playing.There is almost no room for faults since most of the stuff will 1-hit the player, I know that the developers must've made it their way, but when playing on hardcore it is just too unforgiving.tl;dr: dont buy it, too luck/grind based instead of skill, unpolished, broken mechanics sluggishly borrowed from other games. My tip, go for Risk of Rain for roguelike, Path of Exile for action

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												Difficult, unpredictable, gets worse with every update.I don't know at what point the developers for Hero Siege decided to make their game even more random than it already was, as well as severely nerfing skills (seriously Pyromancer now only has a CHANCE to fire an extra fireball instead of it happening constantly?) and generally making the game feel like a chore to play, but it has gone from being a genuinely fun roguelike-shooter hybrid to being a frustrating mess of a game.Why can't we use crystals anymore to buy a random item at the start of the game? Why if a dungeon or a crypt spawns at the start of the game can you not enter it when the wave finishes? Why are the enemy-kill reactive bombs still FAR too fast (seriously if I get 1-shot by a laser that I literally cannot avoid due to not being able to outrun it, then it is just outright unfair game design). Then we get to the issue whereby upgrading stats and skills is just a bit pointless. By the time they get to a place where they're having a significant effect on how the character plays with zero artifacts, I've already grown bored of playing that character because of the lack of variety in the first place.Used to be fun, now it's overly difficult to the point of frustration because of how random it can be at times.EDIT: Went back to play the game once after writing this review. Had pretty low health and a wave had just finished. Dune rat pops out of absolutely nowhere and kills me. Yeah, I'll catch up with this game in another year or so and hopefully they'll have added some serious balance changes/QOL changes to it.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												For any of you reluctant to buy this:Dude. This game is honestly the game i've been trying to find for months.1) Really fun and easy gameplay2) XP Based level-up systems3) Hidden stuff to find4) Actually has fairly good voice acting5) Addictive (I bought this and it immediately ate up 2 hrs of my time)6) The soundtrack and overall audio of this game is very well done and fitting7) The boss fights are fun to play, hard as ballz, but you level up often enough and get enough skills so you look at the boss and say "awww f**k" buy then look at your skills and say "Get ready to get your sh*t rocked"8) The enemy designs are stylized (<- dunno how to spell that) and very pleasing 9) This game is exactly what i want. A pixelized game that isnt pixelized because lack of technology such as in the SNES or N64 era even, but because they can use *today's* tech and make a pixelated game that just runs smooth and is exceedingly fun to play. I had like $0.30 in my steam account since i bought other stuff beforehand, so i sold a few extra cards i had; no biggie. Then i found this game was only like $1.50 or so during steam sale. For a buck fifty; hell yeah this game is worth it. For it's normal $6 price? Completely worth it. Everytime i play and eventually die, it only makes me want to keep going because it was always my mistake. I've encountered no game-breaking or player-killing bugs, its only and always me using the wrong move or walking into a bad spot filled with enemies. Will i buy the DLC? I see no reason not too :DRating: 9.5/10My only gripe with this game? They really want you to buy the DLC XDThey show you cool characters (er, *cooler* characters) at the create-a-class screen and i was trying to click this one character before i realized the big fat "DLC" thing above it ;~;but you do get like 2 characters in addition to the maps and other items they added in the game, so you aren't buying *just* the character like some games *cough cough* mobile games *cough cough*I plan to buy the DLC not because i want the cool character (BY THE WAY all the characters are really cool and have skills and movesets that are applicable and fitting)  but bc i want those extra maps and items and stuff to mess around with in my downtime. All in all: for an indie game, this proves how much better this genre can be than mainstream/headline game companies. You will not regret buying it :3

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												Hero Siege is a great 2-player local coop game.In Hero Siege, you fight wave after wave of enemies, then fight a boss, then do it again in the next world.  While that sounds like a game that has been made 1000 times before, Hero Siege does it really well.  Each player can choose one of eight heroes, each with their own special abilities.  You level up your hero by killing enemies, increasing your stats and learning new abilities.  Those stats/abilities are permanent.Additionally, in each playthrough you find gold and artifacts.  The gold can be used to buy potions or increase your stats more (for that playthrough only), and the artifacts give you further stat-boosts, or sometimes special abilities.  These temporary stat boosts count much more than the permanent ones.  The net result is that, while leveling up your characters definitely does help, the outcome of a given playthrough depends much more on how well you played.  It's entirely possible (though extremely difficult) to beat the game on your first playthrough.There are enough different artifacts/enemies to keep the game interesting through multiple playthroughs.The downside is that the game is currently extremely buggy.  During 10 hours of gameplay, we encountered 3 game-breaking bugs which set us back several hours each, along with countless other less serious bugs.  We played local-coop; the developer recently (mid-July 2014) released an experimental online coop mode, which I've heard is even buggier.Fortunately, the developer is very active on the forums, and has promised to continue fixing the bugs people find.  The latest bugfix was currently 4 days ago, so he seemed to be making good on his word.EDIT April 2015: We tried playing again today.  The majority of the bugs we found a year ago have been fixed, but have unfortunately been replaced by a whole slew of new bugs.  The game is still unbeatable, entirely because the game still crashes after several hours of play, and doesn't correctly save your relics.The developer still seems to be active, which is good.  And this game is a TON of fun.  Just be prepared to lose your game at any time due to the massive number of bugs.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												Its a big  9.5/10.   TL;DR :    + Really really nice pixel art + Big variety of everything, you'll never get bored playing this game + Good mechanics, a little little wonky on gamepad but you customize it + Basically the perfect hack n' slash ++ Devs are always present and here to help you. You can tell how much they love the game. - DLC's, they add a lot, like new classes,maps relics etc. But they're cheap and it wont affect the game that much, really. You'll have the same amount of fun. - Bugs, crashes etc. A month ago a new patch screwed up the whole coding but they already fixed basically everything with the help of the community, again, the devs are present. Dont worry about bugs&etc.  Long/Detailed Review This might be one one my favorite games i own here. I played this game a lot offline/at friends houses but i eventually bought it because i was so fissured in it jesus christ help this game is so good.Basically you pick your hero and your only purpose is to live, and let me tell you, its going to be hard sometimes. You run around the stage, dodge some traps, kill monsters, get sweet relics and level up. All you need to do is to live trough all waves and beat the boss. And trust me, you'll do that for hours, the game really knows how to keep you entretained.There's a variety of everything here relics, stages, skills/builds, bosses, charms, buffs, mobs, costumes, everything. The game can be pretty hard, and pretty long. But not boring at all, you'll always be able to go to dungeons, crypts and special stages that gives a really nice touch to the game. The voice acting is kinda cool too, you really get what your class/character feels. The (pixel-)art is pretty, it really pays off very well in the scenario and on the character/game design in general. The mechanics are amazing too, the game is pretty simple but at the same time you need to be aware of everything that is happening, otherwise you'll end up dead because a giant spiked block hit you.   HOWEVER  Nothing is perfect, the only thing i cant not talk about here is that you WILL NEED patience with the game. There are lots of crashes and bugs that will drive you nuts, but dont worry. The  game devs  are always up to date and  present in the community .  They will quickly release a patch to fix anything, hell, some days they've even released 3 patchs.  I believe the game is on its way to be a 10/10. But really,  buy it. Its ♥♥♥♥ing amazing.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												tl;dr - only the graphics are goodIt's another two-stick shooter where you try to survive waves of enemies and level up your abilities. The decent art disguises how amateurish the game feels. I tried playing as the redneck class (to take back 'Merrikuh from the monsters). There was no description of how the different classes play, so I was confused to find my controller vibrating at full power and the attack button (there IS at least a controller map) not working. I was eventually able to start attacking (the redneck swings his chainsaw just like a sword... did I mention how limited the animations are?) and figured out that the redneck has to take a minute to pull the ripcord on his chainsaw at the start of a fight. I think. Again, there's no warning about this, no cord-pulling animation, no proper sound effect of a chainsaw starting up, just vibration and a disabled attack button.Oh, and I unlocked a molotov cocktail attack that you use by aiming with the right thumbstick and then launch by clicking in the thumbstick. That sounds like a terrible, awkward way to aim an attack because it *IS*.I enjoy other games like this in small doses, and I don't mind simple graphics (I bought both of the Zombie Estate xbox indie games) but this has severe design flaws and just isn't fun. Many of the reviews are positive and one specifically mentions that it takes a few hours to get the feel of this game, but I'm not going to give it the benefit of the doubt.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												Here is a genre I like very much. You don’t need to solve puzzles or be scared of being lost on a big map, you don’t need to struggle with complex RPG elements… All you need to do is to focus on the carnage! It is said to be roguelike but doesn’t roguelike mean turn-based? Hero Siege is not turn-based, quite the opposite, it is a fast-paced game. There are some simple RPG elements; you level up when you earn enough experience killing monsters, you gain talent/ability points and spend them however you like when you level up, you can carry an item and you can buy something from hidden shops. It is just the way I like in such a game. I would define Hero Siege as hack and slash.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												Do you want to play Diablo 2, except with more monotony and terrible balance?  This game is for you.  It's good for a number of hours if you enjoy top-down hack'n'slash style games.  As as added bonus, this features an itemization system similar to Binding of Isaac, except with content ripped off from many other popular games (mostly Diablo).Haven't tried multiplayer, and I have no desire to until balance is fixed.  There's an option to start in a later act, but it's practically useless unless you're an absurdly high level and only serves to make beating the game more difficult, edging on impossible.I can't recommend this game until balance changes are made and original content is developed.  I feel like I'm playing a crappy Diablo 2, which is a travesty.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												You have to fight waves of monsters, dodge mean traps, clear dungeons and crypts, beat amazing bosses and avoid your own death!This is another great roguelike game which i want to recommend. You can choose between a couple of classes and some of them have a very different playstyle to each other. Beside this, you have a levelsystem with multiple possibilities to spend your abilitypoints. It has enough different difficulties, so that it wont get boring after the first few hours. I can really enjoy the graphics, it reminds me of some other old 2D-games. Also you will discover some refferences to other games, so maybe you will even get an extra smile, when you receive the next item from the last bossfight.More interesting than this is probably the fact, that it has a nice local coop mode (and its fully supported for xbox360 controllers and personally I really love to play Hero Siege with using them). But even when you cant get some friend over for a local session, theres still an online coop mode - so in worst case you can still play with some stranger around the world. Last but not least, the developers didnt abandon their game and they are updating all the time (fixing bugs but also granding new content).

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												  This game is a blend of Diablo 2 and The Binding of Isaac, or, in other words, Hack 'n' Slash with Rogue-like elements. What I'm getting at is that it's got randomized enemies, dungeon-crawling and gold hoarding like from an old Diablo game, yet it has randomized "pills" (potions) and gameplay-changing relics as seen in The Binding of Isaac. I like it. The game is also light in content, meaning that it's not supposed to be taken seriously, e.g. such over-the-top serious voice-acting, that it makes you cringe, etc.Up-sides of the game:+Something new: Hack 'n' Slash meets Rogue-like+Humorous voice-acting (some may disagree with this one)+Randomized enemies, each stage may have different bosses, etc.+Randomized potions, powerful relics+Lots of character classes, each with their own skills and skill-builds  What I didn't like about the game is that it didn't have much to offer, as in, all levels were limited to a box-shaped fortress which you couldn't leave, all the gold you hoarded gave you little help (you may ocassionally buy a Full-Restore potion, which is by far the best use for gold, or buy an AttackSpeed-Boost potion to help you take down a boss quicker) but I'd really like to see some other use for the gold I gather rather than just spending it on potions. The game also has lots of grinding to get the higher levels of your character, and when you eventually get strong enough, the early levels become a total bore.Down-sides of the game:-Little use for gold-Game is a grindfest, but you overpower your foe fairly quickly-Boring base levels (Dungeons and Crypts are a bit more random)-Game doesn't keep giving you fresh content for longOverall I'd give this game about 5.5/10, it's pretty "meh-diocre"My advice, if you sometimes need to waste a couple a' minutes and see this game for a cheap price, get it. Otherwise? No. I don't think buying this game will pay off as you won't play an hour for every buck you spent on it buying it full-priced.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												WELL, it's a fun enough game, if you can manage to play for a long time without experiencing a crash. I enjoyed this far more than Binding of Isaac, but it does have the same kind of feel.The characters are pretty interesting, as are the relics implemented. Your accessories, the aesthetic stuff, are purchased through crystals, not microtransaction based AFAIK.The downside to this game: well, there's many crashes, as I said earlier. I sunk 5 hours into my Marksman, and experienced my first freeze, had to close via Task Manager and lost everything. There's no autosave, so if you enter through a portal to the next level, you'd best hope you don't have a horde waiting for you, and have to pop all your cooldowns, because odds are, one of those times, you're going to crash. It has happened twice now, the other being after the annoyance at losing my stuff, only to see it happen again, this time as a fatal coding error.But, you know, for $2, it's a good time consumer. Takes me back to early hack'n'slash fun. Give it a shot, while it's on the severe discount, you may enjoy it and experience no crashes whatsoever.

												Hero Siege is a surprisingly fun & addictive game that I never expected to enjoy half as much as I have. It combined elements of old school arcade games with dungeon crawls and implements the grind factor in without making the game overly drab or repetitive. The level design are challenging and albeit frustrating as hell whilst the character design is charming and the enemies are plentiful in the variants for this neat little game. If you picked this up in a bundle, I recommend dumping a few hours on it when you feel a bit of casual play. If not, it’s not an awful RRP for the game but I’d say it was worth no more than it’s Appstore counterpart at $2-$3.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												What we have here is a fairly decent start to a roguelike that quickly gets consumed by its own weaknesses. You start every game at the beginning: great. You can upgrade your character through progression: super. Your upgrades stay with you when you restart: just what I wanted.After that though, we encounter the two biggest design flaws for the game. First, the ratio of player power to enemy power doesn't follow appropriately and you soon find yourself in a situation where the enemies are far too powerful. Second, the fact that you can only fire in four directions means you are severely limited in what you can hit at any given time; plus, enemies have no such restriction, making the design choice questionable at best. The combination of these two things means there is a definite "correct build" that you must go through to get very far into the game, which for this type of game reduces player agency in their progression.The graphics are very well done, with high-quality pixel art and a great palette. There's never any confusion because of graphics as to what's going on, with the slight exception that it can be difficult to see your character or other enemies when they're behind something, like a tree, even with the fade out of the object. Not sure what the fix is to this, but it's only just "okay" as it is.The sound feels powerful and the music is good, but not terribly memorable. All in all, the game starts off letting you feel like you're doing very well but quickly descends into an exercise in futility. After a point, you never really feel very powerful any more and you just see the progression as a chore. That's unfortunate because there's a lot of potential here.All in all I don't think I can recommend the game, not because it isn't fun for a while, but more because it should be fun for a lot longer and isn't. The difficulty curve doesn't track in a way that pushes you to keep coming back, but instead punishes you for doing well early on, punishes you for minor mistakes, punishes you for not being able to see behind objects, and punishes you if you've made the wrong build along the way.If there were a "maybe" button, I'd select that. Since I can't, I'd say skip this and go for any number of other games like it that are better.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												PC gaming and pc gamers in general have always been a very mature and humble crowd. For years we have been content with our simple and plain steam interface, and we sure as hell don't buy into the flashy advertisements or gold lettering of"Xbox live gold". And you certainly never see advertisements tacked all over steams borders.So for me to open a PC game on steam and see two huge advertisements "BUY NOW ON APPSTORE, BUY NOW ON ANDROID STORE" really just rubs me the wrong way. Is this the begging of the end? Are we going to allow this? This is the heart of mobile appstore freemium brought right to our doorstep. Next we are probably going to start seeing all sorts of mobile apps make their way to steam (Have you seen greenlight lately?)...Heck we are probably start going to get free "Lite" versions of games as well.And im not just saying this because i saw an advertisement and jumped to conclusions, i saw first hand what a freemium deathtrap this game is. In fact, it's almost insulting how much of a freemium deathtrap this game is. This should never have surfaced to the pc. This belongs in the appstore for 9 year old to go crazy on spending their moms money. This game exists with the SOLE INTENTION of sucking every last hour and penny out of its player. It's strategically created to NEVER give the player the satisfaction they desire. It is  scientifically crafted to keep the user within an arms reach of recieving satisfaction at all time.. No matter how much you play this game it becomes very clear that the only way you will be able to sink your teeth into it is if you have 1. Hundreds of hours and a credit card locked and loaded.I purchased this game expecting it to be some quick and easy fun to get into without much hassle. And based on the way the game presented itself, i expected it to be a light weight simple RPG void of all the mundane and boring aspects of larger RPG games. I just thought it was going to be a cute small little RPG with fast leveling and simple perk choosing with quick and easy satisfaction.. NOPE.After just a short while of playing this game it becomes very clear that the only way you will ever get an ounce of satisfaction out of this game is if you invest THOUSANDS of hours and dollars into it.This is PC gaming folks, please open your eyes. Don't let this freemium app garbage invade our respectable PC community

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												Initially, i was very hyped about this game, Spent lot of hours playing it, back then game was recently released and i was aware that some bugs may occur. After devs released first DLC for Hero Siege everything went down to drain. Bugs that "should" be for people who bought dlc, somehow got into vanilla version and then couldn't unlock new difficulty levels, later that month one of the devs stated that they released patch which "will" fix this issue for vanilla version, but in the end turned out to be lies. Stopped playing and took huge break from Hero Siege but i did not delete game.Today i decided to return and enjoy it once more, during break i noticed bunch of frequent updates for Hero Siege. Hopped that they actually fixed issue i had. Launched game, saw some improvements, picked my hero and what i see, all ACTS are locked, i thought okay lets do it, beat ACT I, then started ACT II died at first mini boss, that is fine i still wanted to continue to play, since ACT I is completed you can choose to start from ACT II, but what the hell, game did not register ACT II, which means i have start from ACT I. These are same bugs all over again. I'm so fed up with Hero Siege and will stop support these devs, why? Because it's been year since i got it and it still feels like an Early Access game. I might change this review at some point, but right now it will be as it is.- INTRODUCTION:When The Binding of Isaac meets Diablo 2.- GAMEPLAY:Hero Siege still counts as Rogue like game which means is very brutal, at first you will die a lot and that is normal. Just as soon you will hit first few levels and can get to ACT I boss, then game gets more enjoyable. Choose between 8 playable heroes, each hero has their own unique skills.Every level is like arena and is divided by Acts, at the end of each Act you fight powerful boss.- IS THAT ALL?:Yes, as i meantioned above "when The Binding of Isaac meets Diablo 2. There is nothing more to be said.- OVERALL:Is it worth to buy Hero Siege? That depends, do you like to encounter obnoxious bugs every time you launch the game?

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
This review is very long, so skip to the conclusion if you're in a rush! Or you could read everything and know why I came to the conclusion I did.Hero Siege is a fun and wonderfully built game with appealing visuals and appealing music. Unfortunately, not all audio is as stunning as the epic tunes are, because the few voices sound like they were done by a couple people using Audacity to skew their voices to sound like different people, and the sound effects sound like they were done out of the mouth. It's not at all as bad as I'm probably making it sound, but the quality of the sound is no reason at all why you should turn away this game anyways, and allow me to explain why.This game has a steady and solid pace, magnificently enchanting to play at the speed it is, but of course you can change the difficulty. Starting out is the tough part, and even though you are taught mostly everything you should know, what you aren't taught is easily and quickly learned.This game is interesting in many ways. Once you die, you keep your character and the progress you've had with the character, but not your gold or items. You can choose from a set of classes when creating your character. As far as I can tell, the only things that are effected by the class you choose are the sets of powers you can achieve and upgrade, and your starting attributes. I did not see anything on the class select screen that showed you what class does what. Even then, you can level up whatever powers and attributes you'd like, with their respective points you gain after every level, allowing for you to play however you'd like! A great system for a great game.The maps aren't randomly generated, but the stuff inside them are. Once your epic journey is ended by a skeleton or a clay statue shooting beams at you, or a daring and death defying skid across spikes went awry, you'll know exactly what you've done wrong, and even though it was unfortunate and you'll have to start again from the beginning, you'll still be having fun. You'll be stronger this time around, since you keep your levels, and you'll easily be able to plow through the old enemies again, you'll quickly be where you were interrupted by death.In ConclusionIn the 1.3 hours that I've had with this game so far (as says the steam window), I've had epic and bloody fights with a colossal  eyeball, a mummified corpse with undying gaze, and some plain old rats, which still did not cease to be entertaining, for they all ended in a gory explosion of ribcages and blood scattered across my screen. Even when I died I knew exactly what I did wrong, and I made sure to fix my mistakes next time I got around to where I was.Pros:+ Appealing graphics+ Gameplay that could make Chuck Norris himself shed a tear, but only one because he's Chuck Norris.+ Very quick to learn+ Pick it up and play if you just want a quick game, just be sure not to get too involved or you'll be here for hours.+ Plenty of new monsters and items you'll be just finding out about even hours into the game.+ A lot of classes to pick from+ Most of the hats are references to games (Master Chief helmet, Payday mask, Minecraft head, Pyramid Head, Altair Hood)+ Simple yet complex+ Epic tunes+ There's a frog hat+ BUY THE GAME DUDE+ Fun gameplay+ Frog hatSide notes* Not sure how to get the gems/crystals to customize your character other than the random drop in game, which believe me, is not often. You start with 750 or so.* I saw a "redeem code" option in the settings menu. Not sure what the deal is with that.* The game has it's own font, which is super cool.Cons- Some of the audio's a bit "odd".- Have to make the trek back from where you died if you die, no matter how long it is, which can get tedious even if you one shot enemies- No character creation, just classesBuy this game. I was so surprised to see this magnificent game for only $5.99. I'm sure you'll hear this a lot, but trust me, this is the most true time you'll hear it: Buy this game, it's worth every penny. This is coming from a kid with no  job, it's the best purchase you'll have ever made on steam. Trust me. If you don't buy this game the next time it's on sale, then I'd be disappointed in you.Just screenshots from the game aren't enough to do it justice, see the game in action, buy it yourself.    tenouttaten![38.media.tumblr.com]

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												At first, I just bought this game because it was on halloween sale for about 1 buck. and trading cards :vFirst, you chose a class for your character, for me it's pirate. Then, you go to the game. Your character started with nothing. This can be pretty hard in the beginning until you level up a bit. The game divided into 6 waves each stage. After you cleared a wave, you got 30 seconds to prepare yourself. You can go to the dungeon and shop in this time. The shop and dungeon randomly generated on the map each time you cleared a stage. A shop requires silver key to open. When you died in the game, you can resume the game on the same wave with reduced HP. The key to clear this game is collecting the relics. The relics greatly boost your stats or give unique special effects, thus it's very important to get these relics. Relics can be obtained from chest (crystal chest has the higest chance to drop relics), clearing a stage, dungeon drop or from shop (usually obtainable for 1000 coins). Each time you level up, you get 2 stats point and a skill point. The objective of this game is to pass until the final wave. On the end of a stage (each 6 waves) you will face special bosses. Boss has special skills that will conduct after a specific time. Beating a boss is pretty easy if you have some relics with you. Pros :Great musicCrisp pixel graphic8 classes to chooseVariative skills and relic's effectsDiffrent difficulty to chooseCons :Online mode requires DLC to playGame turned out pretty easy after you collect the relicsCostumes are a bit hard to collect and some requires DLC to obtainI still reccomend this game even at it's full price.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Hero Siege is fun for short bursts, but gets incredibly repetitive after a while. Theres not really much to the gameplay besides main attack, use skills,use item and move away from the enemies. Insta-kill traps and OP bosses are incredibly irritating as well. Most of my sessions were either obtaining an OP relic and just mowing down enemies or sudden death from BS traps and there are a LOT of traps. Also,when you pick up a potion it has a random effect and there are potions that reduced my stats permanently or killed me abruptly which adds to the frustration factor. Subsequently, my main complaint is that this game has balancing issues. There was also a glitch I encountered where I was playing local co op and went only to wave 17 I saved and exit then when I went to play solo it had overridden my stage unlocks so I would have to do 80 waves to get to where I was before. However, a part of me still wants to play Hero Siege because at its core its fun, but its plethora of issues make me think twice.

number of helpful: 10 of 19 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												I got into Hero Siege last year close to its release on Steam after seeing a Twitch streamer play it. At the time it was a lot of fun and had great potential. After a few updates and the addition of 2 classes, the game reached its zenith for me. At the time it was an appropriate mix of skill, character progression, and hopefully a little rng luck. However with a little skill and some patience, you could usually win through a run even if you didnt get lucky with items. Then the Karp of Doom expansion came out. I'm not entirely sure what the exact changes were, but i recall attempting to play a game on Normal with my lvl 70 Necromancer (who had previously been in the middle of a good Hell difficulty run which was reset by the update) and i couldnt make it to the first boss due to getting 1-2 shot by traps or the "bombs" some enimies drop. I tried to stick with it and give it another chance every couple updates, maybe try multiplayer. To this day, i havn't been able to get a successful multiplayer game started and the game feels more and more RNG luck based. Chars have been nerfed into uselessness, and most of the whole game has been "rebalanced" to a degree that i would consider it a different game entirely. I've decided to retire the game indefinately and remember the fun it used to be.

number of helpful: 10 of 19 people (53%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												Definetly Worth It!Ok, there are some bad reviews.  However if you look at the big picture, I think they are unjustified. This game is definitely worth the price of admission! First, this isn't a huge developing house pushing out games and running with the cash after the release.This is a small ( 2-3 man ) dedicated team working on sharing their passion with the public.  Second, for the price and replay value, you would be very hard pressed to find a better game.  My logged time ( probably twice what is shown since I play off-line more -- limited internet ) is proof that I keep coming back for more.Third, bug resolution, they do get fixed.  Some may gripe about this and that ( I have done some myself in the heat of the moment - I think we all get a little hot headed when something in a game changes how we play it ) but things do get fixed and changed.The ultimate things to consider are these....Do you have someone or someway to give feedback? -->  Yes Will someone on the other end actually listen to and consider the feedback? -->  Yes Will said feedback be implemented if enough people agree? -->  Yes Does the Development Team  actually care about their product and you? -->  Yes If the answers are  Yes   to the above ( In this case they really are!  Honest Abe! ) then you have found a true GEM!

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												Wonderful game! I love it!At first I wasn't sure, but when I load it first time, it looks with very nice graphics and it is this kind of games that begging to be played!So, I start with Nomad (which is really good!) and then went through the first ACT. I died within 5 seconds I think. Then I tried again and again, but still dying very fast!Then I got it!! It is like the old good games! Run Run, then hit, then run run, then hit. I also figured out to use the traps to kill the enemies. That's it, everything else depends on how you move your character!Then I bought the DLCs which add/unlock some contents in the game. So far, it has been a wonderful experience. I don't have any problem with stability or control. I use xbox 360 controller with Windows 10 and a budget nVidia card (GTX 750). Anyway, there is maybe a bug when I played Nomad after updating the game with the DLCs. The enemy’s health was increasing when I hit them!!! But, it might be a curse as I touched the Demon statue! The gameplay is fantastic really. There are many differences between the characters and this affect the way of attacking and defence. It also has many variations of elements and enemies. Well, I don't know why some others rated it negatively but for me (and I'm not that good in action games! ) it is an excellent game and I didn't find it difficult at all, of course at Normal difficulty!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												I have played this game for a short while with friends and will try to make a concise review. Here it goes...This game reflects a few aspects from Diablo and The Binding of Isaac but without the complexity, skill or even a story which those have. My friends and I have crashed several times, once so badly that I lost all of my Relics; gear which is obtained from boses and the shop, and ceased spawing for me after that point. From what I hear, it's normal to die instantly for no apparent reason. I have also crashed for inexplicable reasons for simply running into an item the incorrect way.The in-game servers are horrid if you're trying to play with close friends. Lobbies decide to appear and re-appear when they feel like. Best to use Hamachi or Port-forward if you know how to do so.The art in this game feels uninspired and the music is decent; it fits the mood but often becomes background noise.The character model will often get buried under followers you obtain from bosess and also enemies, explosions, your own abilites, Allies (whom can push you around until you get flight) and hazards which often kill you in a few hits.The Devs clearly want to cash in with he amount of DLC they create and massive lack of bug fixes. That or their incompetence is to blame for the amount of glitches I have seen.---Stay away from this title unless you're bored or masochistic or want to gift this to an enemy.

												This game is lots of fun. I don't own any of the DLC, and I'm nowhere near finishing. It's tons of fun and great to play with friends. IF YOU CAN CONNECT. The server system is crap. You can't refresh the list, and sometimes servers just won't be there. Just today one of my friends and I spent 15 minutes: launching servers, relaunching the game, logging in and out of the system, relaunching servers and getting nowhere. If the servers were through Steam, it'd be much better, but it's all run through the company that owns the game. You can't invite people through Steam, or join. This makes it impossible to find them sometimes. Other than that, the game is great. Great little way to mix an item system like Isaac's and the theme of Diablo. It's great fun alone and tons of fun with friends, if you can find them.

												--- If it's on sale, give it a go. But be warned ---It seems this game has become a huge experiment for the developers. They change random things and then "patch" the changes when they realize something wasn't working with it. The player base has become the testers. With the type of no-research, random game-changing patches the devs are doing, this game should definitely be considered Early Access still.When I first played and bought the game and DLC it was fantastic. A friend and I played for hours together and enjoyed it a ton. I played multiplayer with random groups and had a great time leveling my character.Now, every time I play the game it is bugging out. Multiplayer and local coop both have all kinds of bugs where things aren't synced up for all players. The game randomly crashes (way too frequently). Players are dropped from party. Players load into different maps (one in town, one in dungeon, one in level, etc.)All of these kinds of things are CONSISTENTLY a problem with the game and have made it virtually unplayable in any multiplayer or coop capacity. The devs continue to put bandaids on old bugs and add random new things to the game that eventually become old bugs.It's truly sad. I think the game could be freaking amazing if the devs just sat down, wrote a GIGANTIC list of all of the past and current bugs that are still being talked about by players, and addressed ALL of them before continuing new development.I will continue to check back on this game, as I have been, from time to time to see if it has become a complete game. Sadly, it doesn't seem like that will become a reality.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												I would just like to thank PAS for helping me through anxiety and just hitting a nerve that is primal. Crack, nah. Heroine, s'aight. I have dreamt about this like it was Tetris. I have related this game to things in my life that really matter. All that aside....This is my favorite game of all time. It has so many subtle touches, when I play it I think I know what the heck is going on, trying to make sense out of the creative team of this game. I watched those guys live stream while they were tweaking some of the overall stats of the game. Just numbers to some but actually honing math to emulate other games. Not a copy, they capture the flow of some of the best out there. Diablo, Isaac, touch of Zelda. I don't know, delightful.There are some bad things. No story, repetitive, not the flashiest. Blah, blah. Who cares?If you feel like a great experience, buy this game. Side note, they ufcked us on the iOs version. It could be great, but the lack of updates, full abandonment of the product, and half-assing the MFi controls, which carried over from previous pc versions (I've spent more time trying to get this game to read a controller on my mac (pc even seems to glitch sometimes, probably my fault. Anyways it'd be nice to hear some accountability from somewhere.Anyways, its great. Deuces...[EDIT]: Support of ultra-wide resolution, perfect frame rate. Maybe just my set up, but visuals are incredible.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Hero Siege is an interesting game. On the surface it sounds great and makes a lot of sense but the further into it you delve the more mish-mash the whole experience becomes.Graphically the game is great. Characters are designed well and fit the atmosphere niceley, the enemies are well drawn and so are the background elements. Problem is.... the background elements are totally placed randomly throughout the maps (which are poorly designed in and of themselves) which make the levels feel really.... dead. Which is the most serious problem plaguing this game. Nothing about it feels immersive or engaging.The leveling system is a fun twist to the roguelike formula but pretty much means you'll get hammered by the hordes of enemies until you're strong enough to progress. And regardless of how many levels you gain you'll find traps and certain moves constant headaches since they can potentially one-shot you ruining a hundred+ wave game. Furthermore the skills and stats, although novel, feel tacked on and pointless. Your stat points strengthen your character really really slowly, and the skills don't really offer much customization. Sure you can invest in one skill over another but you really don't feel very unique doing so. Maybe if the characters progressed through branching classes or something you'd feel more invested in how you build your character but the current system leaves you wanting more.There are also LOADS of things on the screen that clutter up the experience. Enemies come at you in big clumps and frequently have abilities that leave so many particle effects on the screen that you feel like you're stuck in some sort of horrible particle effect nightmare.Progression in the game is extremely boring, as well. Wave after wave after wave without any change. Sure you can do the occasional dungeon but I feel like the dungeons are way more fun/interesting than the core gameplay.Hero Siege is like a tower defense game with no home base to protect. It is like an RPG without equipment, classes, and storyline. It is a roguelike without unlockable content, mish-mashed graphics, clunky+boring progression and replay value only for the truly dedicated.Not to mention the bugs. Thinking of playing co-op? forget it, for now. The co-op is completely clunky and broken. Online multiplayer has never worked for me so I can't tell if it is more fun than offline (I'm sure it is, if it would work).Having said all that... it is a fun game.I recommend playing this ONLY if you can get it on sale. The 5.99 price point doesn't seem like much but in its current state there are loads of issues with the game. The developers seem interested in fixing things but the list is so long, and the core gameplay so mind-numbingly boring, it may be a long time before we see this product turn into something truly awesome (though the potential is there).

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												The game is a pretty decent time killer, aside from the cheesy voice acting and bland writing of the dialogue, there is a lot about this game that irks me. Firstly, I don't have much respect for the fact that the leveling system is a direct rip off of Diablo II, I didn't really like it in D2 and I especially don't like a rip off of it. The games color pallete makes enemy attacks easily blend into the environment, which wouldn't be so bad if you didn't die in 4 hits, There is way too many things going on in the screen to allow the enemy attacks to not stand out very well. Even after completely stat dumping into armor I felt I was way too squishy, even in the early stages of the game. I also don't appreciate the fact that there is no invincibility frames to protect you from getting completely wiped because of a single mistake, due to creep damage or a marksman volley that lasts 7 seconds.One thing that is going to make me *really* want a refund is the fact that I can't revist a save after I exit out of the game, it gets locked and says "thou shalt not cheat", unless the game considers me taking a break wildy heinous and wants to completely block me from returning to a character that I just put 4 hours into. There are a few undefined things about this game that bother me, but I'm going to chalk those up to personal taste, this game gets a 3/10 from me.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												Have you played Rogue Legacy? 2D side-scrolling action-adventure RPG with perhaps the best rogue-like feature I've seen, alongside The Binding of Isaac.Now here we have Hero Siege. You choose one of 8 playable classes, with many talents to choose from. Relic system similar to The Binding of Isaac can yield buffs for your toon or spell doom for you enemies. Dungeons, crypts, and many other secrets await you in one of four acts, each with multiple stages that never play the same way twice. Buy temporary buffs from gold drops or use it to buy potions to get back in the fray with a renewed thirst for violence. The evil that rises from the lands needs to be dealt with; can you turn the tide of darkness and bring peace through the visceral slaughter of all who stand against you?Get this ♥♥♥♥ing game now, dammit. Multiplayer beta is out.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												This is a nice casual past-time, looks like a top-down shooter, but you are confined to a single area and have to fight waves of enemies in order to progress. The game has easy controls that can be mapped, with seperate keys for movement, and another set for shooting (in all directions) so you can for example walk to the left but shoot to the right or downwards. You also can use a couple of specials which are unique per character. These are unlocked as you progress character level. When you die, you keep the character level. This works like in Rogue Legacy and other similar games.The downside of this system is, that for a long while you have to be grinding without making any significant progress. I had to level up my character to around level 18 before I could get past the second boss, ie. wave 12. But after that things went a bit faster. The enemy damage scales with your character level, but the enemies do not. So you can steamroll a couple of levels later on, as long as you avoind being hit.I can recommend the game for a quick in-between, but the grind can be a bit frustrating at times. :6.5/10:

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Hero Siege PC –“If Diablo & Binding of Isaac made love, this would be the result”By Joshua Alexander – R Alexis WolfeThe first thing you will notice about Panic Art Studios Hero Siege is that it is saturated in tons of video game, pop culture, and movie references. The flies from Binding of Isaac, Various recreations of famous Diablo & Diablo 3 monsters just to name a few. Navigating the menu is simple either on keyboard and mouse or XBOX 360 controller. The options are limited as this is a “Retro” inspired game. You can change from full screen to windowed as well as tweak the graphics settings and resolution, and sound volumes. Upon pressing start you are asked to pick a character slot and choose a class. Each class has its plus and minuses, which a little play time, will have you figuring out your favorite fast.  Once you create and name your character you will be sent to the act/difficulty selection screen. Normal of course will be the only choice for starting followed by later difficulties being unlocked upon completion of the game.  For anyone expecting a AAA 3D APRG you will be disappointed. The sprites are all lovingly hand created, as well as the sound FX and Music. I found myself really enjoying the music as I battled endless waves of rats, undead minions and angry mages, only to run headfirst into the first randomly picked boss a floating eyeball. Bosses act like your typical raid boss as in they have special abilities and phases and a large life pool. With proper dodging and attacking you can win. Killing the final wave boss rewards you with a ton of gold and a new relic, which players of Binding of Isaac will be familiar with. Levels seem to be randomly generated from a pool of available layouts and the game is great for a quick pick up and play, Long time enjoyment is not a problem either but I can see this getting stale if you try to marathon it to completion. Simply put this is a game you pick up to kill a bunch of monsters spill a bunch of blood and feel better about yourself. And oh there is blood TONS of it. In fact so much blood is in this game that even the boxes bleed and explode into bloody chunks. I did find myself wondering why the hell the boxes bled but I laughed it off as this game is meant to be humorous anyways. With free copies available on the google and apple stores, as well as a currently discounted PC port on steam you can’t go wrong with picking this up. For those playing it on steam it comes with the favorite achievements and trading cards. No excuse to get this and support indie developers. If you are afraid of this becoming another early access DayZ issue you will be okay as the Developer regularly works on this and patches it.  So that brings us to the last part Bugs/issues. From my gameplay time I only noticed a couple non game breaking bugs, the first being that sometimes the character will refuse to attack and just run around doing no damage. This was solved by logging out of the game and restarting it. The second was not a bug but more of a design flaw in my opinion. The UI scales very well on larger screens but the HUD takes up a large portion of the playing field and led to several deaths for me. Maybe implementation of a Scaling option for the UI in the options menu could solve this? All in all I give this an 8.5/10 with most likely the upcoming DLC bringing it to a full 9! Thanks for reading and support the Developers in all their projects!  check out a 10 minute gameplay video here: https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?v=4415977854790&l=7195181521437868516

Because the first game is not getting content updates anymore!

												Being a fast-paced run, dodge and hit-game, Hero Siege does almost anything right it has to. I picked it up a while ago and thought I'd really have to look into it. Leveling up unlocks various skills to upgrade your character and you can find some pretty nice weapons and trinkets. The game is always fair, you always know what you are up against or why you just died with the controls being very simple. All this together makes for an awesome amound of fun and the "This time I'm gonan get one level further" works pretty well.8/10 easily achieved!

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Hero Siege PC –“If Diablo & Binding of Isaac made love, this would be the result”By Joshua Alexander – R Alexis WolfeThe first thing you will notice about Panic Art Studios Hero Siege is that it is saturated in tons of video game, pop culture, and movie references. The flies from Binding of Isaac, Various recreations of famous Diablo & Diablo 3 monsters just to name a few. Navigating the menu is simple either on keyboard and mouse or XBOX 360 controller. The options are limited as this is a “Retro” inspired game. You can change from full screen to windowed as well as tweak the graphics settings and resolution, and sound volumes. Upon pressing start you are asked to pick a character slot and choose a class. Each class has its plus and minuses, which a little play time, will have you figuring out your favorite fast.  Once you create and name your character you will be sent to the act/difficulty selection screen. Normal of course will be the only choice for starting followed by later difficulties being unlocked upon completion of the game.  For anyone expecting a AAA 3D APRG you will be disappointed. The sprites are all lovingly hand created, as well as the sound FX and Music. I found myself really enjoying the music as I battled endless waves of rats, undead minions and angry mages, only to run headfirst into the first randomly picked boss a floating eyeball. Bosses act like your typical raid boss as in they have special abilities and phases and a large life pool. With proper dodging and attacking you can win. Killing the final wave boss rewards you with a ton of gold and a new relic, which players of Binding of Isaac will be familiar with. Levels seem to be randomly generated from a pool of available layouts and the game is great for a quick pick up and play, Long time enjoyment is not a problem either but I can see this getting stale if you try to marathon it to completion. Simply put this is a game you pick up to kill a bunch of monsters spill a bunch of blood and feel better about yourself. And oh there is blood TONS of it. In fact so much blood is in this game that even the boxes bleed and explode into bloody chunks. I did find myself wondering why the hell the boxes bled but I laughed it off as this game is meant to be humorous anyways. With free copies available on the google and apple stores, as well as a currently discounted PC port on steam you can’t go wrong with picking this up. For those playing it on steam it comes with the favorite achievements and trading cards. No excuse to get this and support indie developers. If you are afraid of this becoming another early access DayZ issue you will be okay as the Developer regularly works on this and patches it.  So that brings us to the last part Bugs/issues. From my gameplay time I only noticed a couple non game breaking bugs, the first being that sometimes the character will refuse to attack and just run around doing no damage. This was solved by logging out of the game and restarting it. The second was not a bug but more of a design flaw in my opinion. The UI scales very well on larger screens but the HUD takes up a large portion of the playing field and led to several deaths for me. Maybe implementation of a Scaling option for the UI in the options menu could solve this? All in all I give this an 8.5/10 with most likely the upcoming DLC bringing it to a full 9! Thanks for reading and support the Developers in all their projects!  check out a 10 minute gameplay video here: https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?v=4415977854790&l=7195181521437868516

												Overall the game deserves a 9.5/10:Why? Because it's a really enjoyable experience and a frustrating one at the same time, also a + because in a way it reminds me of Diablo. It's a top-down rogue-like experience that I really enjoy and anyone that likes a rogue-like from time to time or all the time will also enjoy. Great overall experience, really fun to play, can keep you entertained for hours so watch the clock when you play. And as I said, I give it a 9.5/10 because I fell in love with the game the first time I played.Would I recommend it? Yes.Is it worth the money? Definitely.Is the DLC any good? If you want more hats and a new class the it is.And another plus side is that multiplayer is being developed for the game so soon (or not that soon) you will be able to kill spiders, rats, tree ents, weird eye things and much more with friends. Do yourself a favour and buy the game.Also did I mention that the game is in a pixelart style? If thats your thing then even better.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												Have you played Rogue Legacy? 2D side-scrolling action-adventure RPG with perhaps the best rogue-like feature I've seen, alongside The Binding of Isaac.Now here we have Hero Siege. You choose one of 8 playable classes, with many talents to choose from. Relic system similar to The Binding of Isaac can yield buffs for your toon or spell doom for you enemies. Dungeons, crypts, and many other secrets await you in one of four acts, each with multiple stages that never play the same way twice. Buy temporary buffs from gold drops or use it to buy potions to get back in the fray with a renewed thirst for violence. The evil that rises from the lands needs to be dealt with; can you turn the tide of darkness and bring peace through the visceral slaughter of all who stand against you?Get this ♥♥♥♥ing game now, dammit. Multiplayer beta is out.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												I used to really enjoy this game, a bullet hell brawler with punishing difficulty but not too long ago I loaded up my lvl 150 pyro to find they've changed the game so much that I don't find it fun anymore.It used to be that loot dropped and you would have to either wait until the end of the wave(s) to decide whether to equip it or do it during battle.  Instinct told you whether an item was better and you would quickly press A or B to decide.  Now you pick up equipment, it's placed into storage and have to go through a tedious process of deciding whether to equip or sell it.  In theory this would work well except that the loot screen doesn't tell you the full stats for the item, some attributes are missing rendering the whole thing moot.  Also money in the game only has use in the shop so selling items is pretty much pointless since you get enough of it during the waves.The change to have an energy bar has destroyed your talents.  Instead of being on a cooldown timer they now have an energy cost and all draw from the same pool.  I can see that they are trying to go for "carefully pick which one to use at the right time" but in reality it means that you only try and use your strongest attack the other 3 are useless.  For a pyro this means you get 2 hydras and then have to wait ages to get another as the energy bar slowly refills.  Enemies will sometimes drop energy pills that refill the bar a little but there is so much flak on screen it's difficult to get to them.You can still get insta-killed by acid spitters and other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t one hits which is the reason why I stopped playing the game in the first place.Everything seems to be a lot easier as well, even with limited hydras I can still trigger all waves and get through with no hassle.The problem is that this seems to be change for the sake of it but it's still buggy and not well balanced.  There are still times when I wonder what killed me.  The relics still aren't explained.  Keys still drop far too infrequently.  Bosses are still way too easy (I haven't checked if you can still farm them by save scumming).  The energy system is a needless addition that prevents you from having "oh♥♥♥♥♥♥oh♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; moments that spamming buttons gets you out of, it has also made useless 3 of your talents. The new loot mechanics are buggy, needless and add little.  You still can't have local multiple player on multiple monitors (so you can push each other off the screen).  Potions are still a hit and miss affair.  You still get killed by the environment more than enemies and the core game I originally enjoyed has gone.And wtf is a wormhole???  The game could explain these things a LOT better.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												I love this game. It's a fun, arcade-style roguelike-ish, quasi-twin-stick amalgamation of genres and styles that blends together very, very well. Like others, I was unimpressed at first, but something kept calling me back to the game. I cannot recall (nor find in my email) where I purchased this game, but I'm sure it was a promotion through Steam or an indie site. A gamble that paid off, I found a game that hooked me and kept me coming back. I bought a copy, full price, for a friend of mine. I sang its praises and told him we need to play multiplayer.Well, as you've probably come to find out, multiplayer is a DLC only option (even though it's a main-menu selection). We found that out the hard way, and then I felt like a chump for buying and gifting the game. Any customer experience that leaves the buyer feeling like a chump is just a bad way to do business. I like the game, but don't recommend supporting practices such as these. I'd expect a terrible experience from EA (or similar), but to get the same from a small indie dev is disheartening.

												I used to really enjoy this game, a bullet hell brawler with punishing difficulty but not too long ago I loaded up my lvl 150 pyro to find they've changed the game so much that I don't find it fun anymore.It used to be that loot dropped and you would have to either wait until the end of the wave(s) to decide whether to equip it or do it during battle.  Instinct told you whether an item was better and you would quickly press A or B to decide.  Now you pick up equipment, it's placed into storage and have to go through a tedious process of deciding whether to equip or sell it.  In theory this would work well except that the loot screen doesn't tell you the full stats for the item, some attributes are missing rendering the whole thing moot.  Also money in the game only has use in the shop so selling items is pretty much pointless since you get enough of it during the waves.The change to have an energy bar has destroyed your talents.  Instead of being on a cooldown timer they now have an energy cost and all draw from the same pool.  I can see that they are trying to go for "carefully pick which one to use at the right time" but in reality it means that you only try and use your strongest attack the other 3 are useless.  For a pyro this means you get 2 hydras and then have to wait ages to get another as the energy bar slowly refills.  Enemies will sometimes drop energy pills that refill the bar a little but there is so much flak on screen it's difficult to get to them.You can still get insta-killed by acid spitters and other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t one hits which is the reason why I stopped playing the game in the first place.Everything seems to be a lot easier as well, even with limited hydras I can still trigger all waves and get through with no hassle.The problem is that this seems to be change for the sake of it but it's still buggy and not well balanced.  There are still times when I wonder what killed me.  The relics still aren't explained.  Keys still drop far too infrequently.  Bosses are still way too easy (I haven't checked if you can still farm them by save scumming).  The energy system is a needless addition that prevents you from having "oh♥♥♥♥♥♥oh♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; moments that spamming buttons gets you out of, it has also made useless 3 of your talents. The new loot mechanics are buggy, needless and add little.  You still can't have local multiple player on multiple monitors (so you can push each other off the screen).  Potions are still a hit and miss affair.  You still get killed by the environment more than enemies and the core game I originally enjoyed has gone.And wtf is a wormhole???  The game could explain these things a LOT better.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												The game is a pretty decent time killer, aside from the cheesy voice acting and bland writing of the dialogue, there is a lot about this game that irks me. Firstly, I don't have much respect for the fact that the leveling system is a direct rip off of Diablo II, I didn't really like it in D2 and I especially don't like a rip off of it. The games color pallete makes enemy attacks easily blend into the environment, which wouldn't be so bad if you didn't die in 4 hits, There is way too many things going on in the screen to allow the enemy attacks to not stand out very well. Even after completely stat dumping into armor I felt I was way too squishy, even in the early stages of the game. I also don't appreciate the fact that there is no invincibility frames to protect you from getting completely wiped because of a single mistake, due to creep damage or a marksman volley that lasts 7 seconds.One thing that is going to make me *really* want a refund is the fact that I can't revist a save after I exit out of the game, it gets locked and says "thou shalt not cheat", unless the game considers me taking a break wildy heinous and wants to completely block me from returning to a character that I just put 4 hours into. There are a few undefined things about this game that bother me, but I'm going to chalk those up to personal taste, this game gets a 3/10 from me.

Do yourself a favour and buy the game.Also did I mention that the game is in a pixelart style? If thats your thing then even better.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
This game is frequently updated by the developers based on community feedback (that's a good thing), so this review is based on version 1.0.7.1 of the game.Hero Siege is an excellent time-killer. Twin-stick, randomly-generated, Roguelike gameplay with 5+ classes, customization, dozens of special items to find in dungeons for extra power... It scatches so many game itches for those of us who enjoy some action RPG (light RPG, mind you) fun. The basis of the game is fighting off wave after wave of enemies, leveling up as you do so and obtaining items of power (relics) on a periodic basis. This game screams for a gamepad; you move in eight directions and shoot in four independent directions, while also activating items, allocating stats at level and buying from shops. I don't want to imagine doing that on a keyboard.Like a true Roguelike, there's no telling what you'll get with each area. Maps are generated randomly; you might be under constant assault by traps (which you can lure monsters into), have a maze of trees to navigare through, find a bounty of loot chests, or all sorts of other scenarios. There are over 100 relics right now to find in the game, and each provides either a significant stat boost or a special ability to your character. It's complete luck of the draw what you get, and the developers were gutsy enough to put in some truly unbalanced items, such as relics that give you the ability to fly over open air and water, staying completely out of the range of many enemies. No game played is a waste; if you die, you'll lose all the relics you've collected, but can restart with all the levels your character has amassed (except in the perma-death Hardcore mode.)Miniboss and legendary versions of regular enemies show up on a regular basis and every sixth wave, you'll fight a boss creature; success takes you to a new area (and often rewards you with a relic.) There are four "Acts" to the game, with apparently more to come, and 5 classes to try out and level up, also apparently with more to come. The game supports some sort of local multiplayer right now, but I have only done single-player mode. I can imagine that getting 2-4 people going on the same game would be a hilarious blast.The bottom line is that there's a lot of variety in this little title. The repetitve wipe-em-out nature of the game might not be for everyone, but I've already put in 12+ hours on a single class type, and that's more "fun" time than I've gotten out of many AAA titles at three times the price or more.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												What could have been a very fun game is ruined by cheap (or simply bad) design. Hero siege is littered with cheap shots. Traps and turrets dealing 2/3 to 100% of your health in damage. Certain mobs spawning impossible to dodge traps. Some dungeons spawning with diagonal corridords yet you can only shoot in 4 directions. Other times you will find an item early that lets you one-shot almost everything and you will get very far until you get one-shot by something you didn't see coming. Altogether the game is more frustrating than fun. It would be fun for a free game, but I wouldn't say its worth the asking price.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												Hero Siege suprised me. It was better than expected. Some of the negative reviews put me off, but I'm glad I tried it anyway.When starting playing Hero Siege I died a lot. Most of the times it was an instant death with not even a clue what just happened. After a while however you leveled enough to with stand those blows. It's a pity that you need to go through this initial builiding of your character but otherwise it's fantastic. The game involves some basic 4 directional combat. Depending on the character you choose it will be shooting or slashing. If you look at the achievements you will see the archer is the most popular. This is also the character I used to complete the game i.e. play through the 4 acts (without DLC).For a game that looks like it's from the 90's, it is actually great fun. Not a lot of games in this segment make me want to play them longer then an hour or two. This game is a positive exception.7/10
