number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												Hero Siege has some of the worst try-hard voice actors in a video game i have ever heard. It's super cringy, the characters say stupid cringy stuff and i wish they could have skipped the voice acting in general. The sound is awful, i know this game is trying to be old school and it kind of get what it is doing on some points. But the sound is way more awful then i would have imagined. The music is mediocre.However, the pixel art is superb and i kinda get this "Habbo" feeling when i look at this game. Not that the game is like Habbo, it's far from, but the pixel art is just as cool and accurate like Habbos art style. The game is repetetive but fun. You kill enemies, gain perk points, level up, get new gear and abbilities and the hub area really makes this game feel like some online game from the early 2000. However, the levels are boring since it is pretty much just wave based gameplay with small dungeons you can find where you can earn some sweet lot for completing puzzle and stuff like that. Even the many areas of levels there is to explore, it is still pretty much the same, over and over again. The "Free" characters are pretty boring. However you can buy dlc packs with other characters, yeeyyyyyyyyyy.....And the game is mostly just the same throughout the time you spend on it.However, there are now seasons with new stuff coming to the game, like more boring quests(like finding 20 snowballs for a snowman) and some sweet stuff.The game is mediocre, online is fun. Buy this game for a lower price if you have the chance.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Hero Siege is an interesting game. On the surface it sounds great and makes a lot of sense but the further into it you delve the more mish-mash the whole experience becomes.Graphically the game is great. Characters are designed well and fit the atmosphere niceley, the enemies are well drawn and so are the background elements. Problem is.... the background elements are totally placed randomly throughout the maps (which are poorly designed in and of themselves) which make the levels feel really.... dead. Which is the most serious problem plaguing this game. Nothing about it feels immersive or engaging.The leveling system is a fun twist to the roguelike formula but pretty much means you'll get hammered by the hordes of enemies until you're strong enough to progress. And regardless of how many levels you gain you'll find traps and certain moves constant headaches since they can potentially one-shot you ruining a hundred+ wave game. Furthermore the skills and stats, although novel, feel tacked on and pointless. Your stat points strengthen your character really really slowly, and the skills don't really offer much customization. Sure you can invest in one skill over another but you really don't feel very unique doing so. Maybe if the characters progressed through branching classes or something you'd feel more invested in how you build your character but the current system leaves you wanting more.There are also LOADS of things on the screen that clutter up the experience. Enemies come at you in big clumps and frequently have abilities that leave so many particle effects on the screen that you feel like you're stuck in some sort of horrible particle effect nightmare.Progression in the game is extremely boring, as well. Wave after wave after wave without any change. Sure you can do the occasional dungeon but I feel like the dungeons are way more fun/interesting than the core gameplay.Hero Siege is like a tower defense game with no home base to protect. It is like an RPG without equipment, classes, and storyline. It is a roguelike without unlockable content, mish-mashed graphics, clunky+boring progression and replay value only for the truly dedicated.Not to mention the bugs. Thinking of playing co-op? forget it, for now. The co-op is completely clunky and broken. Online multiplayer has never worked for me so I can't tell if it is more fun than offline (I'm sure it is, if it would work).Having said all that... it is a fun game.I recommend playing this ONLY if you can get it on sale. The 5.99 price point doesn't seem like much but in its current state there are loads of issues with the game. The developers seem interested in fixing things but the list is so long, and the core gameplay so mind-numbingly boring, it may be a long time before we see this product turn into something truly awesome (though the potential is there).

content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
This game is frequently updated by the developers based on community feedback (that's a good thing), so this review is based on version 1.0.7.1 of the game.Hero Siege is an excellent time-killer. Twin-stick, randomly-generated, Roguelike gameplay with 5+ classes, customization, dozens of special items to find in dungeons for extra power... It scatches so many game itches for those of us who enjoy some action RPG (light RPG, mind you) fun. The basis of the game is fighting off wave after wave of enemies, leveling up as you do so and obtaining items of power (relics) on a periodic basis. This game screams for a gamepad; you move in eight directions and shoot in four independent directions, while also activating items, allocating stats at level and buying from shops. I don't want to imagine doing that on a keyboard.Like a true Roguelike, there's no telling what you'll get with each area. Maps are generated randomly; you might be under constant assault by traps (which you can lure monsters into), have a maze of trees to navigare through, find a bounty of loot chests, or all sorts of other scenarios. There are over 100 relics right now to find in the game, and each provides either a significant stat boost or a special ability to your character. It's complete luck of the draw what you get, and the developers were gutsy enough to put in some truly unbalanced items, such as relics that give you the ability to fly over open air and water, staying completely out of the range of many enemies. No game played is a waste; if you die, you'll lose all the relics you've collected, but can restart with all the levels your character has amassed (except in the perma-death Hardcore mode.)Miniboss and legendary versions of regular enemies show up on a regular basis and every sixth wave, you'll fight a boss creature; success takes you to a new area (and often rewards you with a relic.) There are four "Acts" to the game, with apparently more to come, and 5 classes to try out and level up, also apparently with more to come. The game supports some sort of local multiplayer right now, but I have only done single-player mode. I can imagine that getting 2-4 people going on the same game would be a hilarious blast.The bottom line is that there's a lot of variety in this little title. The repetitve wipe-em-out nature of the game might not be for everyone, but I've already put in 12+ hours on a single class type, and that's more "fun" time than I've gotten out of many AAA titles at three times the price or more.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												This game is incredibly fun. Infuriatingly fun actually. The infuriating part? I'd wager it's the #1 glitchiest, buggiest, poorly designed game on all of steam, with the all-time worst UI I have ever encountered in any software application, game or otherwise, in all of my life. I mean, it's *impressive* how bad the UI is. Whoever the developers are, let me know what drugs you're on so I can try some.Still, would recommend, because the many, many, many bugs do not actually stop you from progressing, and you can play around the utterly horrendous design choices (No confirmation prompt for portal/ladder? Are you serious?!).Dying isn't the most frustrating thing about this game, oh no. Just wait until a Satanic weapon drops directly on top of the exit portal because the boss you're fighting doesn't move. Then you get to stare at it, knowing it's just out of reach. Taunting you. Laughing at you. And then, after several solemn minutes contemplating uninstalling, you step through the portal, and continue to grind. An empty, broken shell of the man you once were.I'm so triggered.

Posted: September 24, 2014
												Being a fast-paced run, dodge and hit-game, Hero Siege does almost anything right it has to. I picked it up a while ago and thought I'd really have to look into it. That was an awesome decision! The game is pure fun! You create your character and start killing monsters. Leveling up unlocks various skills to upgrade your character and you can find some pretty nice weapons and trinkets. The game is always fair, you always know what you are up against or why you just died with the controls being very simple. All this together makes for an awesome amound of fun and the "This time I'm gonan get one level further" works pretty well.8/10 easily achieved!

number of helpful: 17 of 34 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												THIS REVIEW HAS BEEN EDITED SINCE MY ORIGINAL RESPONSE, PLEASE LOOK BELOW:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------NEW REVIEW:Alright, so I don't nessecarily do reviews much, but having been bored and looking for stuff to play, I thought I'd give a game like Hero Siege another chance. I didn't see that I actually recieved a reply from one of the two developers as well, so let me go ahead and give another fairer review of it. My original score was a 0/10 on the claim that I wanted multiplayer and when I purchased it, it turns out mutliplayer wasn't even in the game, then over a year later it was in an early release and it turns out you had to pay for it. Please allow me to look at this over again:Hero Siege, as you can tell by my small amount of time playing it, is not nessecarily fun. Its an OKAY time-killer at best, using simplistic mechanics. Its very easy to get into which is nice, but upon purchase of the game you are not given everything thats inside the game; and this isn't the kind of game that warrants DLC. You get thrown into different arenas and fight varying mobs that tend to charge you head on or try to shoot at you - you dodge and fight back, simple stuff. I can't nessecarily speak for multiplayer because even though I have friends who own this game, no one wants to play it. The art is decent, it all stays within its style, and it looks like someone's first shot at making a video game- that being said it is impressive for what it is, but its nothing new or groundbreaking and should just give you access to the entirety of the game at one simple low price rather than having DLC and/or microtransactions.Buy it if you can get it for under a dollar, get a 4-pack, make ONE night of it, then never play it again probably.SCORE: 3/10

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												Post release, the core game was abandoned.  It's still buggy as hell.  The display is a mess, with items and text constantly pushing outside of the frames.  Power creep was never addressed.  The game becomes an endless grind, and is basically worthless without the ~$25 worth of DLC.  Even then, the devs have never bothered to polish and bug fix beyond what is absolutely necessary to keep the game running.  It sucks, because the gameplay itself is wonderful.  The awful programming and lack of polish will seriously leave you pulling your hair out.Also, my original review for this game has mysteriously disappeared.  No clue why.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												TL;DR-Best randomization I have ever seen-4 Classes w/ talent trees-4 acts-Fairly difficult, but rewarding-High replayabilitySo far this game is very fun.  It looks very simple at face value, but I can assure you that it is not!  Hero Siege is not unlike many other rogue/rpg games like Rogue Legacy or Bindings of Isaac, but it does a much better job at making a super fung game.  Hero Siege has much more, and better randomization than the other games in its genre that I have played.  The classes in this game have quite a bit of depth to them when compared to other games as well.  Overall the game has the randomness that you would expect, and the depth that you would desire from the genre this game falls into.  I highly recommend this game if you enjoy arpgs like Diablo or Marvel heroes, or games like Rogue Legacy and Binding of Isaac.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												What could have been a very fun game is ruined by cheap (or simply bad) design. Hero siege is littered with cheap shots. Traps and turrets dealing 2/3 to 100% of your health in damage. Certain mobs spawning impossible to dodge traps. Some dungeons spawning with diagonal corridords yet you can only shoot in 4 directions. Other times you will find an item early that lets you one-shot almost everything and you will get very far until you get one-shot by something you didn't see coming. Altogether the game is more frustrating than fun. It would be fun for a free game, but I wouldn't say its worth the asking price.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Gotta say the fact that something as essential (Essential for this kind of game anyway) as MULTIPLAYER is a payed for DLC is utter nonsense. I repeat! You Have to BUY ONLINE MULTIPLAYER as a seperate DLC. I see now why "Multiplayer" isn't included in the tags.Now, on to my (admitttedly limited) experience with the game:It was okay I guess. Nothing really grabbed my attention. The graphics were nice enough, the controls worked, the enemies kind of wandered towards me as I kited them all to death with little trouble at all. I found that my abilities had trouble acitvating however. Many times I'd press the button (even 2 or 3 times) and nothing would happen. The ability icon would be in full colour, but it just wouldn't activate.Eventually I reached the first boss and that's where this games shortcomings really brought themselves out. The boss was this armless zombie who spawned swarms of flies and threw giant spike balls. Sounds interesting in concept, but the execution was rather poorly done. 1) The swarms of flies are constantly moving towards me which results in a constant wall between me and the boss and he always spawns more as soon as I clear a swarm.2) The flies each have a noticable amount of health. They are not as easy to clear as you'd think flies would be.3) Every time he attacked, And I do mean EVERY TIME he attacked, the boss would speak one of his 3-4 sayings. And with his neverending wall of flies you can imagine that those lines would get repetitive.4) Eventually the flies started spawning with elemental enhancements which didn't seem like a problem at first, until one fly touched me and I was frozen and then instagibbed by the swarms.5) I levelled up like, 7-10 times just on those flies alone, in like, a few minutes. To me there's something wrong with a boss fight if the minions He's spawning are strong enough to warrant that much of a reward.TLDR: 1) Visuals and music are nice           2) Controls work for the most part           3) You have to BUY ONLINE MULTIPLAYER           4) Bosses can be frustrating to fight           5) Character sayings get annoying           6) Can't shoot diagonally           7) Get's pretty old really fast

												Most of the classes in this game are horrible.  The skills either dont do any damage, have long cooldowns, or both. Have fun running around in circles just so you can line enemies up to attack them if your ranged.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												Alright, so this is a special review, and I'm gonna ask you guys to read it to the end before dropping any ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t on me. A good friend of mine gifted me this game like 2 days ago, and I actually like the game. It has some flaws, like the random nature of Roguelike games for example, but it's not a terrible experience. So, why do I NOT recommend it? Easy.The game is a rip-off. And I'm not saying that like "it copies the concept and gameplay of other games". That would been aceptable IF the game is good. What I mean, is that the game quite literally uses assets from other games. I can accept using the Diablo font, for example, since the game IS a parody of Diablo. What I CAN'T accept, is that the game uses an INSANE amount of sprites taken directly from games such as The Binding of Isaac. And unless it's proven otherwise, they did NOT ask for permission, because that would be like asking the Bank manager for the keys of his Safe-lock.I usually ♥♥♥♥♥ about games having ♥♥♥♥♥♥ bugs, glitches or being lazy, but taking assets from other games and using them in your own TO THEN SELL A GAME WITH THEM, is STEALING the effort of other people, and getting paid for it.And it's sad, really. I was going to give the game a positive review, but then I noticed all the stolen sprites. I'm still gonna play it, don't get me wrong... But why they stole all of that, is a mystery that goes beyond my mind right now.EDIT: I discovered some extra stuff yesterday, and I also forgot some others. I'll keep it short:-Controller support seems to be random. I have a Xbox360 controller, a PS4 controller, and a random other controller that was cheap as hell and works at times. Weird enough, you have to select what kind of controlls you want in the Controls option screen, but the game doesn't recognize ANY of them.-The game has just too many grinding. I can understand that in games such as Disgaea, but here it gets boring quite fast.-Remember that I talked about the randomness of Roguelike games before? Well, screw that. This game goes beyond. What do I mean? I've faced multiple times already some unfair stuff, 2 of the 4 times, I had a LVL3-5 character on the first stage, and for no reason an enemy with arround 60k HP appears, and kills me in one hit. Difficulty should not mean "Of 9001 tries, you might win a stage once".-While the controls with a keyboard are okay, it feels weird. You attack with the arrows, while moving with WASD. Why not making your character face somewhere with the mouse, and attacking with it? Would been better, on my oppinion.-The game kind of drops you into it without any explanation at all. You have to select a character from 10 or so, and it doesn't tell you what each one does, you have to look it up on the Internet. The game doesn't then tell you where you have to go. At first I though I had to talk with NPC's for quests, but turns out ALL of the NPC's in town just trade some stuff on crystals, an ingame currency. I don't like tutorials, but the game should at least give some indications of what you're supposed to do.-Tried the multiplayer once, and I will never do it again. Why? Tried it 10 times in a row, NOONE of them ever worked.I'm kind of glad I didn't buy the game, it was a gift... But I feel bad for the friend who bought it to me. He though I would fall in love with it. Kind of sad to see potential go to waste. I hope tough, that they make a sequel at some point, with all of this stuff fixed. And please, don't "take" so much inspiration from other sources next time, try to make it more original. Diablo parodies are nice, but I rather play something refreshing, with some innovation.

												Can't reasonably recommend the game. The game has amazing potential, but I'm not convinced it will ever get there. The development team is small, and is very focused on releasing DLC for the game. While the DLC adds new content, the game is full of bugs. Some modes like multiplayer are pseudo unplayable. You can play a few levels, maybe you'll get a few hours in, then you'll run into a boss or something that will crash you, and there isnt anything you can do about it. Also at the time of this post, strange errors happen with damage scaling of people who join games in multiplayer. The Devs admit that the game isn't polished yet, and they hope to get it there one day, but they really need to focus less on additional content. But unfortunately there isn't much money in it.  Lastly, I perused the forum quite a bit to get an answer to some of the bugs in the game, or report them myself, and see if devs were working on them. Quite a number of the responses were abrasive from a member of the development team.

number of helpful: 17 of 34 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												THIS REVIEW HAS BEEN EDITED SINCE MY ORIGINAL RESPONSE, PLEASE LOOK BELOW:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------NEW REVIEW:Alright, so I don't nessecarily do reviews much, but having been bored and looking for stuff to play, I thought I'd give a game like Hero Siege another chance. I didn't see that I actually recieved a reply from one of the two developers as well, so let me go ahead and give another fairer review of it. My original score was a 0/10 on the claim that I wanted multiplayer and when I purchased it, it turns out mutliplayer wasn't even in the game, then over a year later it was in an early release and it turns out you had to pay for it. Please allow me to look at this over again:Hero Siege, as you can tell by my small amount of time playing it, is not nessecarily fun. Its an OKAY time-killer at best, using simplistic mechanics. Its very easy to get into which is nice, but upon purchase of the game you are not given everything thats inside the game; and this isn't the kind of game that warrants DLC. You get thrown into different arenas and fight varying mobs that tend to charge you head on or try to shoot at you - you dodge and fight back, simple stuff. I can't nessecarily speak for multiplayer because even though I have friends who own this game, no one wants to play it. The art is decent, it all stays within its style, and it looks like someone's first shot at making a video game- that being said it is impressive for what it is, but its nothing new or groundbreaking and should just give you access to the entirety of the game at one simple low price rather than having DLC and/or microtransactions.Buy it if you can get it for under a dollar, get a 4-pack, make ONE night of it, then never play it again probably.SCORE: 3/10

content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												Fantastic game, takes me right back to childhood and gives me and my brother a really fun game to play online.Single player this is great, I haven't seen any bugs and its a thoroughly enjoyable hack and slash game defeating waves of monsters/completing dungeons/finding treasure forts etc - sort of a like a really cartoony diablo but it's easily a game in its own right.Multiplayer I experienced many bugs over the few months I've played online with my brother (not tried couch co-op but this option is available) however the developers are easy to contact and WANT to fix these bugs and have fixed many of them over the last few months. Right now the online multiplayer is in open beta and i'm only having small bugs which come and go and are reset when an area/dungeon is exited so no biggy, I completed normal difficulty multiplayer alongside my brother a couple days ago and experienced no game ending bugs whatsoever that we had experienced in the previous month so the developers are obviously working hard on this.If you're expecting a bug free multiplayer option then wait a bit - it's open beta there are gonna be bugs, otherwise this game is absolutely fantastic and one of my new favourites that i'd recommend to anyone.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												I got a 4-pack of this game ON SALE (key word there) For $1.79 during the summer sale and let me tell you i am thouroughly impressed.For a relatively cheap game it is very woth your while to purchase. I played it with some buddies for multiple hours now and for the cost i got some amazing enjoyment out of it. This game actually has some longevity to it compared to other cheap games and that is great. It is great fun with friends however it does fall flat playing solo.That being said it does have numerous bugs that will crash your game (like talking to the landlord but i think that has been patched,) The town is shallow, and you cant really purchase things outside of levels with your hard earned goals, also there is nothing purchasable that wont disappear upon death. And the DLC is grossly overpriced for what you get.But despite the negatives the game looks amazing, the short cutscenes after bossfights ACTUALLY INCLUDE YOUR (key word is YOUR) CHARACTER(S) opposed to other games which will use filler characters in the clips (which by the way are really well designed)Quick things to list:-Decent graphics outside of clips-Wont break weaker computers-Every character feels unique in both abilities and design-Game feels too easy on first playthrough (probably intentional) however becomes basically impossible on next difficulty up-Wave trigger is broken and you can spam it and skip to the last wave, also skips to last wave randomlyOverall: Great game to pick up on sale if you have friends to play with, I fell in love with it, However not worth your while solo, DLC not worth it unless on sale7/10 - Dat Boi

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Most of the classes in this game are horrible.  The skills either dont do any damage, have long cooldowns, or both.  The only class I found enjoyable was the Redneck due to his ability to cleave multiple enemies and weird random skills.   Any other class is going to require you to slam your head against the wall as you die multiple times from weak enemies.  Adding points to strength barely does anything to up your damage, instead relics are your damage modifiers which are rare.  I initially thought about buying 3 copies for friends but thank goodness I didnt because there is no multiplayer.  Also not being able to shoot diagonally is a real pain.  Have fun running around in circles just so you can line enemies up to attack them if your ranged.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												Can't reasonably recommend the game. The game has amazing potential, but I'm not convinced it will ever get there. The development team is small, and is very focused on releasing DLC for the game. While the DLC adds new content, the game is full of bugs. Some modes like multiplayer are pseudo unplayable. You can play a few levels, maybe you'll get a few hours in, then you'll run into a boss or something that will crash you, and there isnt anything you can do about it. Also at the time of this post, strange errors happen with damage scaling of people who join games in multiplayer. The Devs admit that the game isn't polished yet, and they hope to get it there one day, but they really need to focus less on additional content. But unfortunately there isn't much money in it.  Lastly, I perused the forum quite a bit to get an answer to some of the bugs in the game, or report them myself, and see if devs were working on them. Quite a number of the responses were abrasive from a member of the development team.

												fun game.but glad i got it while it was on sale because i still feel like i overpayed, because you can get Hero Siege for FREE if you have an Andriod device. it is the basicly the same game, it has some minor user interface differences and ingame purchase to unlock some things, but the game play is the same.untill just a few days ago you could get the exact same version as what is now here on Steam for free through the Windows Store, but they just recently pulled it out of the Windows Store.if you have an Andriod device just search Google Play for Hero Siege and get it for free, unless you really want it through Steam, or unless you really want to support the developersalthough the forum mods (Tupu and PaNicci) from thier development team keeps deleting this info from the game's forums, they dont want Steam users knowing you can get it free else where. kind of rude on thier part. so i am posting this here in a review, where hopefully Tupu or PaNicci can not delete it. you all have the right to know you can get this game for free.also the game may be available on Xbox One, but i don't know if it is free for Xbox One.despite all that i would recomend the game, it is fun, but if you can get the FREE version first before deciding to buy the Steam version

												I wanted to like this game, but I think my biggest gripe with it was that there was no clear sense of direction and purpose. There's nothing in the game to tell you what to do, and frankly the combat is rather boring and repetetive. I'm new to dungeon crawlers, so I'm not sure if this is what the genre has to offer but in general the game leaves me confused on what to do except slash at baddies. But besides that the levels look really messy, and the voice actor (atleast for the first guy you play as) sounds... perturbing, and not so much in the good way. I really wanted more from this game, I'm glad it was a gift.TL;DR : Boring combat, no direction.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												There's potential for a good game here, and the coding is certainly competently executed, but the game is ultimately far too poorly-designed to be a success.For starters, the game is too random (even by roguelike standards - sure, potions in Nethack are random, but the key difference - and one which the developer may not quite grasp - is that Nethack potions CAN be identified through various means before swallowing them) and certain elements are extremely poorly-thought-out (there's no "momentary invulnerability" on hit - so if you happen to wander into a patch of poison, you die pretty much instantly) or just clunky (it's too easy to get hung up on scenery, and sometimes traps can be spawned "behind" trees and other objects, rendering them completely invisible until you happen to get killed).On top of that, the game is EXTREMELY grindy - I love a good grind as much as the next guy, but only when the game is fun and fair. "Fun" is in the eye of the beholder, but "fair" is not, and with its plethora of one-hit-kills and suicide potions, this game is anything but.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												This is a really nice game.Is it worth full price? I would say yes.Your goal is to beat the waves that come at you by using your attack. There are different classes, and the attack is different for each one. There is only 1 attack per class, but each class has abililities and perks that can modify the class specific attack, which is very nice indeed. For instance, as a pyro, the base attack is a ball of fire, but as you level up you can improve the chance of instead of firing a ball of fire, you fire a meteor, or even fire the base ball of fire in multiple directions. There's all sort of crazy things you can do really.As you beat waves, you go trough different areas. Those areas are different each time you play (they are somewhat randomly generated), and different areas have different traps and enemies. What i mean by "somewhat randomly generated" is that for instance the size of the area, the type of the enemies, and the type of traps you can expect in one area it's always the same, but they are placed in different locations each time, and some instances may or may not have some traps. That makes each play-trough unique, and you may have to adopt slightly different strategies each time. Killing enemies gives you experience, which you use to level up. When you level up you are given points that you can spend on improving your stats. There are 4 stats in the game, those being Damage, Attack Speed, Armor and Health. Also, you receive points to improve/unlock abilities or the chances of your base attack do something different. It's also a rogue-like, in the sense that if you die on one wave, you're done and you have to start from the Wave 1 of the act all over again. Though, unless you're playing on Hardcore, you keep you character, its levels, points, abilities etc.. Part of the point of the game is level up so you're stronger the next time you play.The game also features dungeons, that appear on the areas of the game. The dungeons sometimes are harder to beat than the normal waves, but they give you an item if you beat the dungeon, so it's more often than not worth the risk. Those special items, called "relics" are also given to you each time you beat an area, and they really improve you experience with the game. Those items do all sort of crazy things. Some give you base attack a chance of freezing/poison enemies, others give you homing missiles that are around you that fire automatically and help you killing the enemies, others "simply" improve your base stats etc... I say "simply" because even though "improve you base stats" may sound something boring, it can REALLY help you out making areas easier. These items are also wiped from you if you die, so you have to collect new items again each time you play. The game seems to have a finite number of these relics, but there's a large number of them and the items you find are also randomly generated.As you kill enemies they drop gold, that you can spend on the store on thing like health potions, damage boost potions etc. Those boosts are also only valid for that specific play-trough, they reset if you die, as well as all the gold you happen to find. The game has also a rare currency, the crystals. These crystals are really hard to find, as far as i know there's only 2 ways to get them: crystal chests (chests that need a crystal key to be opened) or bosses that sometimes drop a few of them, very rare to happen though. With crystals you can buy cosmetic stuff, the possibility of have a skeleton pet the next time you play (that actually helps you fight the enemies), the possibility of starting with a relic on your next playtrough, crystal keys. You might be like "Hang on a minute..you say you can get crystals from crystal chests, but you have to spend crystals on crystal keys to open them, what?" Yes, the good news is that those crystals chests often give you more crystals than the ones you spent on the key, along side with tons of gold and possibly a relic. And for those wondering, i'm happy to say that the game has no microtransactions whatsoever.I really recommend this game. Already put 10hrs on it and will definitively put more.The only word of warning advice before buying this game it's that even though it's on sale as a completed game, it is not. As the time i'm writing this, new classes and multiplayer are promised and are still to be added. Some balance improvements are still being made. It's more like a beta, but with a pretty solid gameplay already.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6
												Bad game design at at almost every point.  It feels like they took bad part of every ARPG and shoved it all into one game.  The pixel art is kind of cool, but more than half of it is completely uninspired rip offs of other intellectual properties.The sound design is also just kinda...bad.The screen becomes of cluster-♥♥♥♥ of pixels, to the point where you can't even tell what is happening.  Playing co-op and just putting all attributes into damage, most enemies die before you can even see them on screen. There is so much CRAP LOOT just thrown at you...it just adds to the clutter.There are almost no actual gameplay mechanics...first of all you are restricted to shooting up, down, left, and right...but the game does not seem like it was designed to have that restriction at all.Most things die so quickly that nothing gets a chance to happen, or vice versa...you die so quickly that you don't get a chance to do anything.  It becomes a game of who gets one-shot first, therefore no mechanics needed.This feels like something some students would put together as a school project...not a finished game that people should pay money for.I commend the devs for sticking with their game, however they need to hire design director or something, because it's obvious that they don't really know what they're doing when it comes to that field.I got this game shortly after it initially came out, and at that time it was supposed to be a rogue-lite or something; now it seems like it's trying more to be like diablo, with a hub world/portal system like crash bandicoot.I just don't understand what they are trying to accomplish with this game, and I'm not entirely certain the devs do either.If anyone has any questions, or concerns, I can try to answer them. Verdict: Would Not Recommend (No hate intended, this is my opinion)

A lot of abilities and classes are borrowed from Diablo 2 and Binding of Isaac, but without compelling synergy system that would make building your character at least remotely interesting. Constant spam of enemies and effects and meaningles items, horrible potion and buff systems, sprites overlapping each other and making it harder to see on the battlefield, dungeons resetting the level for no reason - it's just a frustrating mess of a game.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												I saw Hero Siege on a list of local co-op games, added it to my wish list without much thought, and eventually bought it in a Humble Bundle. I expected it to be somewhat similar to Hammerwatch, but instead it's a rather dull wave-based twin-stick shooter which doesn't have much going for it. Its art style and graphics are somewhat mundane and amateurish, and everything on the screen sort of blends together when there's a lot of combat going on. On top of that, the game's sound effects are terrible. There are locked menu items on every menu with references to DLC or future DLC, and the game doesn't seem to bring any new ideas to the table, either. Overall, Hero Siege feels very amateurish--it reminds me of something I might have made at age 12 with RPG maker or similar, or maybe a flash game one might have found on newgrounds.com in 2002.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												With the overwhelming amount of positive reviews and the game being marketed as "[...] one of the most loved indie hack n slash games with roguelike elements! Join the fun now!!" I did indeed expect to have fun.But fun was not had. This is a plain twin stick shooter masked as a hack n slash. Acts are also promised, but is rather a randomized arena where waves of enemies spawn. That was another letdown because I expected a randomized map as in a place where the outer edges shift in shape instead of a simple square. Though to be fair, there's dungeons. However I never had the chance to enter one before I lost interest.Third letdown was the combat. I always play melee whenever I have the choice and the little I did that in this game consisted of pointing the left stick away from the monsters and the right stick towards them, occasionally pressing it whenever a skill had cooled down.All in all this game feels like it would fare better as a newly released early access game. Since it is not I just can't find a reason to recommend this game.

												I wanna like it... I do like it... kinda... So I've played for enough time to get a feel for it. I've only played single player which is still a lot of fun. I have still never been able to spend the coins. The shops are rare and to stumble upon one with enough coins to spend on something is even more rare. It just seems like a broken mechanic. The rouge-like elements are just not strong enough for me to boast about them. When you die, almost everything but your level goes back to zero and nothing else carries over.Not very rouge-like if you ask me.

												*************************************************************************************************************************************Ill Be honest, this is no were near a perfect game, and the amount of bugs/stupid♥♥♥♥♥♥that exists such as other players in your game not being able to do damage, or do the right amount of damage (see necro bugs). It is a good time sync, and is unique in the rougue-like diabloesc style. Don't listen to the people here ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on the devs calling this a cash cow(unless they start releasing micro transations for ingame currency). 												A pretty fun game that unfortuinatly lets itself down with bad practises. In order to get the achievemnts for the main game you HAVE to buy DLC.There are some also annoying little things, like you have to press a button to pick items up when you are close enough. Sometimes these items spawn ontop of the doors or ladders you go close to in order to leave to the next level. This usually results in the loss of those items, as once you leave an area and return it's reset itself meaning all the items you left there are gone.The game can also be quite annoying too if you're trying to build up alot of items (which since it has a small roguelike element) you loose them on death. I find that when I die, I either get one or two shot, even after assigning all talent points into damage reduction and health.So I'd probably recommend just getting Diablo, which when you've bought all the DLC for this game comes out to the same price xP

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												Take my words - This game is super fun. This is basically a hybrid twin stick shooter, but here no mouse is involved. wasd are used for movement, cursor is for shooting. There are 7 classes, 5 are playable at the moment of writing, rest of the two are locked. Depending on which character you choose, you can turn this into a hack and slash game or just play as top down shooters like Gun Bros. Multiplayer is work in progress as I understand from the game menu. This is a super fun game that you need to play now. The RPG elements are not too heavy and there's only skill progression here. No dialogue or choice to make. Each levels are randomly generated. I am still new to this game so I'll update this review once I discover new contents. Grab it if you still don't have this yet. This game has been bundled at least 5 times if I'm not wrong. So, it should not be expensive if you know where to look(*wink* trade *wink*).

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												I played this game for only around 5 hours, and I'm already in love with it. I just finished Act I with 4 legendary pieces of armor, and Hero Seige has only gotten more fun over the time. There are a couple down sides to it however, but we'll get into that after I state the pros. So, let's get into the details.The game is quite addicting. While it can get a bit repettitive if you're, quite frankly, bad at it, since you face the same monsters and bosses every time you play, if you're skilled at the game you can pass Acts "quickly". Each act has it's own bosses, monsters, traps, etc. The one things that I have found to stay the same is the drops and the layouts of the dungeons and crypts. Even after I beat Act I and got into the snowy act, the crypts and dungeons are still the same textiles as before, dirty. This may be for a reason, since it is underground, but I would have liked to seen some more details, perhaps at least some snow, or maybe some other factor that would indicate the low temperature. One thing I liked about changing acts is that it seems that the previous act's bosses are the new act's normal enemies. For example, a boss called "Annie" that appeared on the first act, appeared as a normal enemy with her health in the next act. Another thing I like about Hero Siege is it's replayability. While it may get a little boring once you beaten all the acts with each character, and I highly doubt many people have done it, each time you play a new act, or a new character, the fun factor doesn't decrease. Hero Siege brings a lot of new content to the table for each of it's components. Each acts has different bosses, enemies, traps. Each character has different weapons, abilities, and special buffs. For example, my Demon Slayer has a lot of health and speed, while my friends Samurai seemed to have a lot of attack damage and got a lot omore experience then me. Which brings me to another point, this game can be played single player, and be extremely fun. While this may seem like a wierd point, and it is, since I can't really word it correctly, I have to give an example. Basically, I can sit down at my PC, skype a friend, and we can both play in our own single player worlds, talking to each other about new things we would, and new bosses we're fighting, and our stats, weapons, relics, etc. Almost none of the games I've ever found had that feature where I can just talk to someone about thsi game and have a lot of fun. So, I may have left a lot out of the game in terms of pros, and I have, I need to be starting on the cons. One of the main problems I have about this game is it's terrible multiplayer support. Normally on Steam games, you can just press join game or something of that nature. In Hero Siege, you have to make your own server by port-forwarding, which not a lot of people know how to. But that's not an issue for me, other than that I can't port-forward, as in it just doesn't work on my computer. My problem is the amount of bugs in multiplayer. I have seen some update logs, and I can see that they are fixing a lot of them, so I guess that good. Another con with this game is how the learning isn't exactly steep, but just "there". People who are bad at the game can't exactly get better. The good loot is with the hard to defeat enemies, and without that, you can't really get better. You're just... stuck? Another thing that I didn't like was that the bosses difficulty fluctiuated, alot. Sometimes I would face a boss that I could one hit on round 24, and then I would face a boss that would one hit me on round 6. They definitely need to change the boss strength to make each boss equal to each other. Another thing that bothers me is that the bosses never really get harder. I'm not talking about through acts, but through the rounds, one boss is as easy as another. When I played the first time, the first boss was extremely hard, and I found pleasure in that. Over the time, as I got better and better loot, I found that none of the bosses leveled up to match my skill. I could instantly take them down, and sometimes, I wouldn't even notice they were bosses. That's due to some of the bosses and almost all of the mini-bosses being re-colors of other enemies. I would like the bosses and the enemies get higher in stats as I level up, since now it's just kind of boring to go through the earlier rounds. I just skip them all, and then just shoot them down easily. Other than that though, the game has really no more disadvantages that I can think of.So, now the real question, would I recommend this game? Yes, definitely. I am recommending this to all my friends at school, and even some out of school. If you're not really good at games like this, more so, terrible at games like this, don't get it. You won't really advance and it'll just be boring. However, if you can handle a challenge, and be patient with the game to level up and get your equipment, I promise this game will be a good buy, I only noticed this game when it was on sale for $.050, and I got the 4-pack. I would probably have gotten it even for it's $6 price now.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												It's an ok game. Has a few issues but still kind of fun.One the biggest issues is the difficulty distribution, especially in the randomly spawning crypts and dungeons. You could get an easy small corridor with a chest in or you could get placed with several monsters with thousands of HP and insane defense, in a room that doesn't allow for kiting or dodging, basically meaning an instant loss that you can only avoid by never taking dungeons. Same deal with standard level boss monsters. You could get an easy melee thing that does nothing and has barely any health, or you get a ranged behemoth, with tons of health, spewing AOE that puts Gradius to shame.Another issue is the seemingly random events that happen thoughout the stages. They vary from raining coins, to raining fiery balls of death. Most of them are fine, but one of them is unavoidable and basically an instant kill. It spawns spiked balls (like a mace head) that roam around the stage in a set pattern. However, it seems to always spawn one of these balls on top of you. Which makes you take 3 or 4 hits before you can escape, which is a problem when you can generally only take 3 hits before you die, from anything.If you can put up with these issues and you enjoy playing Hammerwatch or The Binding of Isaac, you will probably enjoy this game. Challenging, addictive and well worth the few quid it costs.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
Product received for free
												DISCLAIMER: This review is based from my playthrough as 'The Necromancer' (from Normal to Destruction), so I'm sorry if I haven't played the other classes (cause I don't really care about them, at all...) and I also played it in single player... That's all!So yeah... The ReviewWhat I Hate:It's buggy and it's broken...Occasional Crashes and Freezes...It's hard at first, but in later levels, it gets really (I mean REALLY) EASY!The Boss for me... Is also very, VERY EASY (Like WTF?!)And Finally...DLCs & Paywalls (The Acts V and beyond, due to the fact that the game itself is kinda easy and short... Also I just hate Paywalls in general...)However...What I Like:Nice GraphicsGreat 2D Diablo Retro Fast-Paced Action GameDecent Time WasterGood for getting quick and easy achievements (and some other stuffs)Better to Play it with Friends (OBVIOUSLY!)Nice references (one of them is a secret level)And it's Cheap (The Base Game, not counting the DLCs)Overall: I don't know if The Necromancer is just OP as♥♥♥♥♥♥♥(which explains why everything is so damn EASY!) but I enjoyed the game as a time waster... The graphics are good to look at, the gameplay is kinda fun as a Hack 'n Slash game and it's cheap (especially in sales). But considering the fact that it's still broken after 2 years since it was released, plus it's kinda short (4 Acts), very easy in terms of all difficulty (in my opinion) and the game teases you with DLCs, I can only consider this...As an AVERAGE game at best...For me, this is NOT the best Hack 'n Slash game, there are better ones out there that pretty much does the same thing and MOAR, let's say like I don't know *cough* Path of Exile, and *cough* it's FREE *more cough*...But again, it's not the worst one out there. It does for what it can do in it's respective genre. And if you're like me, you can have a good time playing this, 'cause admittedly, it can be a fun game. It's retro (I'm a sucker for 2D Games), and it's cheap (even though it should've been a free game instead). Just don't play it alone please, lest you'll get bored pretty easily... Play it with and you'll get the most fun out of this game...PS: They should rename the Necromancer Class as "Pimps 'n Hoes"...Because most of of it's minions seems to have the urge to break dance in dark places. Should've brought some poles to dance with if their gonna do that!PPS: Devs, fix the game please? I DON'T LIKE USELESS DANCING MINIONS!!~

Also I just hate Paywalls in general...)However...What I Like:Nice GraphicsGreat 2D Diablo Retro Fast-Paced Action GameDecent Time WasterGood for getting quick and easy achievements (and some other stuffs)Better to Play it with Friends (OBVIOUSLY!)Nice references (one of them is a secret level)And it's Cheap (The Base Game, not counting the DLCs)Overall: I don't know if The Necromancer is just OP as♥♥♥♥♥♥♥(which explains why everything is so damn EASY!) but I enjoyed the game as a time waster... The graphics are good to look at, the gameplay is kinda fun as a Hack 'n Slash game and it's cheap (especially in sales). But considering the fact that it's still broken after 2 years since it was released, plus it's kinda short (4 Acts), very easy in terms of all difficulty (in my opinion) and the game teases you with DLCs, I can only consider this...As an AVERAGE game at best...For me, this is NOT the best Hack 'n Slash game, there are better ones out there that pretty much does the same thing and MOAR, let's say like I don't know *cough* Path of Exile, and *cough* it's FREE *more cough*...But again, it's not the worst one out there. It does for what it can do in it's respective genre. And if you're like me, you can have a good time playing this, 'cause admittedly, it can be a fun game. It's retro (I'm a sucker for 2D Games), and it's cheap (even though it should've been a free game instead). Just don't play it alone please, lest you'll get bored pretty easily... Play it with and you'll get the most fun out of this game...PS: They should rename the Necromancer Class as "Pimps 'n Hoes"...Because most of of it's minions seems to have the urge to break dance in dark places. Should've brought some poles to dance with if their gonna do that!PPS: Devs, fix the game please? I DON'T LIKE USELESS DANCING MINIONS!!~

												Edit: Since I originally wrote this, they've added a lot of extra characters (I think there's nearly twice as many as they once had), added heaps of new content, changed the achievements, added an overworld, and from what I can tell, squashed a lot of bugs. Nice work!I loved Diablo and I see a lot of comparisons made between the two which can only be a good thing in my opinion.  This is a very fun, just one more go, rogue-like. The main problem at the time of writing this is that the achievements for completing acts aren't unlocking but a fix is on the way apparently.  I've also had dungeons spawn on top of me trapping me in the wall until the mobs killed me.  A little frustrating but no big deal.

number of helpful: 17 of 34 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												With the overwhelming amount of positive reviews and the game being marketed as "[...] one of the most loved indie hack n slash games with roguelike elements! Join the fun now!!" I did indeed expect to have fun.But fun was not had. This is a plain twin stick shooter masked as a hack n slash. Acts are also promised, but is rather a randomized arena where waves of enemies spawn. That was another letdown because I expected a randomized map as in a place where the outer edges shift in shape instead of a simple square. Though to be fair, there's dungeons. However I never had the chance to enter one before I lost interest.Third letdown was the combat. I always play melee whenever I have the choice and the little I did that in this game consisted of pointing the left stick away from the monsters and the right stick towards them, occasionally pressing it whenever a skill had cooled down.All in all this game feels like it would fare better as a newly released early access game. Since it is not I just can't find a reason to recommend this game.

I find that when I die, I either get one or two shot, even after assigning all talent points into damage reduction and health.So I'd probably recommend just getting Diablo, which when you've bought all the DLC for this game comes out to the same price xP

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												It's an ok game. Has a few issues but still kind of fun.One the biggest issues is the difficulty distribution, especially in the randomly spawning crypts and dungeons. You could get an easy small corridor with a chest in or you could get placed with several monsters with thousands of HP and insane defense, in a room that doesn't allow for kiting or dodging, basically meaning an instant loss that you can only avoid by never taking dungeons. Same deal with standard level boss monsters. You could get an easy melee thing that does nothing and has barely any health, or you get a ranged behemoth, with tons of health, spewing AOE that puts Gradius to shame.Another issue is the seemingly random events that happen thoughout the stages. They vary from raining coins, to raining fiery balls of death. Most of them are fine, but one of them is unavoidable and basically an instant kill. It spawns spiked balls (like a mace head) that roam around the stage in a set pattern. However, it seems to always spawn one of these balls on top of you. Which makes you take 3 or 4 hits before you can escape, which is a problem when you can generally only take 3 hits before you die, from anything.If you can put up with these issues and you enjoy playing Hammerwatch or The Binding of Isaac, you will probably enjoy this game. Challenging, addictive and well worth the few quid it costs.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												I played this game for only around 5 hours, and I'm already in love with it. I just finished Act I with 4 legendary pieces of armor, and Hero Seige has only gotten more fun over the time. There are a couple down sides to it however, but we'll get into that after I state the pros. So, let's get into the details.The game is quite addicting. While it can get a bit repettitive if you're, quite frankly, bad at it, since you face the same monsters and bosses every time you play, if you're skilled at the game you can pass Acts "quickly". Each act has it's own bosses, monsters, traps, etc. The one things that I have found to stay the same is the drops and the layouts of the dungeons and crypts. Even after I beat Act I and got into the snowy act, the crypts and dungeons are still the same textiles as before, dirty. This may be for a reason, since it is underground, but I would have liked to seen some more details, perhaps at least some snow, or maybe some other factor that would indicate the low temperature. One thing I liked about changing acts is that it seems that the previous act's bosses are the new act's normal enemies. For example, a boss called "Annie" that appeared on the first act, appeared as a normal enemy with her health in the next act. Another thing I like about Hero Siege is it's replayability. While it may get a little boring once you beaten all the acts with each character, and I highly doubt many people have done it, each time you play a new act, or a new character, the fun factor doesn't decrease. Hero Siege brings a lot of new content to the table for each of it's components. Each acts has different bosses, enemies, traps. Each character has different weapons, abilities, and special buffs. For example, my Demon Slayer has a lot of health and speed, while my friends Samurai seemed to have a lot of attack damage and got a lot omore experience then me. Which brings me to another point, this game can be played single player, and be extremely fun. While this may seem like a wierd point, and it is, since I can't really word it correctly, I have to give an example. Basically, I can sit down at my PC, skype a friend, and we can both play in our own single player worlds, talking to each other about new things we would, and new bosses we're fighting, and our stats, weapons, relics, etc. Almost none of the games I've ever found had that feature where I can just talk to someone about thsi game and have a lot of fun. So, I may have left a lot out of the game in terms of pros, and I have, I need to be starting on the cons. One of the main problems I have about this game is it's terrible multiplayer support. Normally on Steam games, you can just press join game or something of that nature. In Hero Siege, you have to make your own server by port-forwarding, which not a lot of people know how to. But that's not an issue for me, other than that I can't port-forward, as in it just doesn't work on my computer. My problem is the amount of bugs in multiplayer. I have seen some update logs, and I can see that they are fixing a lot of them, so I guess that good. Another con with this game is how the learning isn't exactly steep, but just "there". People who are bad at the game can't exactly get better. The good loot is with the hard to defeat enemies, and without that, you can't really get better. You're just... stuck? Another thing that I didn't like was that the bosses difficulty fluctiuated, alot. Sometimes I would face a boss that I could one hit on round 24, and then I would face a boss that would one hit me on round 6. They definitely need to change the boss strength to make each boss equal to each other. Another thing that bothers me is that the bosses never really get harder. I'm not talking about through acts, but through the rounds, one boss is as easy as another. When I played the first time, the first boss was extremely hard, and I found pleasure in that. Over the time, as I got better and better loot, I found that none of the bosses leveled up to match my skill. I could instantly take them down, and sometimes, I wouldn't even notice they were bosses. That's due to some of the bosses and almost all of the mini-bosses being re-colors of other enemies. I would like the bosses and the enemies get higher in stats as I level up, since now it's just kind of boring to go through the earlier rounds. I just skip them all, and then just shoot them down easily. Other than that though, the game has really no more disadvantages that I can think of.So, now the real question, would I recommend this game? Yes, definitely. I am recommending this to all my friends at school, and even some out of school. If you're not really good at games like this, more so, terrible at games like this, don't get it. You won't really advance and it'll just be boring. However, if you can handle a challenge, and be patient with the game to level up and get your equipment, I promise this game will be a good buy, I only noticed this game when it was on sale for $.050, and I got the 4-pack. I would probably have gotten it even for it's $6 price now.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												I absolutely love this game, pretty much anything "dungeon crawler" I love to death and this game perfectly fits in my favorites list.  However that being said, I have very mixed feelings and can recommend buying this game for certain things and avoiding it for others. I am changing my Not-Recommended to Recommended for somethings.-- Singleplayer -- (Recommended)The gameplay for Hero Siege reminds me of Diablo 2 and The Binding of Issac I can say that after awhile of playing I haven't encountered many issues due to recent patches. I can honestly say that if you are looking for an amazing dungeon crawler experience grab this game immediatly. -- Multiplayer -- (Not Recommended)Oh boy this is where the fun begins. Let's just start with the registration process of PanicNet. You need to create an account with PanicNet in order to play online. People have been having trouble with this however I have not, it worked perfectly fine for me. Now onto the actual gameplay, this is where the♥♥♥♥♥♥hits the fan. 1. The delay when you are attacking is horrible if you are not the one hosting the actual session, and yes I have played with many different people so it can't be lag. 2. Things tend to break alot especially quests, you will at some point get quests when you are playing and sometimes the objectives for the quest will be outside the map not allowing you to complete the quest. 3. Like singleplayer crashes tend to occur not as much but they do exist. Oh... did I mention how BUGGY AS♥♥♥♥♥♥IT IS? *ahem* it's quite bad.If you are planning to play singleplayer that is fine go ahead and buy the game however if you are planning to buy the game for multiplayer I would hold off until they fix it, they have been working hard on this game so I don't see these issues lasting much longer.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												It's remarkably good at capturing the important elements of Diablo II: loot, navigating skill trees, corralling enemies in order to maximize the number you hit with your stronger skills, that sort of thing. Once I noticed that I could repeatedly tap the next wave button to get all of the level's waves to come at me, the combat became reasonably challenging.It does have some drawbacks though: I've only had a few times where my build was so awful that the bosses lasted longer than the short line they say when they spawn; the game crashed a few times, once it explained itself with an "Out of Memory Exception" (I probably had about 4 GB for it to use at the time), other times it just sort of forgot to draw new frames to the screen for a couple seconds, while I listened to monsters trying to kill me. I don't recommend entering a dungeon while a boss is in the process of spawning. And one time I got knocked over the border fence that prevents you from going outside the level, and couldn't get back in.Sadly, this game has not gotten me any closer to figuring out how to do Diablo-style loot without ending up with Diablo-style combat. Oh well.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
I really wish steam had a “neutral option.”Review in a minute: 


YouTube™ Video: Review in a Few: Hero Siege 

			Views: 105		

			Here is my review in a few for Hero Siege. Buy the game here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/269210/ My written review can be found on steam here:...		

To preface this, I own all collector’s edition DLC and will likely continue to purchase expansions.Hero siege is a hack and slash horde based roguelike with RPG elements tagged on. Containing two player local co-op and 4 player online co-op, with many different classes to play for strong replayability.   It has solid character progression, leading you from a frustrating insta-death to a godlike destroyer of worlds for its RPG influence.  It’s heavily reminiscent of Diablo 2, the two creators being huge fans who enjoyed the grind.It has a lot of visual variety, but it’s mostly a façade covering up its bland designs.  Every map has a different look to it, but the randomness leaves them all feeling the same – With just houses and holes to fill the space between traps and events, nothing changes level to level besides the colors.  This isn’t entirely a bad thing, as it adds a certain familiarity to it all.The controls are very responsive in combat with both a controller and a keyboard; however the menu controls are very much designed for a controller.  Navigating the inventory is a huge pain unless you’re working your thumbs, as it has strange keybinds and lacks mouse support.  With a large variety of classes to pick from, you can find a class that fits your playstyle, some more interactive than others.  This however has led to balance issues, causing certain classes to be useless during certain stages of gamestate.  There’s a few classes locked behind a DLC paywall, restricting a few unique playstyles.Relics are drops that can change the way you play, and add a lot of roguelike feel to the game.  You collect one relic per boss/dungeon/crypt you complete, and they disappear if you die.  While a great mechanic, it means that death requires you to replay old levels or be severely gimped.  Some relics were added with the DLC, so if you play without it some relics are unobtainable.  They weren’t added retroactively.There’s an item system as well, which carries over between lives.  It allows you to customize your characters beyond skills, and in some cases gives you them.  However I’ve found it leads more towards getting one über item early on and keeping it until you hit max level rather than gearing up slowly.Overall I’m very neutral on the game.  I would definitely recommend it if you enjoy roguelikes, Diablo 2, or Gauntlet, but I also wouldn’t recommend it if you never plan on picking up the DLC as the basegame is lacking in certain regards that has been fixed by the DLC.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												The Game is fun, but it has many flaws. First of all, the combination of genres is really cool. It's basically a Beat'em Up + RPG + Rogue-Lite, it definitely has many inspirations from The Binding of Isaac (it even borrows ideas like the bible makes you fly", "Book of Belilal, gives you DMG", and others, plus the way you attack.). Now, when it reaches a certain point, with a certain combination of items, i became a lawnmower with my Viking, destroying multiple waves of monsters in high difficulties alone, with ease. Now, i'll let the flaws come in. Trying to play with friends is a nightmare. You can either port-foward or use Hamachl, but the game constantly crashes, bugs you back to the lobby, many funky stuff that annoys. In a server, you can exit in you don't lose any of your items, so the game is kinda broken there.The sound effects are nice, but most of the voice acting is really unprofessional and distracting, like that Stickman active item that is really weird and badly dubbed. Bosses are ridiculous easy at the beginning, at the point of enemies having equal or more HP than them, and later on bosses have a weird difficulty spike. (Hp barely changes between Normal and Nightmare, there was another one that jumped to Hell where Anubis had like, 500k hp, then on Hell he had 2 or more Million hp.)There is a ridiculously frustrating puzzle in a dungeon where you have to place many crates over buttons (including a line of buttons, it probably sparkles the memories of whoeved did it), where if you don't have any flight it will be a nightmare, the crates get stuck in corners, and any slight touch can move them, so you gotta restart it a lot and it bugged me a ton.And one of the biggest problems are the DLCs. Pratically half of the game content is locked behind DLCs, which are more expensive than the game itself. So yeah, if you're not into grinding through the same levels over and over with increasing difficulty, ready your wallet.Now, is the game worth it? Well, yeah! I had fun with it playing solo, it's satisfying to cut my way through enemies, it has cool mechanics and creative concepts, they only need to improve the game a bit to make it golden (looking at you, servers!).

Posted: November 19, 2015
												Used The Holy Bible to gain Levitation, and then used Satan's Tooth to set all the enemies on the screen on fire. On a serious note; this game is amazing. If you like looting, dungeon crawling, hack & slash rogue-type games, then you'll have a ton of fun with this. The game is currently beta testing dedicated servers for Multiplayer, however port forwarding works well enough for local play. So be sure to jump in with a friend! They update content frequently, however there are a few bugs, but it's understandable. Once you've played the game for a few hours, you might consider getting the DLC's as well, as they add a ton of extra content, bosses, loot, maps and classes. As they are, they're worth every dime. Overall, this is a pretty fun, addictive game. Got a few dollars to spare? Be sure to pick this up. :)

												Hero Siege; this game is simply amazing. It's a rogue-like, hack 'n' slash, RPG. Has the feeling of Binding of Isaac and the feeling of Diablo. Beware that the farther you get into the game the more grinding you're going to need to do in order to progress. Pros	- Tons of Different Classes to Choose From- Smooth Gameplay with Great Controls- Pixelated Game with a Great RPG FeelingCons- The DLC is a little bit on the pricey side (especially if you bought this game when it was on sale)Final Verdict;10/10

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												You are going to die, you are going to be resurrected, and then you are going to die some more. Keep your stats, get stronger and re-attempt the dungeon. This game will drive you crazy, but it is that fun kind of crazy that will make you go back for a bigger beatting. Controls are simple and smooth, plays a lot like an early Zelda game. Think SNES Zelda. Lots of different character classes, i started with the nomad. The dungeon seems to be randomized, every time you die you begin in a new location with different items. It makes for a sense of suspense especially when you are starting out and don't exactly know what to expect. Boxes and plants can be destroyed for items. Health however is scarce. You can play a few quick runs or a few hours, it is up to you. This game is easy to pick up and put down at any time. No need to remember where you left off. If you want a game with a huge amount of replay value, this is for you.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												Well, let me say that this game feels like an addiction.  I was not sure what to expect at first, but 10 minutes in and I was hooked.  It is a rougelike, but does not have permadeath.  You die, then keep your character and keep on.  This game reminds me why I loved Diablo 2 so much and what makes games like Torchlight so fun.  Kill and loot, kill and loot, and this one has great pixel blood and wonderful sound and music.  I have been playing with an Xbox 360 pad and have really enjoyed the vibration that ties in very well with the action.  I am of the opinion that this game deserves your money and your time.  Really a fun and enjoyable game.  Also, I still have not completed the first world, but I have seen tons and tons of random baddies where I died in a few seconds to a few hour long marathon of fun and loot.   Really seems random and depends on what you find.  Funniest thing I have found was some Razor Headphones which caused me to have Music Notes shoot out of my head and attack all the bad guys!  Was hard to see, but was super fun and funny.  Try this game you might just fall in love with it!

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												If you want something to play that'll pass the time or crave a game with the classic RPG feeling to it, then Hero Siege is the perfect game for you. It's, in my opinion, a fantastic little gem of a game. Gameplay wise it feels as though the developer stuffed Diablo’s more reserved brother into a blender with The Binding of Issac, and added in a pinch of Killing Floor for good measure. In more sensible terms, it’s got a great number of rogue-like and RPG elements to it. There are a number of different levels, ranging from forests to snowy tundras, deserts and many more. At the end of each of these levels you can collect random pieces of loot, or relics as they’re called, which grant you varying stats and abilities. These relics come in four different flavours; weapon enhancing ones, which, as the name suggests, enhances your weapon giving it extra powers. For example an item called the Basilisk's Tooth makes it so that you have a 2% chance to turn enemies to stone. There are also passive relics as well, which improve your character’s skills. One example is the Cactus, which periodically spawns a cactus on the nearest enemy. The third relic type is active, which, after pressing the use key, will activate the effect of the relic. The Candy Crusher, one example of an active relic, launches candy in a ring around the player that explodes on landing. And the last relic type is orbiting, which float around the player and help during fights. One example is the Almighty Fedora which rapidly shoots projectiles.All these and many more can be obtained by progressing through the game, and surviving the large waves of enemies the game throws at you.Talking about enemies, there are a large number of different types. Ranging from axe throwing skeletons to towering yeti-like beasts. Also there are several “elite” type enemies that have particular skills that happen once they die. For example creating a large laser that spins in a circle or an X shaped explosion, which both appear where the “elite” was slain.There are also a number of RPG elements in the game too. For one, there are unique skill trees for each class, providing varying passive and active abilities, depending on which class you choose out of the possible seven, or ten (depending on whether you own the DLC). They also all have their own sort of personalities and quotes as well.Graphically the game looks a lot like your typical indie, rogue-like affair. But it fits nicely. The characters are easily distinguishable from each other and the varying levels all look pixel pretty with their individual themes and settings. Overall the game feels enjoyable to play. The classes and their skills vary enough for the game to be replayed time and time again. Not to mention the seemingly endless number of experience levels you can rack up on a single class. The enemies vary in difficultly, depending on the level, and the boss battles, for the most part, feel fairly satisfying once they eventually kick the bucket.To Conclude, I’d say that Hero Siege is worth a play, whether it’s a rogue-like or an RPG you're after, or just a quick bit of fun. It’s a satisfying game to play and well worth a go.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Hero Siege is a Hack 'n' Slash Roguelike RPG by Panic Art Studios.Hero Siege was created by Panic Art Studios and Auto Series Team Jam on September 2013 in 48 hours by Elias Viglione (Graphics), Jussi Kukkonen (Programming) and Aleksi Kujala (Composing). The final game was released 18th of December 2013. ---DLCs---     On the July 18th 2014 the first DLC, called The Karp of Doom, was released, and adds the Samurai class, new Relics, a new Act Plains of Karponia, and a new difficulty level. Users that own this DLC will also have had access to an early Alpha for multiplayer.     Second DLC, The Depths of Hell, was released on the April 30th 2015. It adds new class Fallen Paladin, 6th act The Holy Grounds, new achievements, enemies, bosses, relics, dungeons, quests, siege mode, new clothing and exclusive loot.     The Amazon Jungle Bundle, released on the 8th of June 2015, adds new Amazon class, two new relics, dark green name color and Voodoo Mask hat.     The fourth DLC, The Wrath of Mevius, was released on the 17th of November 2015. It added two new new classes, The Demon Slayer and The Demonspawn. Along with a new act "The Rift", new relics, bosses, enemies and difficult challenges.
